name: Kenzie Woodbridge
bio:
Kenzie works at BCIT, as a Systems Analyst, Web Developer, Knowledge Base Administrator and Technical Writer, and Community Manager. Kenzie has a passion for communication, continuous iterative improvement, and for systemic solutions to systemic problems. Kenzie has previously spoken at PSEWeb, BCNET, Write the Docs, and the International Conference on Communication & Media Studies and recently completed a Master's degree in Professional Communication, having written their thesis on prosocial community within Minecraft multiplayer servers. 

After long debate and discussion, it has been decided that Kenzie would, at the age of 11, likely have been sorted into Gryffindor, though there are arguments to made for every house.
title: Everyone's a player (in a mid-90s MUD)
abstract: This talk takes the approach of applying Player Type Theory (from game design) to getting people involved and engaged in technical and documentation projects in a technical environment. Practical tips are offered for dealing with lack of engagement, human-caused delays, and even workplace bullying.
description:
>  >N
> 
> You have found a secret room in the castle! You gain 26 xp.
> 
> You enter a large interior space with stone walls and a high stone ceiling. Torches flicker in wall brackets. A large self-referential tapestry hanging on the north wall shows a guild workshop full of happy weavers busily weaving the very tapestry in which they are depicted. There are exits to the east, west, and south.
> 
> Linden, another player, is here.
> Gwyrian, another player, is here.
> 
>  >say Hi
> 
> You say “Hi”
> 
> Gwyrian says “Hey! Do you want to explore this area together?”
> 
> Linden attacks you with a critical hit from their sword!
> 
> You are dead!

Other people: sometimes difficult to work with and often impossible to predict. In your technical or documentation project, how can you get the right people interested and involved? How can you keep those people happily engaged until the work is done? Is there anything you can do to prevent griefing… err, “interpersonal difficulties” from causing delays? And why do some people seem to thrive in an environment with poor documentation and how can you encourage them to participate in effectively documenting everything anyway?

In this talk, I’ll explore ways to accomplish these aims, using strategies drawn from “Player Type Theory”. For 20 years, this theory has been employed by game designers to encourage stable long-term play communities in online multiplayer games. These are strategies that I have used successfully in my workplace and they can work for you too.
notes:
This talk originally came about as a result of reading I was doing for my Master's degree and noticing the ways in which various game design and community research offered insights into the work I was doing as a technical writer and administrator of BCIT's Knowledge Base, responsible for wrangling documentation from a wide variety of folks in various positions at BCIT. I recognized that some of the strategies that these theories proposed were ones I was already using to get the best documentation out of the most experienced people, and that led me to test whether other proposed strategies might work to elicit certain behaviours within my work environment similar to the way they might in a game environment. I had some success with this and wanted to share that success with others, in addition to offering the idea that there are always new ways to look at a problem.

Technically, all I need for this talk is a projector.

name: Norah Klintberg Sakal
bio:
I'm a 30-year-old self-taught data scientist and entrepreneur from Sweden living in San Francisco. Besides from the own startup, I'm working with a research team where we are applying artificial intelligence and machine learning capabilities on biomedical science to solve big health problems. My passion and mission is to use my engineering background in biotechnology to accelerate the development of new technologies that will help doctors to cure, prevent and manage diseases. 

I’m eager to show how few lines of code can get you a whole application, end-to-end, and I'm passionate about encouraging and inspiring people to come up with new ideas on implementing data science on their own day-to-day problems by sharing my journey.
title: Guide to your own artificial intelligence application in 3 easy steps
abstract: What do you think of when you hear “artificial intelligence”? Perhaps self-driving cars, autonomous robots and Siri, Alexa or Google Home? But it doesn’t have to be that complex. You can build a powerful image classification model within a topic that inspires and interests you - with 3 easy steps.
description:
How difficult is it to build an own intelligent application? When you hear “artificial intelligence” you might think of complex solutions as self-driving cars, autonomous drones and robots or smart assistants as Alexa or Siri - but it doesn’t have to be that complex. You can build a powerful image classification model within a topic that inspires and interests you - with 3 easy steps. First, find a topic that interests you; it can be something that inspires you, excites you or a super simple day-to-day problem you’re facing. Which of your skills are matching your interests and other topics that excites you? Use that skill set to the next step, which is creating your own data.

My day-to-day repetitive problem was the daily makeup routine; it takes time and its quite uninspiring but when you finally decide to try something new - you literally get over 30 million results when search for “makeup tutorial” on Youtube and beauty being a $400 billion industry indicates that makeup play a significant part of people’s lives. How do you even know what makeup style will look as good on you as it does on all the YouTubers?

Therefore I built my very first machine learning algorithm which tells you which eye shape you have and suggests makeup styles matching your particular eye shape to enhances your features. You just snap a photo of your eyes in the app and the algorithm does the rest; telling you which eye shape you have and what makeup style that suits your particular eye shape. I build this app with 3 easy steps and I’m excited to show how you can build yourself an own powerful image classification model, with your own data, within a topic that inspires and interests you. It might sound difficult but I can’t wait to show you how few lines of Python you need to build the whole app.

What repetitive and categorizing tasks are you regularly facing? Bring your interests, passion and everyday problems and we’ll explore a more widespread adoption of artificial intelligence solutions.
notes:
I’m a 30-year-old self-taught data scientist and entrepreneur from Sweden living in San Francisco (@espressocodes on Instagram). 
My talk would fit a 30-minute talk and the essence is to encourage a more widespread exploration of artificial intelligence solutions.

Besides from the own startup, I’m working with a research team where we are applying artificial intelligence and machine learning capabilities on biomedical science to solve big health problems. My passion and mission is to accelerate the development of new technologies that will help doctors to cure, prevent and manage diseases.

The aim with this talk is to encourage and inspire to get new ideas on implementing data science on day-to-day problems. The purpose is also to show how easy it is to build yourself an own powerful image classification model in Python, with your own data, within a topic that inspires and interests you. I’m eager to show how few lines of code can get you a whole application and the focus with this talk is to concrete and showing code examples while walking through the machine learning parts and giving some basic background to deep learning.

I’ve built an image classification model in Python which is able to recognize your eye shape with convolutional neural networks and by that recommend different makeup styles that suits your particular eye shape. The idea is sprung from my daily makeup routine; it takes time and its quite uninspiring but when you finally decide to try something new you get over 30 million results searching for “makeup tutorial” on Youtube and beauty being a $400 billion industry indicates that makeup play a significant part of people’s lives. How do you know what makeup style will look as good on you as it does on all the YouTubers? The model I built is trained on various images that I annotated myself and is built using very simple convolutional neural networks with a pre-trained model (VGG16) fine-tuned on my annotated data. The results are a model with ~90% accuracy so I decided to take it further and built an app that can inspire others.

You just snap a photo with your webcam or smartphone at the web app and the algorithm tells you which shape you have + suggests makeup styles matching your eye shape to enhances your features. The app itself is built in Flask, a simple Python web server framework, which orchestrates the backend and communicates with the frontend and trained neural network.

The three steps of the talk consist of first deciding on an interest, passion or day-to-day problem, secondly how to create data based on the interest or experience and lastly training a model. I built this classification model with very little experience and the emphasis of this talk is to inform that it is possible to get state of the art results on niches which lack data and that it still exists “low having fruits” in numerous verticals.

The essence of the talk is to encourage and inspire to implement data science on niches and verticals that aligns with your own interests.

name: Nadine Lessio
bio: Nadine Lessio is a designer and technologist based out of Toronto, Canada. She has a background in visual design, programming, and an interest in how technology makes its home in the world. She is part of a wide range of communities, and her past projects have involved building alt-controllers, websites, alternative games, and physical installations. Nadine holds an MDes from OCADU’s Digital Futures program where she spent her time investigating the Internet of Things through personal assistants. By mixing development, humour, and criticism, Nadine’s work considers the interplay between technology and life, sometimes with amusing or unexpected results.
title: Working With Useless Machines
abstract: Working with Useless Machines is a project about personal assistants that don’t want to assist you. By mixing humour and satire, this talk looks at a set of prototypes developed on Alexa and Google Home, that critique corporate tech culture by turning them into devices with no utilitarian function.
description: This talk is the conference presentation format of my MDes Thesis from OCADU. The lens is very maker driven, and uses prototyping as a vehicle for research and exploration. Some things I will be covering in this talk are defining what a Useless Machine is, how they exist contextually in art and pop culture, some of the challenges of trying to make creative products with corporate platforms, and how I went about building the prototypes themselves. Expect a lot of pictures, and banter about platforms, stacks o' yaks, API wrappers, tech-art, and how people respond to things like a blender that has seasonal affective disorder.
notes: This is somewhat more of a high level concept talk where I go over experiences and challenges building these prototypes. Though Python is my primary and prefered development language. I'm one of the few people using personal assistants in an installation or creative capacity at the moment, and I have a strong background in creative tech, and talking about the process of making weird things. I’m also well informed about the current trends involving Voice Technology. Basically, I like Python as a language, and I like art. I like talking about where those two things intersect with projects like this one. I'm also pretty candid and entertaining.

name: Jill Cates
bio: I'm a data scientist and software developer from Vancouver, Canada. I currently work at a company called QxMD, where I am helping build a recommendation system for medical research papers. Proud member of PyLadies, and passionate about applying machine learning techniques to real-life, impactful scenarios.
title: A Brief Introduction to Hyperparameter Optimization
abstract: Hyperparameters are often described as "knobs" that control the learning process of a machine learning model. The hyperparameters that you choose can significantly impact model performance. In this talk, we will discuss examples of hyperparameter optimization and explore specific techniques.
description:
Machine learning models have an overwhelming amount of configurations (hyperparameters) that can drastically impact results. Selecting the best hyperparameters is not a closed-form solution, but rather an iterative process that involves training the model with different hyperparameter settings and evaluating the performance of each configuration.

Hyperparameter optimization is a key part of the data science pipeline which aims to identify the hyperparameters that optimize model performance. In this talk, we will walk through the most popular techniques for tuning hyperparameters:

- Grid search
- Random search
- Sequential model-based optimization
- Bayesian optimization

We will delve into how hyperparameters are tuned with a variety of tools including scikit-learn, scikit-optimize, and hyeropt.
notes: I deal with hyperparameter optimization in my everyday workflow, and have a solid understanding of the tools that are required to perform this process.

name: Briana Brownell
bio:
Briana Brownell is a data scientist turned tech entrepreneur, futurist and innovator. A frequent keynote speaker, expert and author, she is known for making highly technical topics accessible to non-experts, as well as leading a thoughtful technical discussion on the science behind AI. 

Currently, Briana is founder and CEO of PureStrategy.ai, a technology company that creates and deploys AI coworkers into the enterprise so employees can make faster, data-driven decisions. Briana founded PureStrategy.ai in 2015 after ten years as a data scientist in the marketing research and finance industries.  She has lead advanced analytical data projects with top tier companies in pharmaceuticals, telecommunications, banking, insurance, utilities, and retail, among many others. Her unsupervised learning methodology is used globally by research teams and Fortune 500 companies to help accurately track changes in longitudinal data with minimal data collection costs.

Briana serves on numerous boards of directors and committees. Most notably, she is Canada's national Head of Delegation for the ISO/IEC JTC 1/SC 42 Study Group on Computational Methods in Artificial Intelligence, a group which provides guidance to the development and publication of international standards for companies who are developing artificial intelligence applications.
title: That can't be right: Basics of machine learning validation for non-data scientists
abstract: When you're implementing machine learning in your technology, there's a lot that can go wrong, especially if you're relatively new to data science. In this talk I provide some best practices to diagnose errors in machine learning so you know that your design is working correctly.
description: One of the biggest challenges for those just getting started in machine learning and data science is the working with messy, incomplete, error-ridden data.  After over 10 years dealing with data as different as country-level economic indicators, customer experience comments in multiple languages, quantitative survey results, stock prices, store transactions, and many more, I've learned how to quickly diagnose errors in analytics output and machine learning models.  Unfortunately these are often difficult to detect, since they are errors in the data input rather than in the software that uses it. Let me help you find errors efficiently, and make sure you have the tools you need to diagnose data problems quickly and build your analytics with confidence.

title: Solving Sudoku from Scratch with Python
abstract: Sudoku solvers are a great intermediate programming challenge; not too hard, but not trivially easy. But the devil is in the details, and there are surprising challenges waiting for any programmer who says "I could do that". Along the way, we explore Pythonic OOP best practices.
description:
The Japanese puzzle game Sudoku began appearing in western newspapers in 2004 when they could be mass-produced with puzzle-generating software. Players fill in a 9 x 9 grid with numbers according to simple rules.

Whether you find Sudoku to be a fun cognitive challenge or, as computer security expert Ben Laurie put it, a frivolous "denial of service attack on human intellect", you'll be interested in the addition challenge of writer Python code to solve, not just one Sudoku puzzle, but any Sudoku puzzle. This is a beginner's level talk.

Along the way, we'll explore how to design custom data structures for specific problems, Pythonic object-oriented design, Python classes' "magic dunder" methods, and the process of devising programming solutions for abstract games.
notes: I'm the author of several programming educational materials in the form of books, online courses, and web videos. I've created a Sudoku solver in Python and wanted to share the lessons learned when creating this project.

title: My code is not for you: Protecting Python developer’s identity in open-source software projects (OSS)
abstract: OSS is open to anyone by design, whether it is developers or malicious users. Authors typically hide their identity through nicknames, however they have no protection against attribution techniques. This talk will present attacks on Python developers identity and discuss protection methods.
description:
The rapid increase in open source software is an attestation of a new standard in software development. Today over 80 percent of any software code is open source, according to a recent study by Sonatype. Python replaced Java as the second-most popular language on GitHub, with 40 percent more pull requests opened this year than last by GitHub Inc.'s annual report.
 
As the popularity of open source software increases, so do privacy concerns of individual contributors that often wish to remain anonymous. The majority of open-source repositories (GitHub, Google Code, SourceForge, etc.) allow users to keep their identity private while sharing their code. While in the past it was often sufficient, with the evolution of author attribution technology the question of how private the identity of software developers is becoming increasingly important.

Software author attribution aims to decide who wrote a computer program, given its source or binary code.  The main premise of this technique lies in the assumption that programmers unconsciously tend to use the same coding patterns. These patterns comprised of a number of distinctive features allow to characterise a programmer’s style and uniquely identify his/her works. Applications of software author attribution are wide and include software forensics - where the analyst wants to determine the author of a program given a set of potential programmers, plagiarism detection - where the analyst wants to identify illicit code reuse, ghostwriting detection - where given a suspicious piece of code the analysis wants to determine if it has been plagiarized from one of the programs in a given set, and in general any scenario where software ownership needs to be determined.

In this session we will show how analysts can identify the author of Python software and how this process can be deceiving. We present two attacks on current attribution systems: author imitation and author hiding. The first attack can be applied on Python developer's identity in open-source projects. The attack transforms syntactical representation of attacker’s source code to a version that mimics the victim’s coding style while retaining functionality of original code. This is particularly concerning for Python open-source contributors who are unaware of the fact that by contributing to open-source projects they reveal identifiable information that can be used to their disadvantage. For example, one can easily see that by imitating someone’s coding style it is possible to implicate any software developer in wrongdoing. To resist this attack we discuss multiple approaches of hiding a coding style of Python software author before contribute to open-source.

title: Replacing Gamers with Robots: Making Bots with PyAutoGUI
abstract: Video games are fun, but writing bots to play video games is meta-fun. Using PyAutoGUI to control the mouse and keyboard, this talk creates a bot to play the Flash game Sushi Go Round. Along the way, we explore bots, online cheating, captchas, and the issues that automation brings.
description:
In this talk, we look at PyAutoGUI, a GUI automation module that allows Python scripts to control the mouse and keyboard. This beginner/intermediate level talk goes into:

* What features PyAutoGUI provides.
* Creating data structures to represent the game state of Sushi Go Round.
* Analyzing screenshots to determine what is going on in the game world.
* Directing the mouse to execute moves on behalf of the player.

The pixel graphics of Sushi Go Round make an ideal environment for experimentation. Using this Flash game, we'll explore issues of automation, online cheating, and the capabilities and limits of autonomous agents.
notes: I'm the creator of PyAutoGUI, and the author of several books that teach coding to beginners. Many of the educational materials I create use games to teach programming concepts, and I've found a lot of success with this method.

name: Avneet Kaur
bio:
I am a recent graduate, and had been conferred with a degree of Bachelors in technology in Computer Science, in August 2018.

organization: Rails Girls Summer Of Code scholar 2018
title: Demystifying Network Science with NetworkX in Python
abstract: Have you ever wondered about the science of evolution of real world networks such as social networks or complex biological ones? Or how are we all socially only 6 connections or less away from each other? Lets unravel basic concepts of Network Science using NetworkX  in Python.
description:
With this talk I aim to showcase the use of NetworkX library in Python to unearth various concepts in network science. The study science of networks has become increasingly important owing to various reasons such as:  the spread of social media networks, studying target networks of medicine and drug discovery, and most importantly, our entire human body which is in itself a complex network. It is important to identify Hubs and Authorities in a such a network to identify potential causes of failure, more specifically, in the above examples - to point out, the target region/cell/ of a medicine or to identify whether a medicine could be used to treat multiple illnesses, to identify the origin of rumours in social media networks and also to pinpoint the node from which maximum other nodes can be reached to spread the rumour, and to study our body functions in general. 

The talk would be mainly divided into the following sections:
- Introduction to Network Science and Applications in daily Lives

- Networks and their characteristics: Nodes, Degree of a Node, Hubs, Authorities, Topological factors like Clustering Modularity, Betweenness Centrality, Characteristic Path Length, Degree Distribution, Types of Networks such as Small World, Scale Free, and Random networks.

- Introduction to NetworkX library of Python: Creating Simple networks of various types such as random, real world etc. Finding out the previously mentioned characteristics in (2) using various functions of Networks. 

- The Watts and Strogatz Model: Explaining the evolution of a small world network through code in python (using networkX), Simulations and visualisations.

- Error and Attack Tolerance of Various Networks:  Explaining the vulnerabilities of various networks through a thorough analysis, again using code in python (using networkX), simulations and various visualisations. Relating it to Disease networks (eg: which nodes should the medicine target to eradicate the disease) and other examples.

name: Erik Wright
bio: I am a lead Software developer for Shopify's data modeling platforms. Prior to joining Shopify I was a member of the Chrome team at Google. I've honed my unit testing chops over 19 years since an enlightened lead early in my career introduced me to the world of Extreme Programming.
title: Make Testing Agile Again!
abstract: Every line should have test coverage, but when projects get sophisticated tests can grow out of control, difficult to write, harder to understand, and damn near impossible to maintain. Learn tricks to achieve high coverage rates with simple, elegant tests that are easy to write, review, and evolve.
description:
The talk will present some of the pitfalls of unit testing, from bloated shared fixtures to monkey patching, characterisation testing, and brittle/broken coverage for error handling.

If you suffer from these problems, unit-testing becomes a grind, certain code seems un-testable, and covered code becomes painful to evolve. You may even find that your tests aren't even covering what you think they are.

With examples from Shopify's data platform, I will show strategies to mitigate these problems and write tests that are crystal clear, robust, and sustainable. Make testing agile again!

name: Ian Whitestone
bio:
As a student of Chemical Engineering at Queen's University, Ian was pursuing a career back home in Calgary in the Oil & Gas industry. During one summer, he was thrown into the world of data science when he started trying to make money by using Python to optimize daily fantasy sports lineups. After the oil price started crashing, he realized he should probably look for work in another industry.

In his spare time, Ian likes to participate in hackathons, work on side projects (usually involving a raspberry pi), or eat burrito boyz.
title: Gimme Shelter: Using Python to Find an Apartment in Toronto
abstract: With a continued shortage of rental units, finding the ideal apartment in Toronto, let alone one you can afford, is a daunting & time consuming task. But rest assured, Python plus a bit of webscraping can go a long way. This talk will highlight how I used Python and Slack to find a place to live.
description:
PyCon Canada 2018 Talk Proposal
=========================

**Title:** Gimme Shelter: Using Python to Find an Apartment in Toronto
**Duration:** 10 min
**Language:** English
**Level:** Beginner
**Categories:** `web scraping`, `slack`, `google maps api`

Abstract
=======

With a continued shortage of rental units, finding the ideal apartment in Toronto, let alone one you can afford, is a daunting & time consuming task. But rest assured, Python plus a bit of webscraping can go a long way. This talk will highlight how I used Python and Slack to find a place to live.

Description
===========

In this talk, I will dive into how I used Python to continually scan apartment listings on Craigslist and Kijiji, filter them based on my preferences, and send them to slack where my girlfriend and I could discuss and upvote different options. I will talk about some of the neat features I added on top of basic "price" and "number of bedroom" filters, like how far away apartments are from various different subway stations, and how long my commute time would be to work. I will finish off with what I learned and what I would have done differently.

A rough outline of my presentation would be as follows:

**Why searching for apartments sucks** (1 minute)

- highlight the main problems I was trying to solve
    - all the different sites that people post on
    - amount of time it takes to find things
    - how quickly apartments get snatched up
 
**Getting Data** (3 minutes)

- talk about how to get data from Kijiji & craigslist
- talk about some of the challenges of web scraping
    - not everyone website can be scraped using requests, talk about how you need tools like selenium for scraping sites with dynamically generated javascript content, and how you can switch to headless browsers when going to "production"

**Enriching the Data with Other Features** (2 minutes)

- discuss the new features i built
    - time to subway station
    - commute time to work
    - neighborhood rankings
    - price rankings
- discuss some of the challenges and limitations of these methods

**Using Slack as a Notifications System, and a free GUI** (2 minutes)

- quick overview of different options for interacting with slack: webhooks, bot users, and apps
- discuss how the slack app was built with flask

**Wrapping Up** (1 minute)
- lessons learned
- things I would have done differently

**Questions** (1 minute)
 End with time for the audience to ask questions.


See the github repo for more details: https://github.com/ian-whitestone/toronto-apartment-finder

About Me
===========

As a student of Chemical Engineering at Queen's University, Ian was pursuing a career back home in Calgary in the Oil & Gas industry. During one summer, he was thrown into the world of data science when he started trying to make money by using Python to optimize daily fantasy sports lineups. After the oil price started crashing, he realized he should probably look for work in another industry.

With a new found passion for data science, Ian started working for Capital One in Toronto as a data scientist. For the past two years, he has been working on operational monitoring across the business, credit risk analysis, data infrastructure & risk models. In his spare time, Ian likes to participate in hackathons, work on side projects (usually involving a raspberry pi), or eat burrito boyz.
notes: See the github repo for more details: https://github.com/ian-whitestone/toronto-apartment-finder

title: Contribute to Python!
abstract: Fixing bugs, translating the documentation, adding new features, changing the language, improving the processes: there are many ways to contribute to the maintenance and development of Python, for fun and profit!
description: This talk will walk you through the technical setup, development process and cultural practices that exist around the development of the Python language, the standard library, the official documentation and the CPython reference interpreter.  With the recent move to Github, existing guides become outdated; this will be an up-to-date presentation of the current tools, with the goal to inspire you to become a contributor to Python!
notes:
I was a core dev from 2010 to 2014 and recently joined again after the move to github.  I gave this talk at PyCon CA 2012 and would like to update its contents, both technical (git PRs, review requests, new bots) and social (diversity efforts, culture of contempt).

Talk in English, could be done in French.

I think I could also make a 10 minute version work.  Many setup details would be links rather than detailed screenshots, and I would insist on the facts that contributing is easier than people think + the community is welcoming.

name: Éric Araujo
bio:
CPython core developer

Montréal-Python organization team member

title: Python packaging for everyone
abstract: Packaging in Python used to be a complicated affair, for technical and human reasons.  Thankfully, in recent years the Python community has developed robust tools and practices.  If you are wondering how to develop and distribute your project, this talk will show you the best of 2018!
description: Ever had trouble with setup.cfg and MANIFEST.in?  Not sure how to define a dependency only needed to run tests?  Or newcomer to Python and a bit lost with distutils, setuptools and other packaging tools?  You are not alone!  For a long time, distributing Python libraries seemed a lot of more complicated that it should have been.  These days, we can choose between mature tools and promising new systems, with clearly shared specifications to encourage interoperability.  This talk will take you on a tour of the packaging tools of 2018.  We will see sample code using a few selected tools, so that you can walk out and know which to use for your project depending on its needs and existing setup.
notes:
I used to maintain distutils2 and distutils, and have followed packaging development closely since 2010.
I am also a user of these tools for my day job.  I gave a talk in 2012 and would love to give the 2018 version!

Talk outline:

- Intro
  - definition of packaging: build, package, distribute, install, deploy
  - kinds of Python projects (pure / extensions, lib / program / web app)
  - standard formats: wheels, requirements, versions

- Use flit to distribute simple projects to PyPI
  - for new projects, no extensions, lib or program
  - easy configuration
  - install with pip in stdlib!
  - send to TestPyPI then PyPI; pip again to test

- Adapt a setuptools-based project for the latest features
  - declarative metadata
  - markdown long description
  - extras for fun and profit

- Tame your requirements files with pip-tools, pipdeptree and safety
  - incremental improvements for existing web apps
  - pip-tools to solve the human-friendly vs frozen-repeatable conundrum
  - pipdeptree + safety for quiet minds

title: Identifying influencers via Slack Messages in Python using Network Analysis and NLP
abstract: Learn how to build a network web in Python to reflect conversations between people based on Slack conversations. Then, build a natural language processing model to evaluate what all those people are talking about, and which conversations determine who in the network carries "technical knowledge".
description: What can you do with your Slack data? Turns out, a lot! In this presentation, we will go over the basics of how to build a network map in Python, in this instance, using your conversations in Slack regarding who is talking to who. From there, we will dive deeper into the diagram by building a rule-based natural language processing model and a basic machine learning model to understand the context of the conversations that we've mapped. Which conversations are social and which are work-related?  Which conversations are people asking for advise or technical questions? Who are the main players in the map who answer people's questions quickly and effectively? Through this process, we are able to find 5 "influencers" out of 200,000 Slack messages.
notes: I researched this subject as part of a Master's of Science degree via University College London. I was selected to be a speaker at a major network science conference in Utrecht, Netherlands about the subject, and look forward to "funning-it-up" for audiences interested in the beginning stages of how to use Python to explore topics in data science.

title: Naming Your Duck: Static Typing in Python
abstract: Python is well-known as a programming language without static types, but recently there has been efforts to introduce static typing to Python. In this talk, we'll learn about type systems, see what this means for Python and it's programmers, and what the future has in store for Python's type system.
description:
# Description

Python is well-known as a programming language without static types. This means that you don't need to say what a given variable will hold, or whether your function will return a string or an integer (or sometimes one, and sometimes another!). This has historically made Python a very flexible and beginner-friendly language.

In this talk, we'll discuss the advantages and disadvantages to a static type system, as well as recent efforts to introduce static typing to Python via optional "type hints" and various tools to aid in adding types to Python code. We'll see what this means for Python, for Python programmers, and what the future has in store for Python's type system.

# Outline

* About types
  * Types of type systems
  * Advantages of static typing
  * Disadvantages of static typing
* Types in other languages
  * C
  * Ruby
  * JavaScript
  * Go
* Types in Python
  * How Python did/does typing
  * The `type` function
  * PEP 484: Type Hints
  * The `typing` module
  * Tools
    * mypy
    * pytype
* The great benefits to static typing in Python
  * Static code analysis
  * More documentation
  * Code completion
* The disadvantages to static typing
* The challenges of static typing
notes:
This talk is the result of of my experiences working with static typing in Python.

title: Data Protection for Developers: Past, Present, and Future
abstract: In 1970, the German state of Hesse enacted what is widely considered the very first data protection laws. Nearly fifty years later, the European Union has implemented the strongest, most comprehensive data protection regulation ever. This talk gives a crash course on data protection and the GDPR.
description:
# Description

In this talk, we'll examine what the European regulation means for us as developers, with specific examples of how the existing status quo for data collection, data aggregation and data processing will need to change. When can you collect user's data? What can you collect? What can you do with it?

We'll also explore the most important milestones in the history of data protection, both in policy (the evolution of laws to protect data) and in practice (the advent of technology to better protect data) to see how we got to where we are today.

And finally, we'll take a look at the future of data protection, including what to expect from the European regulation, and the current challenges we face in the US.

# Who and why

This talk is for developers who work with data, and want to be knowledgable and current about the latest policies and best practices for protecting their user's data. In addition, this talk is for users of technology themselves, to be able to determine what their rights are with regards to their own data.

The only background knowledge this talk requires is that which almost everyone has: some experience being a user of technology which collects data about them.

After watching this talk, developers should be able to determine if their software projects are affected by the new regulations, and should be informed about how their technology will need to change in order to become compliant with the new laws.

# Outline

* Introduction
  - Who am I?
  - What is data?
* History of Data Protection Policy & Practice
  - Germany
  - Sweden
  - United Kingdom
* Present Day
  - European Union
  - United States
* Imminent: EU General Data Protection Regulation
  - Scope
  - Core Rights
  - Examples
* Future
* Conclusion

title: Modern Python Coroutines
abstract: Coroutines are the most exciting, fastest-changing feature developed in Python 3. Catch up on the latest: how native coroutines work, how to cancel a coroutine or give it a time limit, and how context variables give coroutines the equivalent of thread-local storage.
description:
(5 minutes) Coroutine refresher. Show an asyncio coroutine example that uses "async" and "await". The example code launches a pair of coroutines to fetch two URLs concurrently. They print status messages as they make progress; you can see from the interleaved output that they run concurrently. Python coroutines behave much like Python threads, with several advantages: Python can launch many more coroutines at once than threads, coroutines are less prone to race condition bugs, and coroutines can be timed out or cancelled. Let's examine that third feature in detail.

(12 minutes) Cancellation. One coroutine can cancel another. Update the example code so the URL fetcher that finishes first cancels the other. You can't do this with threads!

When a coroutine is cancelled, a CancelledError is thrown from the root of the coroutine's call stack, down the call chain, and thrown at the "await" statement where the coroutine is currently paused. (Coroutines can prevent cancellation using the "shield" function, or with a try/except block. The audience should research these features if they're curious.)

The most common way to cancel a coroutine is a timeout. Update our example to use "asyncio.wait_for" with a timeout. The implementation of wait_for is quite legible; we'll look at the asyncio standard library code to see how it works.

(13 minutes) Context variables. In a thread-based framework like Flask, thread local storage is often used to hold the "context" of the task the thread is working on. Starting in Python 3.7, coroutines can use "context variables" to accomplish the same purpose. Update our example to store each URL fetcher's context in a context variable.

When a program launches concurrent coroutines, each inherits a copy of its parent's context. This is not how thread local storage works! Update the example to show how a child inherits its parent's context, but modifying the child's context does not affect the parent.

Modern coroutines in Python 3.7 have all the power of threads, especially now that they have context variables, and they have several features threads lack: they obey cancellation and timeouts, and they inherit context variables from their parents.

No Q & A during the time slot, but I'll invite audience members to come talk with me in the hallway afterward.
notes:
Hello! I've been involved with Python async code for many years. I'm the author of the async Queue classes included in asyncio and Tornado, and the co-author with Guido van Rossum of "A Web Crawler With asyncio Coroutines", a chapter in the "500 Lines or Less" book in the Architecture of Open Source Applications series. I maintain an async Python driver for MongoDB called Motor.

title: Recommendation Systems 101
abstract: Want to know how Spotify, Amazon, and Netflix generate recommendations for their users? In this talk, we will explore different types of recommendation systems and their implementations. We will walk through collaborative and content-based filtering, and learn about explicit and implicit feedback.
description:
The recommendation system is a classic application of machine learning that aims to predict which item a user will like best. Personalized recommendations play an integral role for e-commerce platforms, with the goal of driving user engagement through item recommendations.

In this talk, we will cover the following topics on recommendation systems with a focus on Python: 

- collaborative vs. content-based filtering
- implicit vs. explicit feedback
- handling the cold start problem
- recommendation model evaluation

By the end of this talk, you will have a better understanding of the different techniques and Python tools used to build recommendation systems in real-life scenarios.
notes:
I'm a member of PyLadies and have given talks on recommendation systems in the past. 

I'm currently building a tutorial for people to learn how to build their own recommendation systems from scratch. Tutorial material can be found here: https://github.com/topspinj/recommender-tutorial

title: Discovering topics in text with LDA
abstract: Topic modelling is a natural language processing (NLP) technique that aims to uncover hidden topics or "themes" in a collection of texts. This talk walks through the implementation of one of the most popular topic modelling techniques: Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA).
description:
Topic modelling is an exciting machine learning technique that is used to extract key themes from a collection of texts. The beauty of topic modelling is that it can reveal meaningful topics using basic probability theory. 

Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA) was first introduced in 2003 and has become one of the most popular techniques for topic modelling. This talk will focus on the main Python tools that facilitate LDA (e.g., scikit-learn, gensim, nltk, spacy). IMDB's movie review dataset will be used to demo the results of LDA.

Note: This is a talk for people who are new to NLP and topic modelling but are already proficient in Python.
notes: I have written a similar article that walks through topic modelling with song lyrics. Link here: https://topspinj.github.io/topic-modeling-song-lyrics/

title: Python for SEO: Web Scraping
abstract: Search engine optimization (SEO) requires a variety of technical considerations, such as page titles, redirects and structured data. With Python we can build a scalable pipeline to extract and audit this data from web pages. We’ll show how this (and more) can be done using a Jupyter Notebook!
description:
Web scraping technologies allow us (at Ayima) to extract on-page data from our client’s sites at scale. Over the last couple years, we’ve built a collection of tools that are regularly used to audit large sets of pages. Oftentimes we are interested in well-known SEO data like page titles and meta descriptions, however there’s a ton of other important data we look at as well. This includes meta robots tags, canonical URLs, redirects, structured data and (surprisingly) facets!

In this workshop, I want to show off the open-source tools we leverage from Python’s ecosystem, and present them in a guided format. We’ll first look at the basics of web requests with the requests library and show simple HTML parsing with BeautifulSoup4. Then we’ll get into some more advanced details of each, including request sessions, passing cookies, custom user agents and more detailed HTML parsing techniques. Finally we’ll conclude by showing how selenium can be used to render JavaScript when making requests.

This will be done in the context of a Jupyter Notebook, and along the way I’ll be sure to include tips & tricks, and highlight why they are such amazing tools for web-scraping!
notes:
I’ve presented similar material in my Packt course, which can be seen here: https://github.com/agalea91/Beginning-Data-Science-with-Jupyter/blob/master/lesson-3/lesson-3-workbook.ipynb

For this workshop I will build a brand new notebook to walk though live with the group, and host on github. This notebook will include all the material outlined in the description.

Requirements are:
- requests, beautifulsoup4 and pandas (recommended to install anaconda distribution of python for these)
- selenium library + web driver (just for the last 5-10 mins of workshop)

I’m much more inclined towards running a tutorial, but I can present similar material in a 30min talk instead if need be.

title: Options for doing web scrapping in python through selenium and beautiful soup
abstract: Many of us are faced with the daunting task of obtaining data from websites. This data might be already available through a url but sometimes that data needs some sort of interaction on a site to be available.  What can we do? Here we see how it can be done through beautifulsoup and selenium.
description: Options like beautifulsoup will help us pull information(web scraping) that is readily available in static HTML, we strip this information and we can use it for our advantage in pandas for example to see statistics on our favourite star wars characters or our soccer team. This will save us time by not having to type information already available out there. But what happens if interaction with a website is needed? What happens if we need to click a couple of options on a website for us to see the data? Selenium comes to the rescue.
notes:
I currently work with a number of rpa and rda solutions at work, selenium is a powerful library that helps us do automation. We will be using it in the context to obtain data but it can be used as well for software testing and interacting with the UI part of an application. This will be a code along tutorial using jupyter notebooks to give people the starting push into working with both these tools.

name: Vijay Shankar Venkataraman
bio: I am a physicist turned python-loving data scientist who loves to understand how things work.  Generative modelling is my current fascination.
title: Create game characters with Generative Adversarial Networks
abstract:
Generative adversarial networks (GANs) are neural network models that let us create synthetic data that looks like it comes from a given distribution.  

We will explore the GAN framework, some of their famous applications, and use PyTorch to generate synthetic street-fighter characters.
description:
Generative models are models that learn the underlying structure of a dataset (e.g. Pokemon images) and can then produce new samples (new Pokemons) from the same distribution. These are distinct from discriminative models which are trained to distinguish between different classes.

In this tutorial, we will use pytorch to learn about generative adversarial networks (GANs), a recently developed class of generative models. In the GAN framework, two neural networks - the generator and the discriminator - are in an adversarial teaching (think Ph.D student/advisor) relationship which helps the generator learn the underlying structure of the data. In simple terms, the generator's goal is to come up with data that the discriminator cannot distinguish from data it is trained on. 

PyTorch is one of the leading deep learning frameworks and is probably the most pythonic way to build deep-learning models today. In this tutorial, we will use PyTorch to explore some common architectures to generate synthetic images for a street-fighter like game. 

I hope to leave the audience with two things - gain an appreciation for how deep learning can be used for generative models, and how PyTorch can let you use GANs to generate data for various projects. 


## Tentative Schedule (for a 60 minute tutorial)
### Introduction to GANs (15 minutes)
Start with a brief introduction to neural networks and then go on to describe the minimax game framework of GANs proposed by Goodfellow et al. 

### Brief overview of PyTorch (10 minutes + 10 minute hands-on)
Briefly introduce the torch framework for building models and use hands-on time to build a simple discriminatory network/GAN. Depending on audience comfort with neural networks, this can be the famous MNIST digit classifier (a discriminatory network) or a GAN to generate digits. In either case, skeleton code would be provided. 

### Hands-on part building street fighter images. (15 minutes hands-on)
Use provided skeleton code to generate synthetic street fighter images from existing characters. If training time is an issue, pre-trained models will be provided. 

### Discuss/Demo further applications of GANs (5 minutes + 5 minutes for Q&A)
GANs have been successful with other kinds of data (text to images, image captioning etc). Demo/discuss some of these applications and leave some time for questions.
notes:
This tutorial will be a bit difficult to get into for people without some background in neural networks. I will provide a brief background, but 60 minutes is too short to delve into this vast field. My goal is to provide a flavour for what generative models (specifically GANs) can accomplish and how easy it is to build these models using established architectures (though, training them can be a different story). 

Technically, this talk will not require too much apart from pytorch (and associated dependencies) installed on the user's systems. For training, there are a couple of ways for attendees to get free access to GPUs (Google Colab, Kaggle Kernels). Training the models maybe left out if time proves to be a constraint. 

My background is in physics, but I have been fascinated by neural network models for a few years now. I am a founding member of a group in Toronto that tries to implement deep learning papers over the weekend. We have been delving deep into GANs which is where my excitement for them began. It is this excitement that I hope to share with the broader PyCon Canada community.

name: Niall Byrne
bio:
My name is Niall Byrne, and I am Python Developer, Systems Administrator, and Cloud Generalist based in Toronto.
I have a bad habit of biting off more than I can chew, and getting myself in trouble.
title: Concurrent Madness
abstract: This is a David versus Goliath tale of a business problem I was handed that was outside my existing skillset.  The road to a working solution wasn't pretty or fun and it wasn't graced by the slightest bit of good luck.  I'd like to share some of the lessons I learned through this experience.
description:
This talk is in some ways is about my quest to become a better programmer, after falling into a bit of a comfort zone.

The challenge I was asked to solve could not be effectively met by my existing skillset, so I was forced to adapt. 
What I found was that it helped me identify areas of my skill set that needed improvement, or lacked a grounding in formal education.  
Filling in these gaps, allowed me to complete the project and become a better developer.

At first I thought the message might be, "Don't make the same mistakes I did", but after reflection, we should all make these mistakes to remind ourselves how important it is to keep learning, and keep challenging our existing assumptions.
notes:
My name is Niall Byrne, and I freelance in Toronto doing Python Development, and System Administration.

I had been programming for several years before the project I am referring to in this talk, and thought of myself as quite capable.  But I didn't know what I didn't know.
My intention is to share with my peers how important it is to not get complacent or grow too comfortable with your skill set.  And if you ego can handle the bruising, to try something more difficult than you can solve.

title: Dive into PyTorch
abstract: PyTorch is a deep learning framework for fast, flexible experimentation. Its first-class Python integration and imperative style make it extremely easy to learn and use PyTorch. It can be used seamlessly with other Python packages like numpy/scipy/scikit-learn etc thus making its adoption easier.
description:
PyTorch is a deep learning framework for fast, flexible experimentation.  PyTorch is not a Python binding into some C++ framework. It is designed to have a first-class integration with Python. The framework is intuitive, linear in thought and easy to use. Unlike some other deep learning frameworks, PyTorch allows you to arbitrarily change the structure of your neural network on the fly with very small overhead. All these aspects make it an attractive choice for trying out new ideas in deep learning.

Content:

* Few slides about "what is PyTorch"
* Few slides about "what is Tensor" and "operations supported" over tensor.
    * These slides would not go into the internals and are presented to keep the presentation self-contained.
* Minimal introduction to backpropagation
    * Note that I am assuming that the audience is familiar with basic machine learning and backpropagation.
* Few slides on torch neural network library
* Building our first neural network
    * Define the network
    * Specifiy the loss function
    * Do backprop (only from the perspective of the API)
    * Update the weights
* Given this neural network, we will preapre a data pipeline
   * Loading data
   * Preprocessing data
   * Training the model
   * Interpreting the results
*How to train the same model on a GPU with minimal changes
* How to use other numerical computation libraries with PyTorch
* Conclusion

I would be using a pdf for the presentation (when discussing things like "what is PyTorch"). For the hands-on part, I would use self-contained [colab notebooks](https://colab.research.google.com/). Assuming internet connectivity, the participants do not need to install anything on their machines.
notes:
I am a researcher and MSc student at [Montreal Institute of Learning Algorithms](https://mila.quebec/en/) and use both PyTorch and Numpy extensively for all my machine learning based research. I have made small contributions to PyTorch though I am not affiliated with either project. This fall I am working as a teaching assistant for the *Data Mining Techniques* course at [HEC Montreal](http://www.hec.ca/en/). Previously I have worked as a teaching assistant for the 3-course series titled Data Science and Engineering with Spark XSeries, created in partnership with professors from University of California, Berkeley, University of California, Los Angeles and Databricks and offered on the [edX platform](https://www.edx.org/xseries/data-science-engineering-apacher-sparktm).

I have good experience of public speaking and have previously given talks at PyCon India 2016](https://in.pycon.org/cfp/2016/proposals/big-data-analysis-using-pyspark~b8Mld/), [Big Data Training Program, IIT Roorkee](https://github.com/shagunsodhani/talks/tree/master/spark/BDI) and [other meetups and reading groups](https://shagunsodhani.in/talks/).

All the demo code, that I intend to use, would run on [colab](https://colab.research.google.com/) so as long as there is internet available, the participants do not need to install anything locally.

name: Faith H. Wallace, Ph.D.
bio: I am a Web Developer, Professor, Writer, Hogwarts Student, and Doctor Who Companion... Okay, so maybe I am not a student at Hogwarts… I am sure I'd be sorted into Ravenclaw! And, maybe I am not a Doctor Who companion… But wouldn’t time traveling in the TARDIS be amazing? My career started, not in magic, but in education. I taught middle school English before I went back to school full-time to earn a Ph.D. in Language and Literacy from Georgia State University, and worked as a Professor of Literacy at Kennesaw State University (GA). After years of teaching, I decided to leverage my background in language and literacy for a new career as a Front End Developer with an affinity for clean, classic web design with original and well-commented code. However, I have never truly left education, and I have applied what I know about education from years of study and practice to how people learn to code. I help coding instructors learn to differentiate their instruction to meet the needs of diverse learners. Further, I help coders understand WHY learning to code is complex, and how to chose the best resources to meet their needs.
title: Python, Harry Potter & Bloom's Taxonomy
abstract: Are you teaching or learning Python? In order to make the most of the experience, we must move the learning through a hierarchy of objectives (Bloom’s Taxonomy). See how the Harry Potter series illustrates this learning hierarchy in the magical world, then apply that to teaching & learning Python.
description: Have you thought about teaching Python? Are you trying to learn Python? To be successful, it is critical that the learning experiences move you through a hierarchy of learning objectives (known in education as Bloom’s Taxonomy). This ensures that you can progress from simply recalling coding concepts to being able to develop your own original code. The hierarchy has six levels: Remember, Understand, Apply, Analyze, Evaluate, and Create. But what does Harry Potter have to do with the learning objectives and coding? Simple. Throughout the seven books & eight movies in the Harry Potter series, there are numerous examples demonstrating each of the learning objectives in the hierarchy. Remember, Harry is experiencing a steep learning curve. Harry must learn potions, charms, and transfiguration, all with tools he has never used before. Doesn’t that sound familiar? Instead of magic, you are learning the language of Python as well as learning to think like a programmer. Instead of a cauldron and wand, you are using a text editor and a debugger, maybe Python Tutor. In this presentation, I address the six levels in the hierarchy, describe the types of learning outcomes in each level using action verbs, provide a clear example from the Harry Potter series with video clips, and then relate it back to teaching and learning Python.
notes:
Technical Requirements: I will be showing a presentation including links to video clips from the Harry Potter movies to serve as examples. Showing examples from of the learning objectives with clips from the movies allows participants to comfortably grasp the concepts before applying it to coding. Further, this makes the concepts more accessible.

Why am I qualified to deliver this presentation? I am a former Professor of Literacy Education with years of experience teaching teachers HOW to teach, and students HOW to learn. I’ve published and presented various research-based projects throughout my time as a Professor. After years of teaching, I decided to leverage my background in education and literacy for a new career as a developer. However, I have never truly left education, and I have applied what I know about education to how people learn to code. I write a blog with the focus: A Professor’s Perspective on Learning to Code. I help new coders understand their unique learning process and their individual learning styles. I help coding instructors learn to differentiate their instruction to meet the needs of diverse learners. Further, I help coders understand WHY learning to code is complex, and how to chose the best resources to meet their needs.

I will be applying for financial assistance.

title: Egad! How Do We Start Writing (Better) Tests?
abstract: Some have never automated tests and can’t check themselves before they wreck themselves. Others have 1000s of tests that are flaky, duplicative, and slow. Wa-do-we-do? GOOD testing is hard but not impossible. Start with proven advice from this talk!
description:
Some have never automated tests and can’t check themselves before they wreck themselves. Others have 1000s of tests that are flaky, duplicative, and slow. Wa-do-we-do? GOOD testing is hard but not impossible. To show how to get it done, we will follow the story of “Amanda the Panda” (representing the everyday Pythoneer) as she jumps into testing and automation with Python.

Her journey includes:

1. How do I play “buzzword bingo” for testing?
2. Why do I need feature tests and not just unit tests?
3. What skills do I need?
4. What framework should I use?
5. How do I avoid duplicating test code?
6. How do I handle test data?
7. There are too many tests! Which ones should I automate?
8. How do I run tests in continuous integration?
9. How do I make tests reliable so they stop failing again and again?
10. How do I hire Software Engineers in Test?

All examples will be given in Python (of course).
notes:
I am a software engineer with expertise in testing and automation. My specialty is building test automation systems from the ground up, which involves both software development for test code as well as infrastructure setup to run it in continuous integration. I write extensively on these topics at https://automationpanda.com/. From talking with many people (of all software background and from companies big and small), I discovered that test automation is really an under-served skill set. With this talk, I hope to provide a blueprint for how people can get started and be successful.

I have spoken at a few conferences before: PyData Carolinas 2016 ("Testing is Fun in Python!"), PyCon 2018 ("Behavior-Driven Python"), and PyOhio 2018 ("EGAD! How do we start writing better tests?"). I really hope to have the opportunity to speak at PyCon Canada!

title: Code. Fight. Repeat
abstract: In 2017 I started training Brazilian Jiu Jitsu and it changed the way I work, the way I feel and the way I approach hard problems in programming. I want to share some things that I've learnt along the way and how I think a martial art like Jiu Jitsu can help a lot of developers.
description:
In the pursuit of better physical health and something that wasn't sitting in front of my computer and just coding, I decided to take up Jiu Jitsu and 12 months in, I couldn't have found something that has helped me more in both areas. Im going to talk about the foundations of a skill and why they are important. How diet is just as important as anything, experimenting with sleep is fun and how you should really 'round-off' your main skill with additional skills...but not all RIGHT NOW.

No one will be put into a arm-bar during this presentation.
notes:
This talk is about how not only can Bjj help you work out, but how there are a few correlations between what we do in our day jobs and the training. This isn't a preachy "Bjj is the answer talk" and has zero code throughout. Its a story about taking things learnt during training and actively applying them to our work and work-life.

Its not targeted at a specific set of programmers of a single language or framework, but can be applied to programmers from all different walks of life.

title: 3.6 <= Dataclasses >= 3.7
abstract:
How I handled the data classes requirement in Python 3.6 and earlier and how data classes will come in handy after Python 3.7? We will see the exact requirements I have, how I solved them in 3.6 and how to solve them in 3.7.

This talk will also give an intro to data classes so the context is set.
description:
Data storage classes and checks and balances around them are an essential aspect of a non-Dataframe related application.  Possible type checks, light-weightedness, minimal memory footprint, quick serialization and reference data enrichment have been some of the most important aspects of these pure data bearing classes.

This talks will all about the above and will try to cover the following aspects

1.  The challenges associated with using pure data bearers (I call it so to avoid confusion with real data classes)
2. How did we tackle these in v3.6?
3. Introduction to named tuples and data classes (v3.7)
4. Data classes (v3.7) demystified 
5. How to tackle  the data bearer class challenges with the new age data classes

The talk requires basic knowledge of Python.
notes:
I have been working on Python based production applications for a reasonably long time and hence have a good experience of things that hog up in the Production environment. It will be a good opportunity to share my experiences with the community.

title: Continuous Deployment to Kubernetes using Helm Stack - a DevOps tale
abstract: This talk is about how we at Go-Jek deploy hundreds of our microservices to Kubernetes using helm, chartmuseum for managing helm charts, the vault for storing secrets, `Yggdrasil` which is our in-house application configuration management system and gitlab runners.
description:
Deploying applications in the production environment with absolute confidence that nothing will break and the tedious deployment process will be a piece of cake may seem like boiling the ocean. At Go-Jek (a technology startup that specializes in ride-hailing, logistics and digital payments in Indonesia), we have hundreds of microservices to be continuously deployed. We faced the daunting task of deploying hundreds of our microservices to virtual machines in the production environment in different clusters and horizontally scaling infrastructure in times of need and burnt lots of midnight oil. But this procedure didn't seem sustainable or scalable for the scale at which Go-Jek is operating. The best obvious choice seemed to be Kubernetes and hence we chose Kubernetes to deploy our applications.
 
This talk is about how we are able to deploy applications to Kubernetes using helm, chartmuseum for managing helm charts, the vault for storing secrets, `Yggdrasil` which is our in-house application configuration management system and gitlab runners. This talk is also about how we automated this solution using gitlab CI so that our effort could be replicated.

title: Tame your requirements files
abstract: Pip requirements files are a nice way to control dependencies to develop, test, build and deploy a program or web application, but it's not always easy to edit and update them.  We will review a few tools to make daily workflow simple and robust!
notes:
I gave this talk at a Montréal-Python meetup to explain how pip-tools helps managing requirements files, without switching to a whole new tool like pipfile.

The common practice in tutorials and guides about requirements is to add dependencies with pip install, then update requirement files with pip freeze.

Issues:

- dev/test tools vs real runtime requirements
- platform differences
- dependency information lost!
- not human-editable

Solution: pip-tools!

- human-editable source file
- frozen, repeatable "compiled" file
- dependency conflict solver!
- tool to install and remove dependencies
- bonus: pipdeptree for conversion
- (great for tox testenvs too!  -- check that there is time to explain that)

Notes about me: I know packaging tools quite well, have encountered the problems I mention here and solved them.

title: Automating the U of T ITS Private Cloud with Flask, Celery, React and Docker
abstract: Virtual Machine provisioning turnaround from days to minutes, from minutes to seconds. This is how we evolved for the last two years with the creation of the first automation ecosystem at the UofT ITS Private Cloud, including a RESTful API, SDK, CLI  written in Python and a React based UI.
description:
The growth in demand of virtual server instances at the University of Toronto ITS Private Cloud and the limited number of staff in the Hardware Infrastructure Group drove innovation to create the first ITS Private Cloud RESTful API with Asynchronous task and distributed processing which added our team's business logic to a VMware vSphere environment for self provisioning. 

In the talk we will explore how we reduced turnaround times from days to minutes and from minutes to seconds by creating an ecosystem based mainly in Python OSS libraries including Flask, PyVMomi, Celery, Paramiko, Psycopg, etc and the benefits of running on a clustered environment of Docker Swarm Community Edition with Portworx as the cluster storage driver.  Also, we will talk about how we overcome the REST API adoption barrier by creating a cross-platform SDK and Command Line Interface with Click. Finally, why we decided to create the ITS Private Cloud Portal (UI) written in React, the challenges and the value added to the backing API.

We intend to demonstrate how the ecosystem can be deployed in minutes for new VMware vSphere installations, scaled up/down and provision a few virtual instances by either the API, SDK, CLI and UI.
notes:
I designed, developed, documented and deployed the RESTful API, SDK and CLI from ground up, including the current production and testing environment thinking from the beginning in a containerized setup for resiliency, availability and scalability. I've given workshops, tutorials and written several how-to's for end users internally at UofT to familiarize with the different components:
- https://eis.utoronto.ca/%7Evss/vsscli/ 
- https://eis.utoronto.ca/%7Evss/pyvss/
- https://vss-wiki.eis.utoronto.ca/display/API

The author of the UI aka ITS Cloud Portal, Orlando Ramirez Martinez, will be joining me in the presentation (if approved). 

Thanks.

title: Intake - taking the pain out of data access
abstract: Intake is a simple library providing one interface for cataloging, finding, describing and reading any data locally, in the cloud, or on an Intake server. Intake separates the definition of data sources from their analysis, so that Data Engineers and Data Scientists can get on with their jobs.
description:
Defining and loading data-sets costs time and effort. The data scientist needs to know what data are available, and the characteristics of each data-set, before going to the effort of loading and beginning to analyze a specific data-set. Furthermore, they might need to learn the API of some Python package specific to the target format. The code to do such data loading often makes up the first block of every notebook or script, propagated by copy&paste.

Intake has been designed as a simple layer over other Python libraries to provide:

- a consistent API, so that you can investigate and load all of your data with the same commands, without knowing the details of the backend library
- a simple cataloging system using YAML syntax, enabling, for every data-set:
  - a description of which plugin is to load it
  - arguments to pass
  - arbitrary metadata to associate with the data
  - transparent access to remote catalogs and data, for most formats
- a minimalist plugin system, so that new loaders, remote containers, and many other components can be contributed to Intake with a minimum of fuss.

For a simple design and relatively small code-base, there are lots of features. We will demonstrate the main ones and show typical work-flows from two points of view:

- the end user (e.g., Data Scientist), who will be provided with an easy-to-use method for browsing data catalogs, getting basic descriptions of each entry. For each data-set, detailed metadata and data structure descriptions and quick-look plotting are available as one-liners, allowing for quick decisions on which data are appropriate for a given problem, and then Intake gets out of the way. The user need never know the details of the storage format of the data.

- the catalog designer (e.g., Data Engineer), who wants to get on with deciding where data should be stored, in which format, and which package is best suited to load each data-set, so long as the data scientist, above, gets the data-frame (or other artefact) they need. Catalogs also provide a natural place to describe each data-set, with text and arbitrary metadata. Finally, catalogs can also encode user parameters, giving either natural choices to the end user (e.g., to filter a data set, or choose between version A and B), or for getting information required for data access from the user’s environment.

Thus, Intake provides a very simple yet useful division between the users of data, and the maintainers of data source catalogs. Intake has approachable code and is extensible in many places, and so hopefully can progress to become an all-inclusive data ecosystem for numerical Python.
notes: I am the lead developer on Intake, which is newly-released, free and open source.

title: If I Can Be A Speaker Then So Can You
abstract: I strongly believe that everyone in our community has interesting insights and knowledge to share. But not everyone thinks they can speak at a conference. I strongly believe that's incorrect and am going to debunk some of most important misconceptions.
description:
The Django community is full of excellent and bright individuals that make
our community such an amazing place to be part of. Our meetups and conferences
are filled with great content and a welcoming and supportive atmosphere. But
there are still many voices that haven't been heard who haven't shared their
experiences and knowledge.

I strongly believe that everyone in our community has interesting insights and
compelling stories to share. Unfortunately, not everyone thinks they can be a
speaker. If this is you, you should give me an opportunity to illustrate why
you might be incorrect and how you can start building the confidence towards
being a speaker at a conference such as this one. And hopefully I'll be able 
to inspire you to go home and start the work on your very first proposal.
notes:
# About Me

I've been a participant at several Django and Python conferences over the last
few years. I spoke at several conferences in 2016, one of them being PyCon US. I also spoke at PyCon AU and PyCaribbean. 

Recording of these and other previous conferences are available on pyvideo.org: http://pyvideo.org/speaker/sebastian-vetter.html

I work as Python developer for Eventbase, a Vancouver, BC-based company, and am a co-organizer of the local Python and Django meetups.

Over the last few years, I've become more and more interested in being a speaker and experienced the challenges of it every time. The Python community being as supportive as it is, I think it's a great environment for first time speakers. I was lucky enough to meet some incredible, seasoned speakers at PyCons that helped me build my own confidence and would love to share those experiences and give back.

# Talk Outline

* Disclaimer (~1min)

    * How I feel right now
    * I have less experience than many,
    * but enough to share 

* Reasons for giving this talk (~2mins)

    * I have some experience as a speaker
    * Our community is built on sharing experiences
    * Encourage each and everyone to share!!

* The Challenges (~2mins)

    * Not having a topic to speak about.
    * Being afraid to speak in front of a (big) crowd
    * Imposter syndrome & fear of Q&A

* Not Having a topic to speak about (~ 3mins)

    * A good starting point
        * What are you working on?
        * Do you have a pet project?
        * Did you learn from a mistake?

    * Consider
        * giving a beginners talk,
        * an overview/intro to a tool or library
        * explain an unusual or unique approach

* Being afraid of speaking (~3mins)

    * Everybody worries, even after 50+ talks.
        * Stories of seasoned speakers

    * It's good to have it
        * It improves/increases your focus
        * You tap into some extra energy reserves

* Imposter Syndrom & Fear of Q&A (~3mins)
    * It's one source of the fear we talked about
    * I still have it, every time.
    * BUT PyCons are a great and supportive environment

* Steps to being a speaker

* Create a proposal (~3mins)
    * Start with an outline
    * Don't create slides, yet
    * Build structure and a story

* Practise, Practise, Practise (~3mins)
    * Give the talk to youself:
        1. run through it,
        2. make notes,
        3. revise,
        4. rinse & repeat.
    * Present at your company
    * Speak at a meetup
    * Ask for feedback 
* Additional Advice (~3mins)
    * Don't be afraid to ask for help
        * Conferences have speaker mentoring
        * Ask the community or coworkers
    * Learn from feedback on proposals
    * Watch yourself speak and refine your presentations style
    * Present a talk at multiple conferences
    * Ask for feedback after your talk
* Feedback, Please (~1mins)
