title: PyCAIR: Content Aware Image Resizing using Python
abstract: I would like to talk about a image manipulation technique. The primary factor in this technique is the content. The image is cropped, enlarged or modified keeping in mind the primary factor.  I will talk about an algorithm called as Seam Carving and the power of Python libraries to obtain results.
description:
In this talk, I will speak about a simple yet very powerful image manipulation mechanism.


----------

The naive user utilizes the services of any standard toolkit, be it a web service or a remote application for image manipulation. The black box approach to this process is: A user provides an image and other parameters as input to the toolkit which in turn produces the results and returns it back to the user. Often these results are not up to the mark. The image sometimes gets distorted, misaligned or blurred.

Deviating from the standard mechanisms, I would like to talk about a technique called as **Content aware image resizing**. The primary factor in this technique is **the content**. It is the content which drives the entire technique. The image is cropped, enlarged or modified keeping in mind the primary factor. 

I will talk about an algorithm called as **Seam Carving** which is used under the hood to achieve the aforementioned technique. **It is this algorithm and the power of Python libraries**, that makes this technique perform better than the standard mechanisms.


----------


**Agenda of Talk:**

 1. Introduction: Basics of seam carving, how the algorithm works
 2. Understanding energy concepts, basics of computer vision and dynamic programming
 3. Walk over the pseudo-code and dry run of algorithm
 4. Comparative analysis of this technique with standard mechanisms
 5. Q&A Session
 6. Conclusion

title: Django app monitoring with prometheus and grafana
abstract: As soon as we deploy any non-trivial web application, or any software application for that matter, we soon (or should) become interested in how this application is performing in the wild. we want to know how many requests we are receiving, how much time is spent serving a request on average etc.
description:
The choice of monitoring systems out there is overwhelming. When we recently decided to set up a monitoring system for our handful of servers, it became clear that many of the go-to solutions like Nagios, Sensu, New Relic would be either too heavy or too expensive – or both.
What we really needed was something lean we could spin up in a docker container and then ‘grow’ by extending the configuration or adding components as and when our needs change.
With those requirements in hand we soon came across Prometheus, a monitoring system and time series database, with its de-facto graphical front-end Grafana. We set it up for a trial run and it fit our needs perfectly. And I want to share my experience with this technology.
notes:
The sample Python application I intend to demonstrate my talk is tested with Python 3 and may not work with Python 2. In addition, we will be using docker (v18.06.0-ce) and docker-compose (v1.19.0) to run the web application. 
All the source code we will need to follow along with is in a git repository.

The category of Python web application that we will be discussing in this post is a WSGI application deployed via uwsgi or gunicorn and running multiple worker processes (specifically, five); in other words, synchronous web applications where multiple requests can be processed by potentially different processes. A web application written using the Django web framework or the microframework Flask are examples of applications of this category.

title: Idols > Rock Stars for Business Growth & Continuity
abstract: "Developer shortages" comes from trying to hire experienced “rock stars” for undefined roles. Japanese & Korean entertainment companies use defined roles to find & train new idols. One company trained ~500 in a decade. I'll look at how to adapt their methods to find & train new developers.
description:
When trying to grow a dev team, companies look for a "senior full-stack developer". This is because they don't know quite what they want, so they look for someone able to fill all their undetermined needs. This can often lead to not being able to find a "good candidate" (Celine Dion already HAS a job) or worse: expensive, bad fits (I'm Beyonce! I don't WRITE unit tests!). But companies base their business continuity on this risky approach, as experienced developers are sought after and highly mobile.

Through this lens, I'll look at the methods used by Japanese and Korean entertainment companies to develop professional performers, known as "idols". We'll see how these methods are used to find individual idols and build idol teams with the characteristics they need to succeed.  Key parts of these methods are identifying needed roles, a process to identify new members to fill those roles, and training to develop specialized skills needed. This ensures the team has the skills it needs and the company always has the performers it needs. I'll look at how those methods can be adapted to find and train new developers.
notes:
I'm the best person to speak on this subject for a few reasons:
1. Over the course of my careers, I've seen talented individuals NOT work well as teams. The whole can be LESS than the sum of it's parts.
2. As a newer software engineer who's working for a startup and knows lots of people at other startups, I've seen lots of "ninja/rockstar" job postings, failed attempts to recruit experienced developers, and a lack of training for junior developers.
3. There might be 100 people on Earth who've studied the idol industry the way I have AND can draw parallels to software development teams.

Learn how this can increase your velocity, your trust in process, and allow you sleep soundly with each deployment.
description: In this talk, I go over the development workflow on our python teams at Shopify. I start by talking about how we form PRs, how code review is performed, what CI does, and how we perform deployment. I touch upon how we can structure these workflows increase developer velocity and keep momentum without turning CI and CD into a time sink for developers.

name: Ivan Torroledo
bio: Ivan Torroledo is a data scientist in the Cyxtera Research organization. In this role, he develops and implements machine and deep learning algorithms to enhance phishing detection, network security, fraud detection, and malware mitigation. Ivan is also highly interested in research on the application of machine and deep learning in high energy physics and astrophysics. Before joining Cyxtera, he worked at the Central Bank of Colombia, applying high performance computing tools to monetary policy analysis. He is passionate about applying the most advanced scientific knowledge to cyber security industry. Ivan holds degrees in Economics and Physics.
title: Building next generation writers using AI
abstract: Could a machine write an original book? it’s known among AI community that ML algorithms helps to automate many tasks, nevertheless, machines will never match human creativity. In this talk we’ll discuss how to create a text generator algorithm capable to replicate the creative writing process
description:
This talk is based on the research paper DeepPhish: Simulating AI (https://bit.ly/2LH3jYQ), where it was designed an AI text generator capable to create URLs to bypass an AI phishing detection system. Using this theory, we are going to present an alternative application of natural language processing. Specifically, we will show how to build an AI text generator capable to learn the writing style of most famous writers and even capable to create its own style. The talk is design to cover from most basic natural language processing concepts, main techniques for text preprocessing to finally apply the these concepts to design our first AI powered writer.


Outline

Introduction
NLP fundamentals
Data preprocessing
Building an AI text generator
Examples
notes: There are not technical requirements for the talk. It is just required beginner python experience and passion for Artificial Intelligence! Ivan has several years applying machine learning, statistical models and computational modelling in areas like finance, economics, physics (astrophysics, high energy physics) and cybersecurity. His latest research experience its centered around natural language processing applications for cybersecurity. Some of their recent talks have been at Anti Phishing Working group symposium (https://www.antiphishing.org/), DEFCON (https://www.defcon.org/) and Bogota Data Science meetup (https://www.meetup.com/es/Machine-Learning-Data-Science-Bogota/events/past/)

name: Adam Burbidge
bio:
Adam is currently a Master's student in software engineering at Stevens Institute of Technology and works as a software developer in aerospace.
His interests include many aspects of software development such as security and configuration management.
This material in this presentation is based on the final paper for a class on designing secure systems.
title: Quantum Computer Security
abstract:
This talk covers some of the basics of cryptography, ways your information might be compromised, and how quantum computers could change the game.
Intended for beginners or those who want an overview of some recent developments.
description:
The amount of everyone's personal and private data available on the internet is increasing, and consequently cybersecurity is rapidly becoming an area that everyone needs to be concerned about.
This talk will discuss methods for exchanging secret messages starting from some of the earliest known encryption methods, with a brief overview of the mechanics of public key encryption.
It will also discuss ways that quantum computers could change the game by invalidating some existing security methods, but also possibly opening the door for new unbreakable encryption methods, and some of the problems with creating a quantum computer.
Finally, it will suggest a few ways that your information could be compromised even without the encryption being broken.
notes:
This material has not previously been publicly presented, but it was part of the final paper for a graduate course on designing secure systems, and the professor encouraged students to seek publication or conference presentation.

I tagged it with 'fun' even though it's also a serious topic because I take a lighthearted approach, and I think it's a fun little exercise to try to implement some of the algorithms discussed using Python. I also tagged it with 'systems' and 'security' because that's what the main topic is about, and 'best practices' because I offer a few suggestions to help improve personal cybersecurity.

name: Evan Kohilas
bio:
Evan is a passionate 3rd year Computer Science & Maths, Student and Tutor at the University of New South Wales.

He loves tutoring Python to high school students through the National Computer Science Summer School, and the NCSS Challenge, and is the Social Events Head of the UNSW Security Society.

You'll often find him procrastinating by crashing lectures he's not enrolled in, nomming on subway cookies and chasing bunny rabbits.
title: Viterbi knows what you'll type next!
abstract: What if I told you I could predict your next word? Sure, there are plenty of text prediction algorithms that try to do the same, but how many of them will also attempt to read your mind? Come along and I'll show you how Viterbi can finish your sentences!
description:
When it comes to text prediction, Markov Chains ⛓️ and Neural Networks 🧠🌐️ are cool, fancy but cliché.

Come along and learn about Hidden Markov Models and the Viterbi Algorithm (commonly used in speech recognition), and how we can also use them for contextual word prediction.

I'll cover my strategies and results, while showing and talking about my hurdles with the Numpy implementation.
notes:
I have always wanted to do something that would make use of my chat history, and so last year I was given the idea to write a contextual autocomplete engine that would try to predict a user's next word given a sentence. 

But I also wanted to do something new and different, and not just make another Markov Chain or Neural Network, and so I realised that I could take the Viterbi Algorithm that I had just learnt, and alter and apply it in a different way to be used for contextual text prediction, that could guess your next word given yours or others, recent or entire history.

In this talk I aim to briefly cover some common text prediction algorithms, such as Markov chains, and then talk about and explain hidden Markov Models and the Viterbi algorithm, such as how they're normally used and how to predict a hidden state from observable states, and go over my different strategies and results, all alongside showing and talking about my hurdles with the Numpy implementation.
additional_info: As I live in Australia, It would be very difficult to attend without a travel/accommodation grant of $750, as my estimated costs would be approximately $1300.

name: Mike C. Fletcher
bio: Mike Fletcher is a Design Epistemologist (philosopher studying the formation of meaning or belief) turned programmer. He has been programming Python since the mid 90's, is a Python Software Foundation Fellow, and runs a software consultancy in Toronto. He's married to a computer scientist and has two smallish children who are not computer scientists except in the sense that everyone is a computer scientist these days. He's taught programming to children and adults, has worked on lots of Open Source projects, and generally has been around long enough to have silly opinions about all things Python. He values the small and silly bits of life and reminds you that Python is named after the Pythons, not the Python.
title: Where's my singularity already?
abstract: We all want a soft singularity where everyone loses their jobs and hates us, but how close are we to accomplishing it? We'll look at what we've got so far, and what we need to accomplish to bring everything down in flames around us. We might look at whether it's a good idea if we get time.
description:
Market forces mean that corporations are going to force us into a soft singularity. A set of societal changes brought on by the potential for automation from machine learning tools that will dramatically, and relatively rapidly change the nature of work. As practitioners of programming and machine learning we are moving toward that future. While it may not be as close as some would sell it, we are moving and we should be ready for it.

We're going to look at where we are in the process of achieving a soft singularity; where machine learning becomes a general tool to be applied to most programming tasks, and where the state of the art is sufficient to rewrite the economics of industries when it is applied. We'll look at a few ideas of what a soft singularity tool set would need to provide, and what that would let it do with regard to changing the nature of work.

We'll contrast our current accomplishments with the idea of what is necessary to bring about a soft singularity, then highlight the areas of research that seem to be pointing toward this type of goal, and what each capability would enable within this limited and controlled form of machine learning applications. We'll look at some of the issues surrounding access, fairness, ethics and the like.

We'll briefly contrast the ideas of soft and hard singularities and highlight the features of thought that we likely do not need to develop just to dramatically shift the nature of work, but which would shade into producing a general intelligence. We'll look at how those features might wind up being useful as tools applied to machine learning projects.

Finally, we'll discuss the ethical and practical questions surrounding the drive to automate away significant fractions of the livelihoods of the masses of the world. This will necessarily include discussing whether these technologies will wind up exacerbating existing issues, biases and the like. Does the potential for increased productivity and freedom from drudgery justify potentially destabilising countries? Is there any realistic curb on the profit motive for corporations to pursue machine learning automation as soon as it becomes practical regardless of human consequences? Is there some social or government change needed to adapt to the changes?

name: Samy Abidib
bio: Samy Abidib is a Senior Software Engineer at Shopify on the Data Acceleration team building Python ETL data platforms using PySpark. Samy has been using Python static typing in production for the last 2 years and is an organizer of the Ottawa Python Meetup.
title: Why I trust MyPy more than my test suite
abstract: At Shopify Python static typing is used in all Python 2/3 projects. Static typing accelerates teams and helps us maintain code built for longterm. In this talk I explain how static typing pervades developer workflows at Shopify as a part of code review, CI, CD, and git pre-push hooks.
description:
This talk goes through the details of what static typing looks like in Python and what it looks like at Shopify. I start by discussing how we took a chance on a new project and used static typing from day one. I delve into how this increased productivity, readability and made it trivial to make large scale refactors. This was especially apparent for developers that switched into the team from a previously untyped language.

Since we took that chance 2 years ago, we've been using typing it production for all new Python project.

Specifically, I discuss:
   - What static typing in Python looks like.
   - Some examples of why it can be helpful (and sometimes be as trustworthy as your test suite).
   - What a developer workflow with static typing looks like.
   - The process of implementing static typing in production.

name: Steve Jackson
bio:
Steve Jackson is an Electrical Engineer with 40 years of experience with designing and manufacturing a variety of hardware and software products - embedded systems for cash registers,  theatre ticketing and kiosk applications, and bank teller automation equipment. 
He has lived through the 30-year software crisis, and recalls a time before the crisis began. In the good old days, when you needed a program, you wrote a program. DSI takes us back to this happy dynamic of controlling our own projects, with a minimum of system complexity. His desktop is Ubuntu.
title: Simple Made Easy Computing
abstract:
What if all software could be reduced to the equation:  y = F (Y,G) 
where: y is a new Immutable Tuple, F is a Microservice Function, Y is the set of all previously published Immutable Tuples, and G is fresh GUI input. The only system data persistence is Y. 
That would change how we do computing!
description:
This talk continues the “Simple Made Easy” framework theme from my talks at PyCon 2016 and 2017. What is described is a simple and robust method for Immutable Tuple Flux computing. Streams are the future! My 2016 talk "Simple made easy" has over 2,700 views. People are saying, "OK, it sounds good. How do I get started with Data Stream Infrastructure?" This talk will illustrate that the process is simple and easy! The subject application is non-trivial – a large scale Payroll application! 

“Citizen Developers” (who are not in short supply) can employ Python to create exactly the Microservices they need and want. This empowers the stakeholders, and eases many of the cultural problems that so often bring conflict in software development work. The Data Stream Infrastructure (DSI) process is inherently Agile, because it meets the original 12 Agile principles without using scrums, kanbans, standups, or micromanaging.
What if all software could be reduced to the equation: 	y = F (Y,G) 
where: y is a new Immutable Tuple, F is a Microservice Function, Y is the set of all previously published Immutable Tuples, and G is fresh GUI input. The only system data persistence is Y. That would change how we do computing! 

Simple made easy. 

This talk describes the Data Streaming application of DSI in more detail, showing its application to a major Government Payroll system. We were punching above our weight!

The blogosphere is full of caveats and warnings about Microservices, and how  they can turn into Megadisasters. Our DSI methodology is easy and safe to use, and it has a short learning curve. We think it is a "software silver bullet". It is accessible to "Citizen Developers". DSI is a "medium code" paradigm, because the Microservices are small single-person programs, and the developer does not need a CS degree!

name: Jeannette Washington
title: Your Special Abilities and Python
abstract: The most unstoppable programmers have been in a situation where a system has gone down or their code broke, and they were responsible for getting it back up. Their resilience can almost always be attributed to their special abilities.
description: A high incident of dyslexia and ADHD traits are found in computer programmers. With today's ever-changing technology-reliant world, join me for an all hands on deck "Think Aloud" conversation about special abilities such as dyslexia and ADHD. With that in mind, let’s steer the strengths, park the misconceptions and drive the tech hacks meant to empower programmers who exhibit special abilities.
notes: I am Jeannette Washington, M.Ed. a former Speech Language Pathologist with nearly a decade of experience working with students that exhibit special abilities. My expertise in the field of dyslexia has been solicited in The Washington Post alongside the cofounder of the Yale Center for Dyslexia & Creativity. Learning Python has ignited my passion for special populations in the tech industry. I have spoken at the Mississippi Dyslexia Symposium, Word Camp Publishers Chicago and participated in a Diversity in WordPress Panel, to name a few. I can always be found boasting the importance of accessibility, inclusivity, neurodiversity and equity in the tech industry.

name: Kojo Idrissa
bio: Kojo Idrissa *was* an accountant who got an MBA and taught at university in two different countries. He's *now* a software engineer and is still trying to figure that out and grow into the role. He's also been a DjangoCon US organizer since 2016 and is the DEFNA North American Ambassador. He's spoken at tech conferences about spreadsheets, contributing to tech communities, Dungeons & Dragons, inclusion and privilege. You can find him online at http://kojoidrissa.com/ or as [@transition](https://twitter.com/Transition) on Twitter.
title: A Tale of Two Pythons: Growing Contribution Through Inclusion
abstract: Starting as a scripting language, Python is now used heavily for software engineering. But the growth of data science, along with Python's accessibility, brings an influx of new community members w/ no desire to be software engineers. How do we best embrace our potential new contributors?
description:
In this talk I'll look at people joining our community who aspire to do two different, yet equally valid, styles of coding:

-  Programming: *people writing code alone, for themselves, that’s meant to run on their own machines, under their supervision* 
-  Software Engineering: *people writing code in teams, meant to be run on other people's machines, without supervision*

Increases in computing power, dropping computer prices and the rise of data science have all led to an increase in people using Python for the "Programming" style of code. Yet our community often tends towards full-on Software Engineering as the "proper" way to code. I'll demonstrate that these styles can both be done with basic or advanced Python. After that, I'll look at practices that may benefit one, but not the other, discuss when there may be shifts between the two, and examine how we as existing community members can help guide new members down the path that best fits their goals. This maximizes their chance for success and our chance to add new contributors to our community. Let's not forget: Python is a FLOSS project. We need all the help we can get.

Remember, all software engineers are programmers, but all programmers don’t need to be software engineers. But some programmers may become software engineers.
notes: I'm the best person to give this talk because it comes from a talk I've given at [PyOhio](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_7dmHvibbEA&) and will give at [PyGotham](https://2018.pygotham.org/talks/a-junior-developer-s-guide-to-software-engineering/): A Jr. Developer's Guide to Software Engineering. This talk looks at a similar issue, but from a different angle. And as someone who ends up trying to mentor new people learning to code and joining our community, I've given this issue a lot of thought.

name: Leland McInnes
bio: Leland McInnes is a researcher at the Tutte Institute for Mathematics and Computing working on bringing new mathematics approaches to problems in unsupervised learning. His work include the hdbscan clustering library and most recently the umap library for dimension reduction.
organization: Tutte Institute for Mathematics and Computing
title: UMAP: Fast, Scalable Dimension Reduction
abstract: Do you have data that you want to visualize but it is too high dimensional? Do you want non-linear dimension reduction for machine learning? UMAP is an easy to use, scikit-learn compatible tool to do all this and more. If you want to understand how UMAP works and what it can do this talk is for you.
description: This talk will present a new approach to dimension reduction called UMAP. UMAP is grounded in manifold learning and topology, making an effort to preserve the topological structure of the data. The resulting algorithm can provide both efficient 2D visualisations of data of comparable (or better) quality to t-SNE, and general purpose dimension reduction for machine learning. UMAP has been implemented as an easy to use (scikit-learn compatible) python library that can perform efficient dimension reduction, scaling out to far larger datasets than t-SNE or other comparable algorithms (see http://github.com/lmcinnes/umap).
notes:
Talk outline
-----------------

1. Intro, and quick introduction to dimension reduction: 5-7 minutes
2. Intuitive explanation of the algorithm -- why it works: 10 minutes
3. How to build a fast implementation -- algorithms + python + numba: 5 minutes
4. Future directions: 5 minutes

Technical level
---------------------

Due to time and space requirements this talk is more technical and assumes some machine learning and data science background. The meat of the talk is a description of the algorithm itself. While mathematics expertise is helpful for attendees to get a full understanding the talk focusses more on intuitions and core ideas rather than technicality, so attendees with a data science background should find it understandable and useful.

Speaker details
----------------------

I am the primary author of the library I will be speaking about. I am a relatively experienced speaker having spoken previously at SciPy and PyData events and presented a poster at PyCon. I also have many speaking engagements at universities and elsewhere. In particular I have given a version of this talk previously at SciPy 2018. You can view that version of the talk [on youtube](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nq6iPZVUxZU). I would be happy to receive feedback from reviewers on ways that the talk could be further adjusted to suit a PyCon Canada audience.

name: Michael Hoye
bio: Mike Hoye is a former systems administrator, entrepreneur and presently the engineering community manager at Mozilla. While he has been internet-famous for a number of oddly unrelated reasons, in 1998 he was recognized at a party for a Usenet post he had written months prior. This allowed scientists to precisely determine the Planck Length of internet fame: the absolute lowerbound below which the concept of celebrity becomes meaningless. The only practical result of this discovery is that you've probably heard of him but don't remember why.
title: The Evolution Of Open
abstract: We talk a lot about bout open source, open standards, and working in the open, but the world has changed a lot in 20 years, and how we understand "open" hasn't kept pace. I'd like to talk about the evolution of "open" to the present day, and a theory of where it's going.
description:
At Mozilla, open software and open collaboration has been central to our identity as an organization since the beginning, but in 20 years the nature of openness - the context, the challenges, and the costs - has changed dramatically.  The word "open" means a lot now, and implies a lot more, and it's working overtime in any discussion about software and the organizations that create it to paper over some deep disagreements and troubling trends in how we work, what we work on and why. 

I'd like to spend some time talking about how our ideas of openness have evolved for the people, communities and institutions that value, what that means, and what comes next.
notes:
I have modest technical requirements for this - some static slides, I'm mostly a talker, but I like to walk around a lot.

As for "why I'm the best person to speak on this subject" , I may not be? I've been working at Mozilla for the last few years as we've struggled through dramatic cultural and engineering changes, and I flatter myself to think I've helped us succeed at those changes. I think there's some value in understanding how things have evolve, and I'd be effective at communicating that evolution.

name: George Khaburzaniya
bio: I was born in Georgia, the country not the state. I moved to San Diego when I was 9 years old, and I'm super excited to have DjangoCon coming to my home town. I graduated from UCLA with a B.S. in Physics, but became a software developer a few years later. At my first job I had to program in Basic, as well as Python. I play Dungeons & Dragons in my spare time.
title: Unicode and Python: What You Need To Know
abstract: Web programmers need to know about Unicode these days. If you're building an app or site that might be used by someone that will type in a language other than English, you need to know Unicode to avoid a constant stream of errors. Or if you want to use emoji, that's also Unicode.
description: This talk will cover what Unicode is and specifically how Unicode is used in Python3. User input cannot be relied on to come in ASCII, or any given encoded character set, so taking text input from your users requires a knowledge of Unicode. We will cover byte strings vs. Unicode strings, opening files in text vs binary mode, a few common encodings, and errors encountered when Unicode is not used, and why Unicode is necessary in the first place. This talk is for anyone that wishes to build a web application that takes text input from users.
notes: A projector and a laptop will be sufficient as I will be using slides to present this talk. I don't know I'm the best person to speak on this subject, but I do regularly work with user input and I regularly encounter errors due to improper handling of it (such as when clients have umlauts in their name) at my workplace, and have been doing so for more than a year.

name: Stuart Williams
bio:
Stuart Williams has a M. Sc. in Computer Science and Engineering from
the University of Washington.  His current position is Software
Architect at IGM Financial/Investors Group in Winnipeg where he helps
teams with their use of Python for Data Science, operations, and web
development.

He has taught Computer Programming at University, at summer camps for
high school students, and at grade schools.  His Python tutotials,
taught at the North American Python Conference for over a decade, 
have received 60,000 views on YouTube.

He founded the Winnipeg Python Users Group, now the Python Winnipeg
Meetup in 2005, and the Winnipeg Data Science Meetup in 2017.
title: Understanding Character Encoding and Mojibake
abstract: Encoding non-ASCII characters is confusing and easy to get wrong. The Unicode standard make it easier, but not trivial. It does not eliminate encoding defects or the importance of understanding the concepts. This session will will give you all you need to understand and implement encoding.
description:
Have you ever had a bug where an accented phrase such as "N° de téléphone" turns into "NÂ° de tÃ©lÃ©phone"? This is known as mojibake (文字化け), which is a Japanese term meaning roughly "character change". It's evidence of a bug in code that does (should do) character encoding, decoding, or possibly both.

Web protocols help, but they also add some complexities, make it easy to introduce defects, make it harder to debug them, and for some let them get by without really understanding what's going on with encoding.

After this session you will know how to correctly use Unicode and its character encodings to write correct code, and how to diagnose encoding defects.

We'll cover the Unicode standard and relevant aspects of UTF-8, ASCII, ISO-8859-1, UTF-16, Windows-1252, and the Byte Order Mark (BOM) character. Several examples will be presented to demonstrate how encoding can go wrong and how to diagnose the problems.
notes:
I believe this topic is relevant because I keep running into bugs related to encoding even in newly written code, and a lack of understanding of the basics of Unicode. I've presented on this topic several times with material based on real examples of encoding problems and defects and how we were able to diagnose them.

The diagnosis section will focus on tools and how they both help and hide encoding issues.

Throughout the session I'll build up a short list of simple rules to follow that should enable prevention of all encoding defects when they are followed.

name: Christoph
bio: Christoph Gockel is a Software Crafter at 8th Light who enjoys writing clean code almost as much as watching Ghostbusters.
title: Slice and Dice - Incrementally Building Quality Software
abstract:
We often build software until we think it’s “ready” to be released. Weeks or months can go by until our product is actually used and we get feedback from real users.
Come along to learn more about ways to build trust with stakeholders and customers early and build better products along the way.
description:
In software we deal with a lot of uncertainties. This can include technology choices, vendors, deadlines, team structure and sustainability just to name a few. But instead of embracing uncertainty and taking on the risk of delivering something, we rather try to manage and mitigate the risk by not putting software in front of real users at all. Does this sound counter productive to you? It sure does to me.

In this talk we’ll discuss ways to deal with those risks. Almost always there’s a way to gather feedback quicker than waiting until the “perfect” solution is ready. “Done is better than perfect” they say. We’ll go through examples of how to slice user stories in ways that benefit our users as well as our teams.
We will learn techniques that help us slicing big and risky features into smaller, manageable and useable features. This not only helps us developers mitigate risks, it also helps management deal with delivery pressures in a different and more open way.
notes:
Building trust goes both ways by incrementally building software. We build trust with our fellow developers by constantly building something that works and we build trust with our surrounding management because we constantly deliver something valuable.

In many of my past projects I've been part of at 8th Light, I've seen teams and organisations struggle with the idea of releasing something that's not super polished. It doesn't have to be this way, though. Almost always there's a way to carve out something small and manageable out of a huge task. This talk is exactly about that. Amongst other things we'll go through examples of stories we've worked on, how they were tackled and how successful the implementation was. This is not always a positive example but something that will show both sides of the medal.
additional_info: No special meals or assistance needed.

name: Christoph
bio: Christoph Gockel is a Software Crafter at 8th Light who enjoys writing clean code almost as much as watching Ghostbusters.
title: Test Driving Django Applications
abstract:
Unit tests, acceptance tests, integration tests or end to end tests… As an industry, we sure don’t lack options to verify if an application is doing what it’s supposed to do.
Come along to learn about the differences in approach and the result they have on our products, teams and codebases.
description:
The physical layout of a Django application is more or less defined by the way Django handles HTTP requests. But it doesn’t stop there. The core of our application shouldn’t be defined by the way Django expects things to be laid out.

There’s a lot of content written about isolating ourselves from frameworks. This is not just a means to an end to make our developer selfs happy. Having abstractions in place that enable this kind of isolation help us create better testable applications in the end. Not only better testable but also better designed and more understandable codebases.

In this talk we’re going to discuss trade-offs between tying ourselves to a framework and completely isolating ourselves from it. In the end it’s a spectrum and it’s important know and understand where we want to land on that spectrum for a given part of the project.

Depending on where we sit on that spectrum some tests are more important than others. So we’re going to discuss what are the tests we should invest in and what are the tests we can defer or even completely skip.
notes:
There are many ways to go about testing an application as a whole, but in past projects I’ve been part of some patterns have emerged that helped us keeping our tests nice, clean and fast!

Together with those patterns, or let’s say different approaches to designing those applications (as I’m not necessarily referring to design patterns here), some tests seem more important than others. Most notably if the focus is on unit tests and we trust those tests, verifying the HTTP layer can become trivial as we don’t need to test our whole application through the HTTP layer anymore.

Some of those ideas are known under different names like Hexagonal Architecture by Alistair Cockburn (also "ports and adapters"), Clean Architecture from Bob Martin or Onion Architecture as Jeffrey Palermo called it.
But more important than the name are the ideas and benefits behind those architectures: Modelling our software in the language of our domain. Making it explicit and obvious that we're not writing a Django application that handles online orders but that we're creating an e-commerce application that happens to use Django to be able to be used through the web.

With an application like that it’s easier to see and draw parallels to the testing pyramid and explain why it makes sense to invest more into low level unit tests, and gradually remove the amount and need for more high level acceptance tests.

Personal note: I also submitted that talk as a Flask version. Depending on the audience it might make sense to choose one over the other and I leave it to the committee who creates the overall schedule to pick the appropriate version.
additional_info: No special meals or assistance needed.

With an application like that it’s easier to see and draw parallels to the testing pyramid and explain why it makes sense to invest more into low level unit tests, and gradually remove the amount and need for more high level acceptance tests.

Personal note: I also submitted that talk as a Django version. Depending on the audience it might make sense to choose one over the other and I leave it to the committee who creates the overall schedule to pick the appropriate version.

title: Reactive Python, Coding Data Streams with FRP Techniques and Rx.py
abstract: Reactive Programming is becoming more widely used. We see it in the JavaScript world with React and AngularJS and in Java with Android. With Python we use the Rx.py library, look at some code and run a few example programs. We walk through how to create observables, how to use subjects to multicast data through multiple streams, along with unit tests to show how different observable functions and operators work. We discuss where reactive programming can be used and how they can used for GUIs and web servers.

title: Artisanal Async Adventures
abstract: Asynchronous networking may seem hard to understand at first, in this talk I will show this is not the case. In 100 lines of code, I will write a low level async network stack in front of your eyes, explaining how things work as we go. By the end, you should understand how and why async code works!
description: If you want to write an efficient server, asynchronous networking is an excellent strategy to do so. To build a production ready system, you would use asyncio, tornado, twisted, trio or another popular implementation. However, to fully understand how and why it works, I will ignore these solutions and instead craft an artisanal asynchronous implementation in front of your very eyes. Step by step we will turn a blocking socket server, only capable of handling a single connection at a time, into a beautiful non blocking server that has no trouble dealing with many connections at once. By the end, you should see that asynchronous code is not magical at all, but nevertheless incredibly useful.

title: Managing OpenAPI technical writing workflows with oaspec and oawriter
abstract: Many tools exist for developing and testing APIs based on the OpenAPI standard, but there is limited tooling for documenting existing APIs. oaspec fills this need by providing a mutable representation of OAS in Python, and oawriter enhances the workflow for writing human-readable API docs.
description:
Although there is a large ecosystem of tools for designing, developing, and testing APIs based on the OpenAPI Specification (OAS; formerly known as Swagger), the available tooling for documenting existing RESTful APIs is relatively limited.

OpenAPI specification generators rely on complex annotations written in a domain-specific language and require user-facing narrative documentation to be stored in code. In contrast, manually-maintained specification documents are written directly as OAS definitions and keep code separate from narrative docs, but can quickly become out of date. These issues are compounded when an organization provides access to multiple backend microservices through an API gateway which must provide a single API definition.

The goal of this talk is to introduce and demonstrate `oaspec` and `oawriter`—two open source tools which aim to solve these problems.

`oaspec` is an unopinionated Python package for creating and manipulating OAS definitions in Python. With it, developers can generate machine-readable API definitions without needing redundant annotations, and they can build unified gateway specifications from multiple backend service definitions.

`oawriter` is a CLI tool (built on `oaspec`) for managing the technical writing workflow of user-facing API docs. It allows a technical writer to write, organize, and update independent narrative docs, inject them into machine-readable definitions, and create API documentation consumable by OAS tools and end users alike.

The tools that I will be introducing in this talk were built to fill the need for full-featured, flexible documentation tools that can work with existing APIs. They are being used in production to support a complex API serving multiple backend services.
notes:
I am a technical writer and Python cloud engineer at Platform.sh, a container-based Platform-as-a-Service providing NoOps/serverless application hosting.

When I was hired this past summer, my first task was documenting our existing APIs and generating a unified API specification to be served by our new API gateway. After a thorough review of existing tools, I found that many were so opinionated that using them would require us to rewrite parts of our backend, and none of them offered a flexible way to combine specs from multiple backend services. These tools are the result of filling that need. This material has not been presented anywhere else.

Note that I haven't included any links to the project because we have not yet released the tools as of the time of writing. This is because the original tool (that we're currently using in production) is both an importable package and CLI tool for working with Swagger/OAS 2.0 definitions, and it was fairly tailored to our specific use case. We've decided to move our API to OAS 3.0, and since the tooling has to be modified to accommodate that, I'm extracting the OAS model into a separate package as `oaspec` and broadening the scope of both tools to a general use case.

As I'm developing it for public release, I'm making sure it has total test coverage and thorough documentation, and I want it to have a mostly complete feature set before release which will take another week or two. If you're reviewing this more than two weeks after the submission deadline, the package is likely residing at: https://github.com/platformsh/oaspec

title: Training a Convolutional Neural Network with Thousands AWS Lambda Functions
abstract: Deploying and configuring Tensorflow/MXNet on virtual instances is non-trivial. Could we train a model on the by just pressing a "bottom"? Serverless cloud does.  Serverless architectures like AWS Lambda are going to be the next-gen cloud. We've crafted a ML framework running on AWS Lambda.
description:
Existing distributed machine learning (ML) frameworks heavily rely upon the parallelism achieved using a dedicated cluster of physical servers or virtualized instances, and one needs to know the quantity and type of these servers to employ for each machine learning training job. Yet, for ML practitioners and data scientists, the process of provisioning a physical or virtualized computing platform itself is inevitably lengthy and error-prone. For example, it is challenging to choose the optimal configuration from numerous combinations of instance types and settings on AWS EC2, which has 115 instance types. 

Following the footsteps of traditional virtual machines and Docker containers, _serverless_ (or Function-as-a-Service) architectures, represented by AWS Lambda and Google Cloud Functions, have emerged as a burgeoning cloud computation model to further reduce costs and improve manageability in cloud computing.  With serverless architectures, developers do not need to manage dedicated servers for their applications. Instead, they only need to define a set of stateless functions with access to a common data store. Due to its lightweight nature, ease of management, and ability to rapidly scale up, serverless computation has become the trend of building next-generation web services and applications.

Most existing machine learning frameworks are designed for physical servers or virtual instances, such as TensorFlow, MXNet and PyTorch. For machine learning developers without a dedicated cluster, they deploy their machine learning dev stack on cloud such as AWS EC2. However,  the cloud is usually not fully utilized due to the trial-and-error nature of machine learning jobs. For example, the model hyper-parameters is adjusted frequently, then the training is paused and the cluster is idle but billed. Therefore, training a model with serverless architectures is appealing because 1) developers only pay for the computing time; and 2) thousands concurrent functions can be revoked simultaneously to provide high computing parallelism. 

We have developed a prototype of framework that performs asynchronous ML training on serverless architectures. This talk will show how to train a CNN model with the AWS Lambda and give a brief introduction about the APIs of the prototype.
notes: I am a 4th-year Ph.D. candidate from the ECE department of UofT (http://www.haow.ca). Our group focuses on distributed systems and machine learning techniques. Recently I am working on distributed machine learning systems. I am a big fan of Python and I also worked as a volunteer in PyCon 2016 Toronto.

title: Leveling Up - Teaching Engineers Demystified
abstract: It is difficult to hire Senior Engineers because there simply aren't enough of them to fill every position. This doesn't need to be a problem, because everyone can teach. Let's take a look at some teaching misconceptions, pitfalls, and come up with a strategy to help our junior engineers level up.
description: In the ever growing technology landscape, there are more and more positions that need to be filled and too few Senior Engineers to fill them. Thankfully, there's a teacher in every one of us so we get the privilege to help Junior Engineers grow their skills (and our own in the process). In this talk, we'll shoot down some of the excuses that might be preventing you from letting out your inner teacher and talk about ways to continue to improve. By the time we're finished, you should feel much more comfortable growing your team by helping others that are less far along in their journeys. The "10x Engineer" might be a myth, or it might be someone who's willing to multiply themselves through teaching.
notes: As a software engineer, I've experienced the pains of trying to grow a team when the pool of candidates seemed smaller than we'd like, but teaching got us where we needed to go. title: Observability: Deliver Reliable Software Faster
abstract:
Let's talk about the bottlenecks of the traditional way of building software and how one can benefit from observability to deliver more on a shorter amount of time, to run experiments, and to ensure quality.

How can modern technologies empower your team to do more! 
(Based on real use cases)
description:
We still live in an era where most of the computer behavior is dictated by human generated code. 

One of biggest errors one can make is to assume that such code is bullet proof based of the “false positives” facts that people take for granted: “works on my machine”, “it has 100% test coverage”, and such.

The impact of such assumption is the unawareness of unexpected behaviour, which, to some extend, should be already covered by current testing methodologies, considering that code already doesn’t work 100% of the time.

The talk approaches the overwhelming challenges of writing reliable code professionally: How does one ensure the code works the way it was designed to?

Exploring the bottlenecks of the traditional approach, comparing with modern practices and analysing the impact both from engineering and product perspective.
notes:
(HEY->> for the reviews only, contains spoilers :D )

I have been working as a software engineer for about 7 years, recently leading high value topics for companies, building architectures from the scratch, scaling for TV campaigns or working with pricing models and such. During this time I've faced different challenges and learned a lot about different ways of handling tests, quality assurance and the impacts of those different ways on the tech architecture, on the teams, and product/process.

From the classical monolith end-to-end integration tests, smoke tests, up to the approach we use on my current company, where we value tight contracts and monitoring (observability) over everything else. 

By questioning the necessity and the cost of end-to-end tests we started to evaluate other options to deliver software faster but still ensure quality, and it has been working quite well for us. 

We have decided to use devops/monitoring techniques to measure how many times our users interact with our systems and we alarm when they can't, that way we don't need to run extensive tests before release, indeed we push to production code almost as is created (behind feature flags and smooth rollout controls) .

On the long run that seems to be the way to go for us, because it helped us to auto-scale our platform on demand based on key-features of our projects. e.g.: "we autoscale the authentication API based on how many authentications is handling per second" ....

abstract: Machine learning has so much hype around it that it can seem like magic. Learn the math behind the magic in this whirlwind tour of machine learning. After spending a few minutes learning about machine learning theory, we'll jump right into practice with three different use cases.

title: The Fn Project. How serverless empowers developers to adopt the most efficient technologies towards success.
abstract: In this talk, I'd like to show how a new serverless offering - The Fn Project, empowers developers to pick exact, the most efficient, open source technologies to solve their business needs. This talk will describe the real experience based on years of the serverless application development.
description:
The idea of adopting multiple programming languages to build highly distributed applications is not new to anyone. We all been taught to use necessary toolkits to solve certain problems in the most efficient way. 12Factor concept helped us to understand how to shift from the monolithic applications to smaller functional units - microservices, with that we can extract the most critical pieces of code into a microservice that can be made natively fault-tolerant. But where is the limit to the number of microservices within one application, when the application becomes sort of the nightmare to those who maintain those?

The serverless concept (namely serverless architecture pattern) is the next MUST technology to adopt for the application development. With the serverless developers can stop worrying about the number of components necessary to have up and running for the sake of the stability and fault-tolerance.

In this talk, I'd like to show how a new serverless offering - The Fn Project, empowers developers to pick exact, the most efficient, open source technologies to solve their business needs. This talk will describe the real experience based on years of the serverless application development. 

As the result you might get the following takeaways:

* serverless is not something you should be afraid of
* how to develop the microservices using serverless architecture pattern
* the upsides and the downsides of the serverless
notes: Well, why am I the best one to speak on the subject? I have pretty good experience in serverless, open source and decision-making areas. I'd like to share real experience of "making serverless" as well as the transition from microservices to the scalable serverless solutions. And it's not a total product pitch, we're talking about the real open source project here, not a marketing bullshit.

title: Designing A More Secure Web App with Django and gRPC
abstract: By using Django and gRPC we can increase web application security at the cost of complexity and performance.  How much more complex does our web application become?  And how much performance do we lose?  Is it worth it?
description:
Traditional web application architectures often have direct access to a production database via credentials stored as environment variables.  This enables queries constructed within the web application to be executed against a remote database server.  In the event of a security vulnerability that introduces remote code execution, such as Apache Struts CVE-2017-5638, it also allows attackers full access to the production database.  Through introducing a distributed service oriented architecture we can reduce our exposure to security vulnerabilities that expose remote code execution at the expense of performance and complexity.  This talk will analyze one such implementation with Django and gRPC and assess the additional complexity and performance characteristics of the distributed architecture compared to that of a traditional web application setup.

In addition to covering the aforementioned abstract we'll address what RCE vulnerabilities are, what is gRPC and how it's possible decouple data access via gRPC, at what size and type of project does a distributed architecture of this nature make sense, what operational changes need to be made to your development and deployment processes, what alternatives exist to gRPC, and where to go for more information.

title: "Alexa, get me a nice job"
abstract: Ever wonder if Alexa can bring you your favorite food or music, can it also bring to you, a job of your choice? Come & learn to develop Alexa skills with Python to make this happen. A perfect blend of Speech Recognition, Sentiment Analysis via ML and an application to life. Build your own voice bot!
description:
Don’t you just hate it when you are applying for a job, after a long series of technical test we still have to have the HR round of discussion?  Why are we obsessed with talking and interviewing people when everything today is just a tap of a screen away?

In the age of the early man, the resources were very limited and the animals wanting to eat you alive, very large. To keep themselves safe and increase their tribe, they read the person’s face and through that the sentiments, all to gather if they could trust that person and make him/her a part of them.

We are at an age where we have sophisticated technical rounds, there’s an entire community on lets say, Kaggle that can validate the extent of our tech skills, so why not build something that can also being interviews at par with the technical tests. Let’s build a tool that retains the essence of building trust through conversation but gives an objective result like Kaggle.

Let’s call in the super heroes, Python and Alexa (more like Batman & Robin)

The agenda of this tutorial is to enable people to marry the voice processing capabilities of Alexa, AWS Components and the agility of Python to enable Machine Learning to build something that you could talk to, and on the fly.

Imagine getting a job coz you had a chat with a bot, imagine how the barriers of accents, languages and perceptions can be removed, imagine how this can be scaled to any application with a human touch. It’s this endless imagination of the people and how it can ease their lives is what drives us to spread our message and get the world to build something beyond imagination.

title: After working with our data what options do we have to visualize?
abstract: Many of us spend an enormous amount of time working on data but are faced with a hard task of choosing an option on how to visualize our data. We will take a journey into what options are out there to visualize data in python besides matplotlib.
description: After we have worked with our data and done our analysis of what options are out there to visualize our data in python? Matplotlib would be the library to start with, but there are many other libraries that work on top of matplotlib. Pandas, seaborn, altair and a imported version of ggplot from r work on top of matplotlib. There are other options like bokeh and plotly that can give a more stylish output, but it will all depend on our level of comfort with a particular library or the needs that we might have for the output we need.
notes:
I previously gave a similar talk with a group called uoft coders on Interactive plotting in Python and R on april 5, 2018. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y-9aU3NuTcI
I give talks with uoft coders(https://uoftcoders.github.io/studyGroup/) from time to time. I have found that since I am passionate about working with data at work and at home I actually enjoy talking to people about ways to improve data analysis. Having the opportunity to work with data in different languages, this has given me the opportunity to see why it is so important to visualize in python. I have found through personal experience that we are given more options and I would like to share my experiences with people starting in python or wanting to learn about new libraries that are out there.

name: William Horton
bio: William Horton wants to make deep learning accessible and approachable for everyone. By day, he works as a backend engineer at Compass, where he works on systems for ingesting, processing, and serving millions of real estate listings. In his spare time, he [blogs](https://medium.com/@hortonhearsafoo) and speaks about deep learning, contributes to open-source libraries like fastai and pytorch, and competes in computer vision competitions on Kaggle. When he’s not doing tech things, he enjoys powerlifting and singing a cappella.
title: You Can Do Deep Learning!
abstract: It’s 2018, and—guess what?—you don’t need a PhD to do deep learning. This talk will empower you to build a deep learning project using Python and open-source tools. Similar to other domains, like web development, we can leverage frameworks that give us powerful abstractions to help us get started.
description:
You know how to code in Python, and you want to learn more about deep learning. This talk will put the tools in your hands to complete your first deep learning project, and put you on the path to growing your knowledge in this exciting field.

Along the way, we’ll discuss the learning process, and how you can leverage what you already know in order to jump start your progress tackling something new. I’ll even take a detour to talk (briefly) about how I got started in web development with Rails, and the benefits you can get from open-source frameworks with high levels of abstraction.

I’ll walk through the pieces you can put together to build a powerful image classifier with deep learning: hardware (GPUs), training data, model architectures and pretrained weights, and software libraries for running training and prediction with your models. Since all of these things are becoming increasingly available for free on the internet, it’s never been a better time to give deep learning a try.

In the end, you don't need a PhD to get started doing deep learning. You can have fun learning enough to do a simple project, like a cats vs. dogs image classifier. From there, you can go wherever your curiosity takes you!

name: Alex Keeling
bio: Alex Keeling is a software developer living and working in New Brunswick. He's worked as a developer for about eight years, but only recently started using Python regularly. He enjoys working on the backend, where product owners request fewer tweaks. His keyboard of choice is the IBM Model M. Alex likes PEP 572 and can't wait to start using assignment expressions. Pre-kids he enjoyed spending time tinkering with Slackware. Now with kids, he has far too little time for Slackware and runs Ubuntu.
title: Using and abusing AWS Lambda
abstract: What can we do in the AWS Lambda environment besides running small Python functions? Could we install and run git inside a lambda? Could we ssh into a running lambda? Could we run headless Chrome? We'll see just how far we can push the Lambda environment AWS provides us with.
description:
AWS Lambda is one of the leading FaaS (Functions as a Service) options. This talk will give a brief overview and some simple example uses of the service, (web scraper, SMS reminders, image resizing) before diving into exploring the details of how the lambda environment is set up---what exactly can we access in the small Linux container called lambda that AWS provides us with? 
Can we write to disk in lambda? How much disk space do we have? What else is available for us to tinker with? With this information, we'll try some unusual uses for lambda like ssh-ing into a running lambda instance, installing git in lambda and using it to mirror one repo to another, running headless Chromium in a lambda to take take screenshots of sites, and maybe even try running Docker in a lambda.
notes:
No special technical requirements. 
I have led a maker workshop before, and led kids' programming camps, but this would be my first conference talk. 
I've gotten into Python only in the past year, but I'm really excited to be becoming a member of this community.

name: Aishwarya Kaneri, Anugrah S
bio: I'm Aishwarya Kaneri, working at Infrastructure team in Go-Jek, building reliable, highly available, maintainable distributed systems at scale. I’m also a strong adherent of open source principles having contributed to multiple open source projects. Apart from coding, I like cycling and talking.
title: InfluxDB downsampling - a DevOps tale
abstract: At Go-Jek, we use InfluxDB for storing metrics. We faced the issue of high memory and disk space utilization by InfluxDB. This talk is on how we implemented and automated data downsampling in InfluxDB and how this saved us from downtimes, machine cost and pagers.
description: At Go-Jek (a technology startup that specialises in ride-hailing, logistics and digital payments in Indonesia), we use InfluxDB for storing system, application and business metrics for monitoring and alerting, with 55,153 points per second being written into InfluxDB instance during peak time. Due to this we frequently faced the issue of high memory and disk space utilization. Instead of scaling the InfluxDB cluster horizontally, we solved the disk space problem of InfluxDB by downsampling our metrics data. This talk is on how we implemented the solution of data downsampling in InfluxDB with Grafana as our dashboard for monitoring and alerting and how this saved us from downtimes, machine cost and burning the midnight oil due to pagers. This talk is also about how we automated this solution using chef for all the InfluxDB instances along with Grafana at Go-Jek so that our effort could be replicated.

name: Stephen Astels
bio: Over the years Steve's career has meandered from abstract number theory, through cryptography and data science to educational software and web development. He spent many dark years programming in C before learning the joys of Python. Currently Steve is a software developer at the Canadian Digital Service.
title: CI / CD all the things!
abstract: Building continuous integration and continuous deployment into your workflow has never been cheaper nor easier. Starting with a simple flask web app I will (WiFi willing) set up CI and CD in the cloud.
description: Two of the more terrible aspects of software development are fixing bugs that have mysteriously cropped up, and managing infrequent software releases. Continuous integration and continuous deployment help deal with these unpleasantries. By running an exhaustive suite of unit and integration tests on each commit we can find and squash bugs before they are introduced into the production branch of our code. Furthermore, by deploying a web app to production with every merge to master we do away with the tedious and time consuming process of dealing with infrequent software releases. In this talk we will show how easy it is to get started with CI and CD.
notes:
A version of this talk has been given at a Python Meetup in Ottawa.

I can do a 10 minute version of this talk instead where instead of live-coding I just give an overview of the process.

name: Joe Gordon
bio: Joe is a site reliability engineer at Pinterest, where he works on python and performance. He has previously spoken at numerous conferences such as EuroPython, LinuxCon, LCA (Linux Conference Australia).
title: Automated Python Code Transformations
abstract: Manually updating an entire code base is tedious. Thankfully syntax trees provide a safe way to automatically and quickly apply transformations. Learn how syntax trees work, how they are used to upgrade code, and how you can write your own transformations.
description:
Applications of automated code transformations
- automatically style guides
- Upgrading code bases to support python3
- refactoring code to remove a library, use a new API etc.
Syntax Trees
- Why syntax trees?
- ast vs lib2to3
Writing a lib2to3 transformation
Example tools built on lib2to3
- future
- Black
- Bowler
- etc.
notes: I use lib2to3 every day as part of Pinterest's python 3 migration, and think automated code transformation are under used in the python community.

name: Beau Carnes
bio: Beau Carnes is the director of technology education for freeCodeCamp.org. He is also an experienced software instructor. Besides teaching in-person workshops and classes, he has created around 100 software training videos on YouTube and has created two software courses with Manning Publications on the topics of algorithms and deep learning.
title: Theory of Neural Networks
abstract: You can understand deep learning, even without calculus! After explaining the key concepts of deep learning, I’ll live code a neural network without using any frameworks. This will help you understand the concepts at a deeper level.
description:
Learn how machines learn using deep learning. Instead of teaching about a framework such as Karas or TensorFlow, I'll give an overview of the methods behind those frameworks.

In the first part of this talk I will cover topics like:
 - deep learning vs. machine learning
 - supervised and unsupervised learning
 - using neural networks to make predictions
 - gradient descent

During the second part off this talk I will use Jupyter Notebook to create a neural network with Python. I'll be live-coding and explaining each line as I go.

As long as you have basic knowledge of a programming language, you should be able to follow along. No advanced math required.
notes: I’m a great person to speak on this topic because I am currently creating a video course for Manning Publications on this topic called Deep Learning in Motion. Here is a link to the course: https://www.manning.com/livevideo/grokking-deep-learning-in-motion

title: Community from the Inside, Out: Cognitive Encapsulation
abstract:
_I came for the language, but I stayed for the Community_ --Brett Cannon, Pycon 2014

It's evolutionary: community increases competence.

One key to effective community is Cognitive Encapsulation.
What does this entail, how does it work,
and how can you begin to put it into practice?
description:
# Community from the Inside, Out: Cognitive Encapsulation

- Everybody is drawn to Community?
  - list of talks, quotes, other communities which mirrored this;

- Why is that? (a brief [~5min] review):
  - evolution
    - benefits & shortcomings (community & cognition basics)
    - mirrored in biological structures (Panksepp)
    - cognition and feedback structures;
      - the interesting structures: play, joy/sadness; exploration
  - widely favored (evolutionarily)
  - for more detailed overview, see: https://cnx.life/pyohio-community-2018
      and the updated slides: https://cnx.life/pybay-community-2018

- Why - a functional description
  - the limits of cognition, and the benefit of social sharing
    - Edelsons's checker shadow demonstration
    - Mike May / Vision
    - how personal, encapsulated our experiences are (Scott Page, Model Thinking)
  - how the benefit works
    - interplay of openness & competence
  - close-enough models; teams of experts; power psychosis (an overview)

- What you think is a model, initiated by instinct (in part)
  - core affects initiate thought;
  - feelings are reliable (important) data;
  - the data-structure of effective communication;

- Skills:
  - the importance of encapsulation
    - disney simulation story
  - "explicit is better" (all the data structures)
    - caching other's data
    - channels (modes) of communication
    - limits of attention (it's a practice)
  - trust (or "what's love got to do with it?")
    - listening & effective openness
    - the practice & structure of kindness (w/in this framework)

- Where to go from here
notes:
This is the second of presentation topics I am offering on this topic,
focusing on a concept of "cognitive encapsulation" - a key element of community skills.
The first presentation was an overview, at PyOhio 2018 - I had too many topics to cover.
I later gave a lightning talk on the topic (w/o slides) at PyBay 2018, and
an interactive OpenSpaces talk of 2 hours.

I have been invited, and plan to be giving this in PyCon-Ukraine next spring (which I've also volunteer to hellp organize, after it's lack of diversity in 2018 talks), and perhaps elsewhere (e.g. around North America).

My background with the material is based on the following experiences, distilled:
- formal technical reviews at Motorola (1996 - developed & trained > 1,000 people; worked w/ psychologists);
  - I didn't want to do it, was a software engineer just flustered with what was planned (meeting hell!), so this was about communicating effectively, i.e. building skills.
- managing a team of software architects at Motorola (Secure Design Center);
  - that was at the dawn of Agile, and so included architecture;
- 9 years staffing & Volunteer Coordinating at PyCon US
- most recently, putting in place tech-screening methods,
  and screening / interviewing for staff of ~100 at Intel
- co-presenting w/ psychologists on 'relationship skills', and conference organizing;

Over the years, I've had discussions w/ (among others) Brett Cannon on encouraging participation (e.g. for python core-devs); Brett's encouraged me to "take this on the road."
If the PSF governance model moves toward a panel, I've offered team skills training.

I've taken retirement this year, decideing to work on this topic full time (i.e. relationship, team, community skills - see https://connectable.us).  I'm also resurrsecting and will be updating what I used at Motorola for team skills training - https://i-skillszone.com
This is nominally an 8 hr workshops; I'll begin offering late this year, early next year.

name: Meg Anderson Kilfoil
bio: I first used Python to send my brother an annoying number of Lilo and Stitch GIFs over Slack, then discovered that there could be real world applications. I work for Shopify, volunteer with Canada Learning Code and am completing a Masters in Computer Science and Data Analytics. In the free time I pretend to have, I knit.
title: Stop trying; I’m never going to learn to code
abstract: For 20+ years, I refused all attempts to teach me how to code. I wasn’t interested. In this talk, I’m going to talk about my journey from Arts student who was never going to learn to code, to marketing analyst who was never going to learn to code, to data professional who lives in python and sql.
description:
Lots of people tried to convince me to learn how to code. In my mind though, coding was building silly snake games in class, or geocities website building. It never appealed to me, and I refused to learn for years.

Then one day, my brother and I were chatting on Slack and he showed me his new chatbot experiment - and it could send a gif! I wanted it to send more gifs, but my brother refused to add more. “Here is the GitHub repo, figure out how to change it yourself if you want more gifs.” “But this is python.” “Google it, I’m busy.” And with that, my journey began.

It turns out that code had a lot of interest to me, I had just been being taught the kind of coding that my teachers enjoyed, rather than teaching me tools for my interests. I learned how to re-write the gif if/else loop, then how to solve a problem that kept crashing my excel, then how to call an API to see what knitting patterns were trending, then how to store that data in an SQL database so I could look at it again later. All of a sudden, I realized that I was coding more than I was using any other tools.

This talk, while nominally about my personal journey to learn python, is about applying some of the philosophies of learner-centered education in teaching new coders, through focusing on the student's learning style and other interests. The target audience for this talk would be coders who want to teach others, and I would hope from this talk that they come away with some ideas for teaching python to the wider community.

I have not presented this material elsewhere.
additional_info: I do not require any accommodations. Thank you.

title: Data science technique for systematic review of academic literature: An example using Metaknowledge and Scikit-Learn
abstract: Authors of the IPCC Sixth Assessment Report must conduct reviews of more than 330k of academic publications. Here we present a method for systematic reviews of a large number of academic literature to select relevant articles and categorize them; which reduces tasks for human readers.
description: Lead and contributing authors of the IPCC Sixth Assessment Report must conduct reviews of more than 330k of academic publications; almost ten times more than the authors of the fourth assessment report (39K publications) in 2007. The conventional way of literature review using human readers is no longer viable when there is a ‘big data’ explosion of academic publications in climate change research alone. In this talk, we present an efficient method of systematic literature review using data science technique to automatically ‘select’ relevant publications minimizing the tasks for human readers. Here we use a combination of machine learning (Scikit-Learn) and bibliometric & citation network libraries [Networks-Lab/Metaknowledge](http://networkslab.org/metaknowledge/) to search for publications related to the IPCCs new scenario framework and classify each article into topical categories. By performing filtering and classification tasks using data science technique, the number of relevant publications for reviews by human readers is more manageable.
notes:
This talks also introduces metaknowledge to the audience who are interested in bibliometric studies.
For more detail about this project, see [here](https://github.com/aidanpower/SSP-Database)
