title: Machine Learning in the Cloud (for Noobs)
abstract: Are you thinking about adding Machine Learning (ML) to your app, but not sure where to start? Unsure of which cloud or what services you could/should use? Join us to review key ML concepts, discuss how to choose the right cloud services for your app, & application that uses ML.
description:
Artificial Intelligence is taking the world by storm, fueled largely by the introduction of the elastic compute resources in public cloud. If you’ve recently shopped online, searched the web, or streamed a video, you’ve almost certainly interacted with systems powered by AI. These systems are built on powerful Machine Learning (ML) algorithms, that until recently, required large time and financial commitments, as well as specialized knowledge and experience to properly develop, train and test. This is not so any more – the power of cloud computing has brought ML to the masses. Every developer now has the ability to leverage powerful ML resources of the cloud and bring the benefits of AI to their customers and users.

But … where do you start? What services can you use? What services should you use? How do you integrate those services into you application?

During this session we’ll answer those questions, and more, while building and evolving an AI-enabled application. We’ll review ML, introducing common concepts, terms and language. Then, we’ll look at what ML services are provided by cloud vendors like Amazon, Google, and Microsoft, and talk about which of those services is the right match for your application and for your team & skill set. Finally, we’ll walk through a real-world design and demo the resulting application. You’ll walk away from this session with the confidence and knowledge necessary to make the right choices for your own application.

You don’t have to be an AI/ML expert to attend this session, nor do you need AWS/GCP/Azure experience. We’ll keep that at a fairly high level. But we will be walking through code examples, so some familiarity with modern programming languages like Python, PHP or JavaScript would be beneficial, but is not required.

name: Sergio Silva Ribeiro
bio: I am a pythonist, IT consultant, writer and chess player currently researching in Digital City, Smart City, Strategic Digital City, Public Management (New Public Management), Organizational Intelligence, Strategic Management, Knowledge Management, Evidence-based, Digital Image Processing, Machine Learning, and Data Mining.
title: Discovering IMRaD Structure with Python
abstract: Data information within published papers around the world in scientific journals are structured in the format of introduction, methodology, results, and conclusion, i.e., the IMRaD. In this talk I'll explain the possibility of using Python for discovery IMRaD structure.
description: Data information within published papers around the world in scientific journals are structured in the format of introduction, methodology, results, and conclusion, i.e., the IMRaD. Human ability to read or analyze is not capable of processing these large amounts of information. If we can identify the structure and consequently extract it to a user who needs a part of the structure, particularly an article in a foreign language, time will be saved as result. Computational approaches like Machine Learning (ML) and Natural Language Processing (NLP) have been widely used for similar purposes. However, it is very important to identify which one, or which group of classifiers work better for a specific kind of problem. The objective of my work is to identify the best way to classify sentences from abstract papers into the IMRaD structure. This work demonstrates the possibility of integrating ML and NLP for the articles' sentence classification based on the IMRaD structure.

name: John Lam
bio: I work at Microsoft on [Azure Notebooks](https://notebooks.azure.com). I've shipped a few products here, including IronRuby, a labor of love almost 10 years ago, and a few versions of Windows. These days, I spend most of my time making Python a great experience for Data Scientists using our tools and platforms.
title: A Lap Around Azure Services using Azure Notebooks
abstract: You love Python and Jupyter and you're wondering what cloud services to learn next. What if there were a really easy way to get started? In this talk, we'll use Azure Notebooks, Microsoft's free hosted Jupyter service, to learn how to start coding against Azure services like Cosmos DB and Azure ML.
description: [Azure Notebooks](https://notebooks.azure.com) is Microsoft's free, hosted Jupyter service running on Azure. In this interactive session, I'll use Azure Notebooks to show you how to use different Azure services like Cosmos DB and Azure Machine Learning Services from Python. You'll leave the session knowing more about the Python support in Azure services, and perhaps spark some ideas about how you can use Azure Notebooks to show off your Python libraries or Python-powered services to the world.
notes:
My team owns Azure Notebooks, a free, hosted Jupyter service running on Azure. https://notebooks.azure.com. 

Azure Notebooks is a free hosted Jupyter service running on Azure. Many of our customers use it to learn how to program, oftentimes in higher education institutions where they're learning not just how to code, but also about more advanced topics like machine learning.

While our service is pivoting to add the ability to create and consume paid services, we will always have a free tier that is suitable not just for education, but for learning how to use our paid services as well. This is an important part of the story of Azure Notebooks, and PyCon Canada is a great place to start telling that story. We have a number of features that will come online just ahead of PyCon Canada, including Azure Subscription integration that will make it possible to tell the story of how to write code against Azure without requiring the user to login multiple times. PyCon Canada is also a forcing function to get us to pull together a great end-to-end Python story on Azure. 

Microsoft is just getting started with our Python support in Azure and our other products. Conferences like PyCon Canada are a great place to continue telling our Python story to the community.  Thanks!

title: The subtle Pythonic way of (secure) API communication:  Everything from using to building your own APIs for seamless Data Movement
abstract: Having been in love with APIs for pretty long now, I believe they are very significant in their import. In this talk, not only do I aim to show the simplicity of using Python for gleaning big data from sources, but also the best practices that can lead to building sound APIs of our own.
description:
# Overview
I begin with explaining the importance of using APIs today and the varied applications they support. APIs are empowering most of the world's applications today and are a seamless way of data communication. Furthermore, I talk about how some of the more popular APIs can be used to garner big data and how to get over the API hit limits that most of these APIs impose on users. Data gleaned from APIs happens to be a major part of the research projects around the world, and can potentially power applications in various ways. I prove the same with a live example of one of my projects which takes a rather unique approach to use this data in a business solution. Finally, I take it up a notch by showing how we can make our own (SECURE) APIs in Python through which we can work with front-end frameworks like React and Angular. Also, I talk about how deploying these APIs on a cloud can be done rather easily.
notes: The technical requirements are very minimalistic when it comes to building secure APIs in Python. The attendees may need a basic level of Python scholarship. The rest, I can take it from there. Coming to why I am the best person to speak on this subject, I am someone who has been working with APIs and using them in ETL pipelines for years now. I can very well tell the difference between a secure and an insecure API. Also, once I am done with my speech, the attendees will be able to create secure and flexible APIs within minutes. I think the best code is the code you do not need to write, and I believe Python endorses this point of view. However, understanding what happens in the background is even more important because procuring partial knowledge about a subject I believe, is worse than having no knowledge of it. Hence, I choose to take the security aspects of the APIs seriously in this speech and try to disseminate the valued information that I have gleaned from varied sources.

title: Easy CI/CD for your Python app using Bitbucket Pipelines
abstract: Building your application is the fun part, but delivering your application is equally important. Many engineers lack the additional devops knowledge required to build and maintain a pipeline process using tools like Jenkins, or Bamboo. Bitbucket has saved the day,  we'll explore how.
description:
Building your application is the fun part, but delivering your application is equally important. Many engineers lack the additional devops knowledge required to build and maintain a pipeline process using tools like Jenkins, or Bamboo. Bitbucket has saved the day,  we'll explore how. 

In this talk, we'll discuss and demonstrate the various options and functionality available to help us easily build, test and deploy our Python applications with just a few lines of yml
notes:
I am an accomplished software engineer having worked on multiple high visibility projects in private and government organizations. Since my first line of code at age 9, I have honed my skills and continue to grow and share my knowledge, particularly regarding Python based applications.

title: Telephony with Python
abstract: In this age of internet, it's now time to reform our traditional telephony practices with smart software solutions. In this talk, we will look at software application of twilio conference calls and architect scalable cloud infrastructure to support telephony services.

title: Formal Methods - Not Scary and Actually Useful!
abstract:
Formal methods aren’t just for academia, they can be used in real systems too! In industry they can help you catch bugs earlier, increase quality, expand understanding, and deliver faster.

I’ll describe 3 different formal methods: Parnas tables, and the model checkers Alloy and TLA+
description:
When designing software, developers often don’t create more than rough pseudo-code and a few Visio diagrams, before starting work and hoping that any design bugs will be discovered before anything goes to production. Even in the case of highly complex, concurrent, fault-tolerant systems, we’re often hesitant to put much effort into thinking about our solution before firing up our favourite editor/IDE. 

But what if you could eliminate bugs in your systems *before* you've written a single line of Python?

Formal methods are a way to apply rigour to the design phase of your software. They offer a precise way to think about the problem you’re solving, and to explore possible solutions before you write any code. Some formal methods even let you run automated, exhaustive tests against the designs themselves. This lets you ensure that in the hundreds of millions of possible states your system might enter, you won’t hit some undesirable corner case.

I’ve been applying formal methods at work for a few years now, using three different techniques.

The easiest to learn are called “Decision Tables”, or “Parnas Tables”. They provide a quick way to precisely document and think about branching and conditional logic. Do you have a function with some nasty but necessary embedded conditionals/branches, and you want to make sure it all makes sense? Then decision tables might be right for you!

Alloy and TLA+ are two powerful systems, coming broadly from the world of “model checkers”. They allow you to specify the design of your system in a high-level language. The first effect of this is that it makes your system easier to discuss and reason about. Second, both Alloy and TLA+ allow you to automatically test that your system will never violate some properties you declare, before you even have code for your system.

Alloy has been used to find security flaws in real systems and real protocols. Developers at AWS and Azure have used TLA+ to help design systems and find serious, highly-subtle bugs in products including S3, EC2, DynamoDB, Cosmos DB, Azure’s Service Fabric, Azure Networking, etc.

This talk will give a brief introduction to Decision Tables, Alloy, and TLA+
notes:
I’ve been using formal methods in one form or another for almost two decades, with a particular focus on model checkers the past 1.5 years. I’ve successfully applied them at Rackspace, on multiple projects. I have a Software Engineering Ph.D. from a school that had a particular focus on formal methods.

I’m an experienced public speaker, and comfortable in front of an audience.

I’ve given versions of this talk multiple times, usually to positive feedback.

I've spoken at the two previous PyCon Canadas:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lI3ipk6j3-k
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LAEXHua4MQQ

abstract: This is more kind of practical talk to show how you can start writing and deploying function to the Fn in minutes with very few efforts. We'll go through the project introduction and tech details as well as what is supported and what's not.
description:
Serverless architectures refer to applications that significantly depend on “cloud” services (knows as Backend as a Service) or on custom code that's run in ephemeral runtime (Function as a Service or "FaaS").

To application developers, “serverless” mean app where some certain logic of it is still written by the developer but unlike traditional architectures or microservices is run in stateless compute runtime that is event-triggered, may only last for one invocation, and fully managed by a cloud.
Serverless helps developers to transfer responsibility for keeping their apps up and running as well as scaling out their workload capacity without involving DevOps/Ops as we got used to.

In this talk we will go through whole “serverless” thing: from decomposing app and its logic to microservices and further to smaller bits, i.e. functions to defining data flow through functions and building their fault-tolerant pipeline. 
Moreover, we will go through the demo that highlights key takeaways:

* how to design scalable architecture without getting into troubles by hitting concrete bottlenecks

* how to combine multiple programming languages into a single app

* why Go and Python are the ones of the best programming languages designed exactly for serverless


To application developers, “serverless” mean app where some certain logic of it is still written by the developer but unlike traditional architectures or microservices is run in stateless compute runtime that is event-triggered, may only last for one invocation, and fully managed by a cloud. In this talk we will go through whole “serverless” thing: from decomposing app and its logic to microservices and further to smaller bits, i.e. functions to defining data flow through functions and building their fault-tolerant pipeline.
notes: Well, I've been to many PyCons around the globe and I've figured out that most of the time people talking about the ML, data science but not about how to host and actually make your code reusable, how to share the knowledge through its practical application (i.e., if you're good at something - write a book, if you're the best at something - make your code reusable and its runtime reproducible). So, this tutorial would be about the serverless and Python, how these two monsters live together, how they empower each other, etc. Through this talk, I'll try to share some knowledge on how to start coding serverless applications, how do we see future development at Oracle, etc.

title: Sequence extraction for legal Contracts
abstract: Anyone who had to deal with unstructured data to extract relevant information knows how mundane & frustrating it can be. Attend this talk to know how we built a custom sequence extractor to extract 22 key pieces of information of vastly varying length with more than 90% accuracy in under a minute.
description:
Anyone who has ever had to deal with loads of unstructured data, be it corporate/govt. documents, invoices, forms etc to extract relevant information knows how tedious, mundane & frustrating it can be and have wished if only there was a quicker way to do all of this.

Contracts are one such form of unstructured data and extracting key relevant information from it can be difficult to an untrained eye. It may even take some good 20 minutes for a lawyer to go through a contract thoroughly and god forbids if one has to process hundred's of such documents. We tried to solve this problem by building custom sequence extraction models for legal contracts that analyse a contract and extract more than 22 key pieces of information, under a minute.

Through this talk, I hope to shed light on how a custom sequence detection model can be built to extract relevant information from a legal document and will go into depth of the following points:

 1. Unique nature of legal contracts and legal lingo. What various steps were taken to tackle the problem and thus steps taken in preparation of the training data (kinds of feature engineering done).
 2.  Description and comparison with various methods used (sliding-window + SVM, sliding-window + LR etc.) and how and why deep learning (bilstm+crf) gave the best results.
 3. How the model can be generalised for other use cases.

Attend this talk to learn how we built a custom sequence extractor which extracts entities of vastly varying length with more than 90% accuracy.
notes:
The talk won't be very specific to legal contracts but as unstructured text data is a very ubiquitous problem, the talk will also discuss an overall view of this problem, specifically:

1. Where does it occur? (except legal contracts)
2. Why is it difficult?
3. How to solve the problem?

Thus it'll be a talk which an average attendee at Pycon will be able to enjoy.

I recently gave a talk at Pydata Delhi and have worked and deployed the sequence extraction model into production from ground up at my workplace.
For any queries or doubts, please contact me at sharmabhanu546@gmail.com, i'll be happy to answer and improve upon my proposal if needed.

Thank you.

title: Bringing test automation to the Linux kernel with Python
abstract: How do you go about improving the testing for a Linux kernel subsystem? Come see the process and challenges in creating a new tool for test automation to be used by kernel developers, and maybe become inspired to contribute yourself.
description:
Tests in the Linux kernel are sometimes limited. While there may be text files containing commands for a developer to run before submitting a patch, in many cases automation may be limited to a shell script to handle testing.  Enter tdc, an automation tool developed using Python.  Originally planned as an implementation of unittest, tdc instead evolved into a more flexible utility that could be used by anyone without any prior knowledge of Python.  It was implemented to test Linux Traffic Control (tc) using tc's command line interface.

Development wasn't easy, however - certain challenges were encountered along the way and these will be discussed during the talk, as will the successes and surprises that came from tdc's use.

While the talk will be mostly about the development of tdc, its primary goal is to encourage more Python developers to get involved in contributing to the Linux kernel, whether it's through an existing tool like tdc, or developing something new to improve an existing process.  The talk will also briefly cover the process of submitting patches to the kernel if anyone is inspired to do so.
notes:
The stated goal of the talk is to encourage more Python developers to contribute to the Linux kernel environment; tdc is one option, but there are other Python-based tools contained within the kernel repository that may also be in need of improvement.  Time permitting, I will highlight some of the more prominent ones. 

I've actually lived through this process - prior to developing tdc I had never contributed, but my boss (who is a maintainer of tc) approached me one day asking for something to improve the testing of tc.  The kernel may be written in C, but that doesn't mean anyone can't contribute.

title: Pyodide: The Python scientific software stack, compiled to WebAssembly to run in the browser
abstract: Pyodide democratizes data science, by moving the computation to the web browser.  The result is a standard scientific Python stack, running nearly as fast as native speeds, with lower latency and no installation hurdle.
description: Traditional data science notebook environments, such as Jupyter, rely on server-side kernels to perform computation, which add additional complexity, latency and cost.  Pyodide helps to move the computation to the client, providing a familiar no-install experience without requiring specialized server-side resources.  Pyodide is built by compiling CPython and the major scientific packages (Numpy, Pandas, matplotlib, etc.) to WebAssembly.  The result, since it is directly based on upstream packages, is fully-featured and familiar to Python data scientists.  Compute performance is between 1x-5x slower than native, depending on the application.  Interactive latency is significantly improved, since computation and visualization happen locally.  A powerful system to communicate between Python and the Javascript Web APIs is also included, making Python a fully-featured, yet somewhat heavyweight, client-side web development environment.  Future directions of the project, such as improving packaging and data interoperability will also be discussed.
notes:
While I am most likely to give the presentation, I would like to credit additional authors on the work:
Hamilton Ulmer, Brendan Colloran, Willian Lachance, Devin Bayly, Dhiraj Barnwall, Roman Yurchak, Alon Zakai

title: Evolution of a microservice from REST to gRPC
abstract: REST APIs are easy to build, but doesn't perform too well in a microservices system. gRPC instead was built from the ground up for building such microservices. In this talk, you will learn how and why we moved from REST to gRPC to serve millions of users with real-time recommendations.
description:
This talk will take the audience through the journey of how a high throughput microservice based system was rewritten using gRPC to handle millions of users. 

We start with the original service a REST API server and how it was causing a bottleneck when serving real-time recommendations. Slowly the different pieces were refactored and converted to a gRPC based system. 

## Outline

1. Introduction to the REST API service and the different problems we faced
2. gRPC and how it works
    1. ProtoBuf vs. JSON - does it make such a huge difference?
    2. HTTP/2 and its advantages
3. Building a simple gRPC service in Python
4. Deploying using envoy
5. Benchmarks, Statistics, and lies.

## Takeaways for Audience

1. Difference between REST and gRPC systems and where to use what.
2. A quick introduction to building gRPC services in python
3. Learn to deploy them in production
notes:
I have more than a decade experience building products for various startups and in the past three years headed the engineering team to migrate a monolithic machine learning/recommendation system to a microservices architecture. 

There has been a lot of learnings in the journey and even after splitting into microservices, the need for improvement had only increased. 

Being the single important service which served real-time recommendations to users, this service was soon becoming a bottleneck with millions of users using the service. We realized we need to move away from REST and I started prototyping this service in gRPC. 

This talk aims to share that knowledge back to the community and discuss how else to improve it further. 

Note: This talk hasn't been presented before.

title: Efficient Load Testing with Python and Locust
abstract: Web applications and services require  efficient scaling for serving a large number of requests.In order to check the behavior of services under load we need to perform load and stress testing.This is done by generating requests similar to those made by users and test them in production environment.
description:
There are several tools that assist with building, conducting and analyzing load tests for web apps. One of them is Locust.
Locust.io is an open source Python-based user load testing tool. This lightweight, distributed and scalable framework helps to figure out how many simultaneous users a system can handle by writing test scenarios in Python code. It can be used for web applications, websites and web-based services.
In this talk you will learn how to define user behaviour with Python code, and swarm your system with millions of simultaneous users. Hopefully, at the end of this talk you will be able to build more efficient, robust and scalable python web apps.

title: Serverless Authentication with JWT
abstract: Authentication is one of the big parts of every application. Security is always something that is changing and evolving. In this talk, I will cover what JSON Web Tokens (JWTs) are and why using JWTs in your applications when it comes to security is awesome.
description:
Setting up an authentication layer is, without doubt, one of the most challenging yet necessary tasks within any web application. Not only does the application in question always needs to ensure the most basic functionality is set up by default (such as login, logout, reset password), but additionally, it’s required to develop all the libraries to handle the validation of the credentials, the connections to the database responsible for the user data, session management, and general security.
In this talk, We will look at how we can use JSON Web Tokens to add both Authentication and Authorization to our functions. 

With Auth0 authentication which is an online web service that handles authentication protocols like OAuth2, LDAP, and OpenID Connect to allow clients to create authenticated services without the need to build the entire infrastructure. This way, an application can retrieve user-related data and showcase protected information to only logged in users.

### Goals : 

* Promote and Educate people about authentication & authorization. 
* Learn about the different concepts of modern web apps. 
* Setup the environment & conclusion. 

In the talk, we will learn how to use Auth0 to enable authenticated-only sections within a web application, as well as to retrieve protected resources and audiences have lots of opportunities to ask questions both technical and non-technical.

abstract: Few pieces of technology impact a developers productivity as much as what editor they use yet often we choose whatever people around us are using. How have editors changed over the years & what factors should be involved in making an informed choice for writing Python?
description:
How did you choose your current editor?  Did you try out a bunch, thoughtfully weighing the pros & cons of each, or did you default into what was being used by those around you? What would it take for you to leave your current editor?

This talk will explore questions like "How have editors changed over the years?" and "What factors should be involved in making an informed editor choice?" through the lens of a full stack Python developer.

Attendees will walk away with a sense of what some of the pros and cons are with many modern editing environments, how they've evolved over time, and some ability to make more informed choices about what tools they use in their day-to-day lives as Python devs.
notes:
I’ve been writing code in numerous environments for multiple decades, progressing through very technology-specific choices (ex: way back in the day using Borland Turbo Pascal) through to very “general” choices (Vim, VS Code, & Sublime), as well as various IDE’s (Eclipse, PyCharm, etc).  This experience has afforded me insight into what pros & cons each of these environments have, as well as discovered some key features which I think can be of interest for more advanced attendees.

My hope is that the talk will be partly demonstration of “editor tips & tricks” and partly “here are the pros/cons, or tradeoffs you might consider in choosing an editor” in the hopes that others may learn from my experiences to make intelligent choices about the editor(s) they use every day.

It’s worth stressing that my talk is not in any way intended to endorse a particular editor, but rather to show some of the general pros and cons I’ve experienced in using various editors in the hopes others will have better insight as to why an editor may (or may not) be the best fit for their own personal preferences (ex: do they value customizability or “everything just works out of the box”, do they value versatility or something tailored to a particular language/tech, etc).

title: DevOps culture: How to identify & deal with reluctant team members
abstract: The biggest danger to culture shifts is the reluctance of individuals to change. In my career, I have participated in several team changes with various levels of success. This talk is for leaders who have had difficulties with culture change and want to learn more about how to help their teams grow.
description: Culture is the backbone of any changes. The current industry trends are shifts toward the various flavors of DevOps, Agile, LEAN, etc, which are all part of the trendy Digital Transformations. But the key to success is not the technology that is used, not the tools, not even the processes. It's your people. Based on my 20 years of experience in the industry, this talk aims at sharing experiences and help you empower your teams to bring about the needed to operate a next generation business.
notes:
This talk can be done with or without slides. My goal is for people to have 2 take aways. 1. The leader gives the vision and the team executes but maybe not in the expected way and 2. One of us is not as smart as all of us.

For 20 years, I have worked for both large and small companies, all of them in the service industry. In all this time, I have learned that top-down decisions rarely work, are never implemented as designed and never last. However, I believe and am passionate about leadership and I have seen real, effective change work when we empower our people to bring about the desired changes which ultimately, helps us serve our customers better. 

I hope to see you soon!

title: From "Hello World" to production, running Machine Learning models into production using Tensorflow serving and Kubernetes.
abstract: Do you have issues deploying your Machine Learning models in to production or want to learn what are some of the best industry practices in regards to deployment and serving predictions? Attend this to learn how you can serve your models into production.
description:
Do you have issues running your Machine Learning models in to production or want to learn what are some of the best industry practices in regards to deployment and serving predictions for Machine Learning models.
In a local environment the task is simple but things become complex when a model is run in production. Scaling, Robustness and reliability are few metrics that one has to take care of while doing so.

This talk will look into answering that question by taking the audience through an example using best made industry practices.

**Tensorflow serving** "is a flexible, high-performance serving system for machine learning models, designed for production environments" . It allows one to deploy newer versions of a model to production without changing either the architecture or the API. 
Configure automatic deployment of a newer model as soon as an update model is available and run it alongside the older one for a no frills transition or scrap the older model completely and run the improved one in the production. With Tensorflow Serving one can easily deploy, manage their models in production to scale and even automate their deployment pipeline.  
  
  
![Tensorflow Serving Architecture][1]  
    
  
**Kubernetes** is used to deploy the created Serving, which will enable better scaling and robustness. How properties of a Kubernetes cluster like elasticity and resource management can be used to serve models to a large number of users and run computationally and data intensive models in production.

Audience will be taken through each step of the process with in depth insights on the tools used while answering the questions of What, Why and How along the process.

 
**Outline/structure of the Session**  

 - Build an example Machine Learning model.
 - Tensorflow Serving: learning to serve predictions at scale and manage various models in production.
 - Containerising the app.
 - Introduction to Kubernetes and how created models can be deployed through it for robustness and scalability.

**Learning Outcome**

- Learning about Tensorflow Serving and how it's architecture can help in management and serving of models at scale. (Used by Google themself in production)

- Learn how to deploy trained models from Tensorflow Serving to Kubernetes for scalability and robustness.

The audience will be taken through an easy to follow example during the talk and by the end of the talk will know about the best practices of deployment in field of Machine learning and how to do it.



  [1]: https://www.tensorflow.org/serving/images/serving_architecture.svg
notes:
In this talk i won't just talk about exactly one solution but will briefly glance upon various other ways in which one can serve predictions thus highlighting their pro's and cons, then will come to talk about the aforementioned solutions in more detail. 

I'll also look into answering these questions through the talk:

1. What was the exact problem we were trying to solve?
2. What options did we try before this one?
3. Why did they fail and what makes this solution better?
4. What are the limitations of this solution?

I recently gave this talk at Pydata Delhi and it was well received there, it'd be my pleasure to present it at Pycon Canada too.

Thank you.

title: A Fast Introduction to using Mock Objects for Testing
abstract:
If you've never used mocks for testing, this short talk will introduce
them.

If you have used mocks, but you're sometimes confused about how to
mock deeply nested objects, calls, and return values, this talk will help.
description:
Our team has used mocks a lot in the last few years and this talk explains the parts that seem to keep confusing us when we use mocks.

If you'd like to understand the following code examples and how they work, come see.

```
mock_curl = Mock()
mock_curl.return_value.get_info.return_value = 200

mock_curl = Mock(return_value=Mock(getinfo=Mock(return_value=200)))

mock_curl = Mock(**{'return_value.getinfo.return_value': 200})

mock_create_engine = Mock()
(mock_create_engine
    .return_value.raw_connection
    .return_value.execute
    .return_value.fetchall
    .side_effect) = ['row1', 'row2', 'row3']
```
notes: I think it will be a bit rushed in 10 minutes and could easily be expanded to 20 or 25 with room for questions.

title: How (not?) to Write a Batch System with 420 Jobs in 25,000 Lines of Code
abstract: Come hear about our choice to use Python to implement the batch system for a large third-party application using 420 classes, one per job, in 25,000 lines of code. We'll tell you pros, cons, and surprises.
description:
We implemented a large third-party application that required 420 scheduled jobs.

Jobs typically fetch files, then run a command to import data, export data, or generate a report, and finally do some clean up or notifications.

We chose to implement these jobs in 25,000 lines of code, in 420 classes, in a class hiearchy 3 to 6 levels deep, with a few mixins. This choice had some pros and some cons. We'll explain our choice, share some of the gotchas lessons we learned, and some of the interesting surprises.
notes: I haven't yet decided if I think this will make a good talk or not, so I'm proposing it to see what reviewers think! It is an interesting story, with some interesting lessons, but I don't know how valuable they will be to listeners.  It could also be a 30-minute talk.

title: Building a data pipeline to train an image segmentation AI
abstract: Companies are afraid of missing out on the competitive advantage that Artificial Intelligence (AI) offers. Their response is to rapidly build AI on top of brittle infrastructure. This is how I built a robust data pipeline that funnels data into the training procedure of an image segmentation AI.
description: After completing a few small tasks at my job as a Data Engineer I had been given my first project of building the data infrastructure to collect and process all the imaging data to train a Convolutional Neural Net (CNN). I was familiar with the vast online content that intricately details methods used to build and optimize sophisticated machine learning models. However, I found that the online resources concerning themselves with the infrastructure supporting these models was lacking. My first attempt at building this infrastructure utilized the Hadoop ecosystem. However, I found myself equal parts confused and frustrated after four weeks of development and decided to go back to the drawing board. My second approach utilized a combination of Python and Postgres, making use of the task management package Luigi developed at Spotify. This approach allowed me to quickly setup the development environment and write complex processing procedures. I even extended the Luigi package to fit my own use cases. I found that building this infrastructure in Python was more enjoyable to write, easier to maintain and actually faster than Hadoop. I would like to share this experience of navigating the world of data engineering to build robust data pipelines that can support artificial intelligence.
notes: Building data infrastructure to support AI is a marginalized topic in the data science field, it is however, paramount to the success of AI projects. Building this infrastructure requires a diverse skill set that encompasses software engineering, data science and even devops. I think that I am a good person to talk about this topic because I have focused on building data analytics and machine learning software for the past 4 years. With this experience I have gained the practical knowledge of how to build scalable, maintainable and robust data infrastructure. I am extremely passionate about building these data systems and I want to share my most recent experience at PyCon Canada 2018 of building my most sophisticated data pipeline yet. I want to share the lessons I've learned in this project so that fellow developers can avoid some of my mistakes. I would like to give a powerpoint presentation outlining my journey of building a data pipeline used to train a CNN. The only technical requirements would be a projector, cables to connect a computer and possibly a microphone depending on the room. I have not presented this material before.

title: Extending Ansible using modules
abstract:

servers. With its many built-in modules and a flat learning curve, it makes it
easy to get started quickly. This Demo will introduce you on ways on how to extend Ansible far beyond its basic capabilities.
description:
## ansible

Ansible is an IT automation tool which can be used to configure and deploy applications on your infrastructure. It can be used as a configuration management, deployment and orchestration tool. Ansible provides a number of modules which can be used to complete most of the required tasks. For the remaining task, ansible provides a clean API to write modules on top of it to extend Ansible itself. 

## What the talk will cover

- What is ansible

title: Using Python Effectively on the Google Cloud
abstract: Python is a first-class citizen when it comes to support on Google Cloud. With the upcoming releases of Python 3 runtimes on both App Engine and Cloud Functions, there has never been a better time to be a Pythonista. In this talk we'll explore all things Python and Google.
description:
# Description

Python is a first-class citizen when it comes to support on Google Cloud: as the first language supported on App Engine many years ago, it has come a long way since then and has only gotten better. Now, with upcoming releases of Python 3 runtimes for App Engine and serverless runtimes for Cloud Functions, the options for Pythonistas are abundant and as well supported as ever.

In this talk, we'll discuss the various ways you can run your Python code on Google Cloud Platform, popular Python libraries you can use in your code to do everything from detecting asteroids to building chatbots, as well as what's new, upcoming and most interesting when it comes to Python and Google.

# Outline

* Introduction
* Running Python on GCP
  * App Engine
  * Cloud Functions
  * Colab Notebooks
* Python Libraries
  * Tensorflow
  * Media
     * Vision
     * Text to Speech
     * Storage
* What's new and upcoming
* Conclusion
notes:
This talk is the result of of my experiences working with Python on Google Cloud.

I love to talk about Python and software development in general. I've given talks at PyCon for the last three years, and I also speak frequently at regional Python conferences, including PyGotham, PyTexas, PyOhio, Florida Py, and more. Links to my previous talks, slides and videos can be found here: <https://di.codes/speaking>

My PyCon 2018 talk was standing room only (<https://twitter.com/Yhg1s/status/995326519999426566>), and my PyCon 2016 talk was described by one attendee as "the most concise and understandable discussion of metaclasses I've heard" (<https://twitter.com/amylouboyle/status/737707897270865925>).

I'm a member of the Python Packaging Working Group, the Python Packaging Authority and a maintainer, contributor, and administrator of The Python Package Index (<https://pypi.org/>).

I have been a professional Python developer for over ten years. Currently, I’m a Developer Advocate at Google, focusing on supporting Python users who use Google Cloud Platform.

title: The Bipolar Software Engineer
abstract: Rarely is mental health talked about in public, but even rarer is mental health talked about in the tech community. I'll tell the audience about what it's like to live with bipolar disorder while maintaining a full-time job as a software engineer.
description: Jenna Quindica was working at her third startup when she was diagnosed with bipolar disorder. Her journey has been a rocky one, marked by medication changes, mental health days, and more. She wouldn't have been able to maintain her full-time software engineering job without help, support, and encouragement from her manager and coworkers. Jenna will share how she navigated a diagnosis and now a chronic, mental illness. This is a story with a happy ending. Attendees will walk away feeling more comfortable discussing mental health in the workplace and everyday life.
notes:
I've given or will be giving this talk at: Docker HQ (internally); AnxietyTech; Square Hear + Now; #causeascene; Southeast PHP; WaffleJS (in September); Northeast PHP (in September).

I speak about Open-Sourcing Mental Illness and mention depression, anxiety, bipolar disorder, and suicide. I cover resources like the Suicide Prevention Lifeline.

title: Scrape websites to get datasets for your next Data Science project
abstract: Any data scientist wouldn't say "No" to more data. But getting good quality data, especially from the web is quite a challenge. By learning to scrape web pages, you can quickly get the dataset you see on a website, in whatever format suits you.
description:
Machine Learning, Data Science, and NLP have become hot in the recent years. But what good is your model generation capabilities, if you don't have the right data set? 

What if you could generate your own data set from all the websites on the internet? That would solve all your problems, right?

## Outline

1. Introduction to HTML DOM Tree, the difference between structure XML docs vs. HTML and how to parse it.
2. Tools we can use with examples
    1. BeautifulSoup
    2. requests-HTML
    3. Scrapy
3. Write your first crawler.
4. Pipelines and how you can transform and add value to your scraped data.
5. Storing the data and exporting it
6. Discussion: Legality of data scraping

## Takeaways

After this tutorial session, the audience will be able to analyze how web pages are structured, scrape for information, apply various transformations on it and store it in some data store for later retrieval.
notes:
I have more than a decade of experience building products for various startups. My first job out of college was writing a scalable, distributed crawler in python using just beautiful soup and multiprocessing modules (this was the time before scrapy). This crawler had various features: not overload the hosts, fetch only the data that had changed from the previous run and also implement a pipeline to run different NLP modules on it. 

Scrapy has done most of the grunt work of crawling easy. I have built various middlewares for scrapy and have also open sourced one of it (https://github.com/cnu/scrapy-random-useragent). Recently I taught a full day workshop on different python modules for research students in Pondicherry University, India and crawling data was one of the sessions.

title: Blockchain 101: Implement blockchain from scratch using python
abstract: This talk will explain how blockchain works under the hood by implementing a tailor made blockchain using basic Python functions.
description:

Keeping in mind the above saying, I will provide a ***hands-on understanding*** of Blockchain technology using Python. There are multiple resources to get a firm understanding about this domain, but the best way to understand it is by using the concept of  **"Learning-By-Doing"**.


----------


**Following are few reasons why I want to willingly contribute to this domain:**

 - Blockchain is the underlying technology behind most of the
   cryptocurrencies and it has a potential of changing the way we work
   and communicate, making it more secure, efficient, and trustworthy.

 - There is a immense amount of speculation going around in this domain
   with the rise of Bitcoin.  What’s happening with blockchain
   technology, I would say, is similar to the great American gold rush
   that happened in the mid 1800s.

 - Innovators, investors, entrepreneurs, technologists all are hovering
   over the same underlying idea on how these cryptocurrencies work and
   how could blockchain be leveraged to create use-cases beyond

----------


Also, I would love to mention **few quotes to support the escalating phenomenon of Blockchain**:

> **The blockchain cannot be described just as a revolution.  It is a tsunami-like phenomenon, slowly advancing and gradually enveloping
> everything along its way by the force of its progression.** -- William
> Mougayar

> **Over the next decade, there will be disruption as significant as the Internet was for publishing, where blockchain is going to disrupt
> dozens of industries, one being capital markets and Wall Street.**
> -- Patrick M. Byrne


----------

As we progress, we would engage into more advanced concepts pertaining to scalability and deployment.

Using **on-the-go learning**  while developing will serve as a pivotal entry point for all the people who are willing to enter into this space and planning to  build smart-contracts or invest in cryptocurrencies.


----------


**Agenda**:

 - Introduction to Blockchain:  Existing problems, what is Blockchain, why it matters, gist of few use-cases, related concepts.
 - Blockchain under the hood: Cryptography 101, underlying data structure and algorithms, conceptual terminologies.
 - Python and Blockchain amalgamated: Create blockchain using python.
 - Discussion regarding scalability methods and resources.
 - Q&A session.


**Note: The above agenda is subject to change. It is tentative for now. Any changes will be updated here itself.**

title: Understanding multithreading by deciphering the cpython interpreter source code
abstract: In this talk, I will provide a concise understanding of Threading and Global Interpreter Lock(GIL) in Python.
description:
In the modern era of hybrid cores and processors, there is an in demand need for concurrent and parallel programming paradigms. Python, since its inception has amazing support for single threaded applications. The extensive use of Python in booming fields like Machine Learning has paved the way to constantly improve multi-threaded applications in Python.

I will speak from ground level covering very crucial aspects of Threading and Locks which will provide a better roadmap for community to develop better Python applications. I will provide a concise understanding of Threading and Global Interpreter Lock(GIL) in Python.

**Program outcomes:**

 - How threading can improve performance, its pros and cons.
 - What works best in which environment between threads and processes.
 - Why GIL matters the most in Python
 - How to leverage the power of open source source code to understand the crux of language.

**Contents to be covered:**

*1. Threading for noobs:*

 - Terminologies: Process, threads, multithreading, multiprocessing, types of threads, locks, mutex, CPU and I/O bound processes.

*2. Understanding the global interpreter lock (GIL):*

 - Impact of GIL on CPU and I/O Bound Processes
 - In-depth understanding of GIL using cpython interpreter source code
 - Reference counting
 - Ticks via context switching

*3. Infamous concepts:*

*4. Removing the GIL:*

title: Recursion for Beginners: A Beginner's Guide to Recursion
abstract: Recursion has an intimidating, almost mythic reputation. But recursion isn't difficult so much as it's often taught poorly. I've discovered several concepts to teaching recursion that are often overlooked (the callstack, before/after recursive calls) that can break down this topic to beginners.
description:
Recursion has an intimidating reputation for being the advanced skill of coding sorcerers. But in this tutorial we look behind the curtain of this formidable technique to discover the simple ideas under it.

Through live coding demos in the interactive shell, we'll answer the following questions:

* What is recursion, and when is it a good idea and bad idea to use it?
* What's a stack, and what's the call stack?
* What are stack overflows, and how do we avoid them?
* What are all the confusing ways that recursion is commonly taught?
* Do some problems require recursion? How do I transform recursive code into iterative code, and vice versa?
* What are some common recursive problems in whiteboard coding interviews?
* What is memoization and tail call optimization?
* How do I draw that cool-looking fractal artwork using recursion?

Beginners will be able to follow this talk. All that is required is a willingness to learn, and a willingness to have the willingness to learn, and a willingness to have the willingness to have the willingness to learn, and... so on.
notes: I’m the author of several programming educational materials in the form of books, online courses, and web videos. I gave a two-hour tutorial version of this talk at a conference, and am currently writing a book on recursion.

title: Understanding Caching in Python
abstract: In this talk, I am going to talk about advanced concepts of Python related to Caching. I will describe in depth the different methods of Caching, their pros and cons. This talk will help developers focus on their code before scaling their applications.
description:
## In this talk, I am going to talk about advanced concepts of Python related to Caching.

----------


A cache can be easily understood as **a saved answer to a question.** Caching can speed up an application if a computationally complex question is asked frequently. Instead of the computing the answer over and over, we can use the previously cached answer.

Caching is an important component while scaling applications which are to be used by many users. It solves various problems related to cost and latency. Usually it takes more time to retrieve data from DB rather than cache. Using a cache to avoid recomputing data or accessing a slow database provides us with a great performance boost.

I will describe in depth the different methods of Caching, their pros and cons. This talk will help developers focus on their code before scaling their applications. It will provide immense performance improvements with this simple concept.

**Outcomes:** The novice audience will be able to understand basic Caching Mechanisms. They will be able to utiilize their knowledge which will serve pivotal while scaling applications

----------


**Contents to be covered in talk:**

 1. Local Caching: What is it, how to do it, example, built-in Python libraries: (using *cachetools*), advantages, dis-advantages  

 2. Memoization: What is it, pseudo-code algorithm, implementation using example, built-in Python libraries: (using *lru_cache*), advantages, dis-advantages  

 3. Distributed Caching: What is it, techniques: (using *memcached*, using *pymemcache*)


----------
**Agenda:**

 - Initial 10 minutes: Introduction to Caching and its various techniques.  
 - 10 - 20 minutes: Examples and code walk through for various techniques.
 - 20 - 25 minutes: Comparative analysis of how caching is better than non-scaled applications.
 - 25 - 30 minutes: Q&A session

title: Develop Yourself Through Meditation
abstract: Meditation has been shown to help with productivity, mood, stress, and even depression, and developers experience these things all the time. Unfortunately, meditation seems mystical from the outside. We’ll get to the core of what it really is and how anyone can reap the benefits of meditation.
description: Developers spend a ton of time worrying about system performance or application architecture, but how much time do we spend on ourselves? Modern languages like Python have had a significant effect on developer happiness which leads to massive productivity and meditation can take that even further. Learn how you can take a few moments for yourself to become a better developer, mentor, and community member.
notes:
This talk is a soft talk without any actual code and will apply to everyone. I plan on having the entire group go through a single minute of silent meditation, without any guidance because that’s what people think of when they think meditation without digging any deeper. From there we’ll break down what meditation is, and show the incredible benefits that it can have on a person’s health and productivity. Along the way, I intend to reference studies on meditation and use my own experiences to help make the benefits more tangible. My hope is that the by the end of the talk, I’ve demystified meditation and that my call to action will prompt everyone to take a few moments for themselves to gain more focus and control in their lives.

I have a bit of an obsession with habit hacking, and about a year ago I decided to give meditation a shot although I felt ridiculous. It was hard for quite a while because my understanding of it was wrong, but once I got down to the core of what meditation was it completely changed my life. The difference was so noticeable that the CTO of my company asked me what had changed in my life. I was more productive, less irritable, and overall just happier. After having someone point this out to me, I dug a little deeper into the effect of meditation and realized that the list is incredible. Developers, designers, and others in tech deal with a lot of stress, self-imposed perfectionism, constant distractions, and even depression. Meditation can help with all of these things to make our lives more enjoyable and make us feel empowered to rise above the current situation. Meditation might not be as flashy as improving the performance of your applications, but for me, this has been much more important.

title: Probabilistic Programming and Bayesian Deep Learning
abstract: Bayesian deep learning has combined the benefits of probabilistic programming and deep learning to generate scalable model for uncertainty estimates.This approach is a leap towards making artificial intelligence truly intelligent alike humans
description:
While creating model for solution of any real life scenario modelling uncertainty is really important. Traditionally, machine learning provides some approach such as Gaussian Processes for modelling uncertainty but these approaches can't scale to high dimensional inputs like images and videos.
On the other hand deep learning algorithms are great for high dimensional inputs but struggles to model uncertainty.

The solution to the problem described above is the topic of my talk -Bayesian Deep Learning .The talk will be about how probabilistic programming, which has been good in modelling uncertainty and deep neural network, which can scale to high dimensional inputs like images and videos, can be combined into Bayesian Deep Learning which provides a deep learning framework and can also model uncertainty.The talk will cover different types of uncertainties and how to model them with Bayesian approach using python libraries(Edward and ZhuSuan) to create safe A.I. 

I'll utilise the time of my talk as follows:

0-10 mins: Introduction to the problem in hand, of modelling uncertainty and why deep learning is not 
                  good enough for the problem. What is traditional probabilistic approach to the problem and it's 
                 shortcomings for high dimensional input, leading to the introduction of Bayesian Deep Learning.

10-20 mins: Explanation of basic mechanism and mathematics behind Bayesian deep learning with some 
                   examples.Description of various types of uncertainties such as Epistemic and Aleatoric which 
                   need to be modelled.

20-30 mins: Introduction to Edward python library and it's usefulness for creating Bayesian deep learning 
                     frameworks. Some example problems to show the working of this library .
                     Introduction to ZhuSuan python library and how it is useful in creating Bayesian deep 
                     learning framework along with some examples to show it's workings.
notes:
I have always been upfront to share cool exciting stuff with the people in general and I believe that Applied PyCon Canada is providing one of such great opportunity. I will be presenting my talk on Bayesian Deep Learning, which is one of the important pillars of making A.I. truly human-like intelligent by including the probability aspect of reality. Recently, I presented my talk in PyCon Thailand 2018 , and I was overwhelmed with the amazing response from the audience who attended my talk

In the talk which I am going to present I will be explaining about the importance of  this probability approach along with how and why it  must be used to solve problems in combination with deep learning.Just like Capsule Networks the importance of Bayesian Deep Learning is that it’s not just another method which has improved the accuracy marginally ,but it’s a new paradigm which has changed the whole perspective with which we look at problems in Artificial Intelligence

The talk will be quite comprehensive and expect the audience to have basic knowledge of neural networks. It’s not a workshop, so the audience need not worry about technical requirements. I believe I can be a really good addition to the list of speakers and I hope to be there

abstract: Your children and teenagers can learn valuable programming skills on their own!  But which resources and strategies actually work and at what ages?  As an author, software engineer, and homeschooling father of 6, I've accumulated proven methods to teach young programmers.  Let me show you how!
description:
# Prepare Your Kids to Control Their Future

You're probably aware that software engineering is among the fastest-growing career paths in existence today, and it's projected to only get bigger in the next generation.  You may desire for your children to learn these valuable skills, but you may also lack the time, patience, or skill required to teach them.

## What Options are Out There?

I'll be frank with you: almost all of the books and courses on the subject of coding--even those directed at children--move at a pace that is much too fast for the average child to follow without additional guidance, explanation, and review from a knowledgeable teacher.

Those few courses that do move at a child's pace usually suffer from another problem: they teach a simplified, sandboxed coding language--one that is difficult to build upon or develop into any real in-demand skills.  In some ways, this is comparable to your child becoming an expert at a single video game.  It doesn't translate well to actual IT job skills.

I know this to be true as I have sifted through dozens of books, courses, online tutorials, pdfs, and reviews in my efforts to teach my family of 6 homeschooled children how to code.

## Save Time and Do What Works!

There are a few good resources out there for children of any age to learn coding.  In this entertaining, informative talk, I will break down what works and what doesn't and leave you with many practical action steps to start your children into developing some of the most valuable skills they could ever learn!
notes:
## A Little About Me

I am the author of the 5-star book _Code for Teens_.  I have a 4-year Bachelor of Fine Arts degree in Musical Theater.  I am fantastic in front of a crowd.  I also have 6 kids at home and many hilarious stories to tell that illustrate the main points I'm making in the talk.  I guarantee my talk will be highly informative, engaging, funny, and well-received.

## Conclusion

I hope you'll allow me to share the strategies I've developed for teaching children to code.  I guarantee this talk will be a hit!

title: Listening to the voice of the data : The importance of exploratory data analysis and data visualization in machine learning
abstract:
Every data set has a unique voice hiding behind it, listening to it helps to obtain confidence in your data to a point where you’re ready to engage a machine learning algorithm.
When you torture a dataset, it can confess just anything but listening to it brings out the voice of its heart.
description:
All the data in the world is useless if you cannot understand it. EDA and data visualization are the most crucial yet overlooked stage in analytics process. This is because they give insights on the most relevant features in a particular data set required to build an accurate model. It is often said that the more the data, the better the model but sometimes, this can be counter-productive as more data can be a disadvantage. EDA helps avoid that.

EDA is useful for professionals while data visualization is useful for end-users.

For end-users: A good sketch is better than a long speech. The value of a machine learning model is not known unless it is used to make data driven decisions. It is therefore necessary for data scientists to master the act of telling a story for their work to stay relevant. This is where data visualization is extremely useful. 
We must remember that the end-users of the results are not professionals like us but people who know little or nothing about data analysis. For effective communication of our analysis, there is need for a detailed yet simple data visualization because the work of a data scientist is not done if data-driven insights and decisions are not made.

For professionals: How do you ensure you are ready to use machine learning algorithms in a project? How do you choose the most suitable algorithms for your data set? How do you define the feature variables that can potentially be used for machine learning? Most data scientists ask these questions. EDA answers these questions explicitly. Also, EDA helps in understanding the data. Understanding the data brings familiarity with the data, giving insights on the best models that fit the data set, the features in the dataset that will be useful for building an accurate machine learning model, making feature engineering an easy process.

In this talk, I will give a detailed explanation on what EDA and data visualization are and why they are very helpful in building accurate machine learning models for analytics as well as enhancing productivity and better understanding for clients. I will also discuss the risks of not mastering EDA and data visualization as a data scientist.
notes:
Over the years, machine learning has been on the rise – and that’s given birth to a number of powerful machine learning algorithms. So powerful that they almost tempt you to skip the Exploratory Data Analysis phase. While it’s understandable why you’d want to take advantage of such algorithms and skip the EDA – It is not a very good idea to just feed data into a black box and wait for the results. It has been observed time and time again that Exploratory Data Analysis provides a lot of critical information which is very easy to miss – information that helps the analysis in the long run, from framing questions to displaying results.

The focus of EDA is making sense of the data in hand – things like formulating the correct questions to ask to your dataset, how to manipulate the data sources so you can build a relationship with a new data problem to get the required answers 

Some risks of not performing exploratory data analysis includes:

• Generating inaccurate models

• Generating accurate models but on the wrong data

• Not creating the right types of variables in data preparation

• using resources inefficiently because of realizing only after generating models that perhaps the data is skewed, or has outliers, or has too many missing values, or finding that some values are inconsistent.


Outline of this talk

	Introductions 

	What is Data Visualization

	Categories of Data visualization

	What is explanatory data visualization

	Why EDV is important for data scientist

	What is exploratory data analysis

	Methods for EDA 

       •	Univariate graphical method

       •	Univariate non graphical method

       •	Multivariate graphical method 

       •	Multivariate non graphical method

	Benefits EDA brings to machine learning projects 

     Risks of not mastering EDA and data visualization

	Key Takeaways

title: Machine Learning: from zero to computer vision
abstract:
It happens to all of us: that weird moment when you realize that your phone or computer just did something impossible. How the heck could an algorithm caption your pictures or understand your movie reviews?

Let me show you how, by giving you the technical foundations of Machine Learning.
description:
A specter is haunting the world of programming – the specter of Machine Learning.

All of a sudden, the stuff of science fiction is real. Cars drive themselves. Algorithms recognize faces better than you and I can. Language translators went from “source of amusement” to “better than humans”, seemingly overnight. How the heck is that even possible?

Even with all the hype around Machine Learning, many developers are still wary of it, because it feels so foreign. The field is teeming with math jargon, research-y conventions and, sometimes, bad code. Rather than blog posts, people point you at academic lectures and obscure research papers. For many of us, this stuff is as intimidating as it’s fascinating.

In this half-a-day tutorial for Python programmers, I will walk you through the foundations of Machine Learning. You don't need to know the basics: I will lead you from zero to a computer vision program that recognizes hand-written characters. Along the way, I will mostly use code and animations (rather than mathematical formulae) to explain Machine Learning concepts. Get ready to enter a whole new field!
notes:
**Warning: I selected the "Tutorial (60 minutes)" format, but this tutorial is actually 3-4 hours long. Although it doesn't match your requirements, I'm submitting it anyway, in case you're willing to accept a tutorial that spans multiple slots.**

This is a machine learning tutorial for absolute beginners. It's the extended, tutorial-ized version of this talk:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zbxtlQaJZ7M

There is one requirement: people must be comfortable with Python. Ideally, people will bring their own laptops and run the code that I'll share from GitHub–but it's also possible to follow the tutorial without running the code, as a traditional frontal lesson. I'll build in some space to experiment and take a break from the lesson.

I need an Internet connection, a big screen. A whiteboard and markers would be nice.

title: Teaching Yourself to Learn (Again) : Cognitive Theory for Professional Development
abstract:
My skills are obsolete! Legacy Python has a death clock! Whether you're alarmed or excited, our industries are evolving. How can we level up without necessarily going back to school?
This talk will focus on 6 principles of expertise. Learn from "How People Learn" with examples from Machine Learning!
description:
**This talk begins with a discussion of why we need to be lifelong learners.** No bootcamp, university, or other time-boxed education program can prepare us for everything - especially in industries that are immersed in disruption and development. So what is the value of an education? And how can we keep up (or level up) without necessarily going back to school?
**Using research from the field of cognitive science, the remainder of the talk covers theories and specific strategies for how to approach learning needs.** The 6 principles of expertise are defined and described, using examples from machine learning to compare and contrast novice-like learning with expert-like learning. Other topics include metacognition, Growth Mindset, and "artisans vs virtuosos." Participants will leave this talk with research-driven perspectives on expertise that will empower their own growth.
notes:
I'm a Machine Learning Advocate and former math teacher with a master’s degree in Educational Research & Assessment. As a self-taught career changer, I drew on my experience teaching others and crafted my own educational program for a successful entry into the rapidly evolving field of data science.
I feel very strongly that professional development is a crucial skill in tech fields because our tooling evolves fairly drastically throughout our careers. My hope in this talk is to provide inspiring insights and actionable strategies that participants can use to motivate and improve their own learning.

title: Keep your Flask secure
abstract: What is Flask doing to keep you secure? What should you do to keep Flask secure? Learn about what to keep in mind and look out for to design a web application that keeps your users and data safe.
description:
Flask is great for writing applications of all sizes, from small data APIs to huge social platforms. It's so easy to get started, that even experienced developers may not consider if their app is ready before deploying. Flask does some work for you, but there's a lot that you need to do as well.

This talk will give listeners a lexicon of terms and techniques to be aware of when developing a Flask (or Django, etc.) application to stay secure. It will provide a broad overview of topics, rather than covering the technical details of attacks and mitigation in depth. It's appropriate for beginners, but all levels should be aware of these issues.

There are multiple layers to a WSGI application, and security is involved in each. Within Flask, issues include escaping user input for XSS, tokens for CSRF, securely signing data, and hashing passwords. Above Flask, at the WSGI and HTTP server, configuration can mitigate DOS attacks, and the server itself should be secured too. Least well known due to its rapid evolution are the various ways to tell modern browsers how to keep the user safe on your site; Flask-Talisman provides a drop-in solution for this. Finally, there are tools and resource to check and keep up to date as these measures continue to evolve.
notes:
I have not presented this talk before.

Even though I maintain Flask, I often didn't think about these issues until recently. It's important that every developer has an awareness of security issues and best practices to make the web a safer place for users.

# Description

In the late 1990s, a man named Danny Hillis decided he wanted to build a clock that would tick for ten thousand years. As software engineers, we don't really think about building software at this timescale, when code that's been in production for a few years is considered "archaic".

In this talk, we'll discuss how the design principles used to build a clock that lasts ten millenia make pretty good guidelines to build anything to last a long time, including software.

title: Inside the Cheeseshop: How Python Packaging Works
abstract: This talk identifies key tools one might encounter when distributing Python software, what they are used for, why they exist, and their history (including the source of their weird names). We'll see how they work together, what it takes to make them work, and what the future has in store for them.
description:
# Description

Questions and confusion about the Python packaging ecosystem abound. What is this `setup.py` file? What's the difference between wheels and eggs? Do I use setuptools or distutils? Why should I use twine? Do I put my projects dependencies in a `requirements.txt` or in `setup.py`? How do I just get my module up on PyPI? Wait, what is Warehouse?

This talk will identify the key tools one might encounter when trying to distribute Python software, what they are used for, why they exist, and their history (including where their weird names come from). In addition, we'll see how they all work together, what it takes to make them work, and what the future has in store for Python packaging.

# Who and Why

This talk is for any Pythonista that has been confused by Python Packaging (read: everyone).

This talk requires that the audience has just the slightest familiarity with how Python Packaging works -- that you need to upload your source code, that there are a few popular and familiar tools, and that they are all a little confusing. Attendees do not need to be publishers of Python Packages but likely will be people interested in publishing someday.

After watching this talk, attendees should have a significant amount of their confusion about the Python packaging ecosystem resolved, and should be able to make informed, reasonable decisions when they want to publish a package (without having to be told step by step instructions, or given extremely opinionated advice).

# Outline

* Introduction
  - Who am I?
  - What is a package?
* Dependencies
  - setup.py
  - requirements.txt

  - source

  - wheels

title: Test Driving Flask Applications
abstract:
Unit tests, acceptance tests or end to end tests… What are the tests we should focus on? What are the tests that provide the most benefit to us?
Come along to learn about trade-offs between different testing strategies and how to write those tests without them slowing you down in the long run.
description:
The physical layout of a Flask application is more or less defined by the way Flask handles HTTP requests. But it doesn’t stop there. The core of our application shouldn’t be defined by the way Flask expects things to be laid out.

Designing applications like this is also known under different names like Hexagonal Architecture by Alistair Cockburn (also "ports and adapters"), Clean Architecture from Bob Martin or Onion Architecture as Jeffrey Palermo called it.
But more important than the name are the ideas and benefits behind those architectures: Modelling our software in the language of the domain. Making it explicit and obvious that we're not writing a Flask application that handles online orders but that we're creating an e-commerce application that happens to use Flask to be able to be used through the web.

In this hands-on workshop you’ll learn different testing strategies for the different parts of an application. From testing that the HTTP layer works as expected all the way down to verifying that the entries inserted into a database are correct.

With an exemplar application like this it’ll be easier for us to see and draw parallels to the testing pyramid and explain why it makes sense to invest more into low level unit tests, and gradually remove the amount and need for more high level acceptance tests.
notes:
There are many ways to go about testing an application as a whole, but in past projects I’ve been part of at 8th Light, several patterns have emerged that helped us keeping our tests nice, clean and fast!
This hands-on workshop shows several of those practices and tools we’ve successfully used in many projects now. In the end it’s always a trade-off so I will also talk about downsides of certain approaches.

It is expected that participants have a working Python development environment installed.

abstract: Have you ever wondered what happens between the time you run `helloWorld.py` and the terminal prints out “Hello world”? I will be sharing the wonderful and interesting process of how the Python interpreter works from the Python source code to the compilation of bytecode.

This talk will share a brief overview of how CPython works from lexxing to compiling as well as how the abstract syntax tree (AST) works. At the end of the talk, you'll be able to understand the general concept of the abstract syntax tree (AST) and how creating a interpreter can additionally benefit you in ways unrelated to the actual compilation such as linting and debugging.
