title: Check yourself: using checklists for repetitive tasks
abstract: Medicine and Aviation use checklists to allow skilled people to perform repetitive tasks consistently. While operating most software isn't (often) life or death like those industries we can use checklists in order to educate our teammates, and reduce human error.
description:
Growing up I was lucky enough to participate in a program called the "Young Eagles". This program was started with the support of aviation pioneer Chuck Yeager and is focused on introducing children to aviation. I participated a number
of times which meant I got to fly in a small airplane. Each time before taking off the pilot would take out a laminated card and read it out loud. As they read each step they would perform a simple action, and make an observation before
continuing onto the next step. This pilot has been flying for many years, but **every** they would go through this checklist.

This pilot is not alone in using checklists in order to achieve safe operation of their aircraft, but instead exemplifies the culture of the industry. In their book *The Checklist Manifesto* author Atul Gawande tells the story of how a B-
17 (WW2 era bomber aircraft) crashing on take off would lead to the first checklist. This checklist, and it's proliferation led to many tasks of flight being codified with a checklist.

Atul Gawande's book also describes how checklists improved various tasks in medicine such as running a line (not quite sure what this means, but they say it on Grey's Anatomy all the time), and delivering a baby. Because these tasks had
been routine practitioners would accidentally skip steps because their brains disengaged after performing a task for the nth time.

Developing and maintaining software doesn't often pose the same risks as aviation and medicine, however using checklists to consistently perform repetitive tasks is something that our industry could benefit from. Checklists allow us to
take what we learn from retrospectives and incrementally improve. By using checklists as a living document for the canonical way to perform a specific task we can educate one another and learn from past mistakes.

In this talk I would also like to talk about:

- [ ] How checklists intersect with automation. Since some aspect of repeatable tasks can be automated using scripts what should be performed by a human and what should be scripted.
- [ ] What makes a good checklist. What makes a checklist useful and something that you and your team would **want** to use rather than something you and your team **should** use.
- [ ] (if there is time) What are some ways to keep a collection of checklists up to date.
notes:
This talk should have few technical requirements beyond a projector and a mic. 

After watching Nicolas Steenhout's PyconCA 2017 talk "Accessibility, POUR, and the Pythonistas" I intend to describe the contents of my slides in an effort to make the talk more accessible to individuals with a visual impairment.
additional_info: I don't require any special meals or assistance.

description:
API-Driven DevOps  
===


##### A Python powered API Engine

###### By Kaz Al-Kazwini ( [@lekaz](https://github.com/malkazwini) )

---
<!-- page_number: true -->

# Topics

- Into to REST APIs
- API Driven DevOps

- The Solution
- Why HUG ?
- HUG in Action
- Demo
- Question

---

# Intro to REST APIs

APIs are the foundation on which the modern digital economy is built. APIs are wonderfully versatile things, enabling a business to expose content or services to internal or external audiences. 
Businesses can use APIs to accelerate multichannel strategies, improve internal processes, thrill customers, encourage developers to extend and even develop entirely new business models.

Purpose: 
- **Consumed by an application**
- **To interact with an Application**
- To interact with a IoT devices 
- Developers which consume APIs

---

# API Driven DevOps

DevOps projects contain REST APIs and microserviced architecture on different cloud endpoints. can lead to a mesh architecture and can add more complexity to extend and evolve. API-Driven DevOps is the organization around APIs, make them reusable, make them centralized, make them developer friendly




---


# Why DevOps need APIs ?

- Interoperability
- Self-service
- Dashboarding
- Automation


---

# Typical DevOps Tools Stack 

# ![](./ReactiveDevops.png)



---
# Reality 


# ![](./tools_set.jpg)


---
# The problem with tools 

- Complex meshed architecutre 
- No glue between tools
- Magic code for connectors
- No maintaince on custom applications (Dashboards, Automation, etc.)
- # ![](./meme_cat.jpg)

---

# The Solution

### A centrlized layer for APIs, which acts as an aggregation for all tools:
- Developer friendly
- Interoperability is achieved in a single location 
- No hidden code and magic connectors 
- Automation is simplified
- Custom APIs for certain CLIs

---


# Why HUG ?

#### Part 1
Python is famously used in a large number of web applications frameworks, and a major part of  this  area  is  web  services in  which  APIs are  exposed  for  other  users’ or applications  to consume, publicly and privately. Django REST  framework and  Flask are the main two popular  choices, but you may not yet have heard of the extermly friendly "hug"

[HUG API](http://www.hug.rest/): is a library that provides a very simple way to create custom REST APIs for various services. By using some of the language features in Python, much of the usual boilerplate normally required when creating APIs for web services is removed.



---
#### Part 2
Hug goes a long way to make you feel welcome. And that’s it! We can immediately test our APIs. You could use a web browser for this, or you can use a tool like cURL
You call: the URL endpoint with the correct parameters, and hug returns the response

It’s impressive to create live web API up with so little work. And the features don’t stop there: 
hug can automatically generates API documentation, which is what you get by missing an endpoint:

title: Lessons learned open sourcing (and maintaining) my first library
abstract: Last year, I open-sourced my first library, PyMC3 Models. This talk has two parts: things I learned as I was writing my library and some of the issues I faced being the sole maintainer of the library. I hope you’ll be encouraged to open source and maintain your own library after this!
description:
Last year, I open sourced my first library, PyMC3 Models, which features custom PyMC3 models built on top of the scikit-learn API. This talk is about some of the things I learned along the way. 

The first half will focus on lessons learned while writing my library:
- The importance of just starting: releasing even a small bit of work is worthwhile because it could help someone. 
- Using toy examples: implementing a basic linear regression helped me improve the broader structure of my package. 
- Documentation: Spending time on documentation was tedious in the beginning, but paid off in the long run.
- Copying: I borrowed heavily from other open source libraries and that’s totally ok!

The second half will focus on being the sole maintainer of the library including:
- how to handle normal contributions
- strategies for dealing with aggressive contributors
- taking care of yourself when you’re the only one working on a library

I hope this talk will encourage you to start your own library and give you some tools as you maintain it.
notes:
Many talks I’ve seen about open sourcing have been given by white men. Part of the reason I want to give this talk is to be an example of a non-white woman doing this type of work and to highlight some of the difficulties with contributors while maintaining a library.

Here are some selected talks I've given in the past: 

- Turning PyMC3 into sklearn, PyData NYC, November 28, 2017 (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zGRnirbHWJ8) 

- When Worlds Collide: Productionalizing a Data Science Model (w/ Tudor Radoaca), PyData Chicago, August 28, 2016 (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZCQHoAMZJsM)

- A Quickstart Guide to PyMC3, PyData Chicago, August 26, 2016 (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rZvro4-nFIk)

title: Terraform + Salt for Cloud
abstract: Terraform is the go-to multi-cloud orchestration tool and Salt is a well known Python-based configuration management system. Pair them together and you have an end-to-end cloud infrastructure management system. Learn how to leverage the power of the duo to master cloud devops automation.
description:
HashiCorp Terraform enables you to safely and predictably create, change, and improve infrastructure. It is an open source tool that codifies APIs into declarative configuration files that can be shared amongst team members, treated as code, edited, reviewed, and versioned. Salt (sometimes referred to as the SaltStack Platform) is a Python-based open-source configuration management software and remote execution engine. Supporting the "Infrastructure as Code" approach to deployment and cloud management.

Terraform can be used to control infrastructure deployments and lifecycles in multiple clouds (orchestration) whereas salt is used to configure and manage servers and other devices. 

In this tutorial we will cover the ABCs of Terraform and Salt: we will learn how to deploy different types of virtual machines on different platforms using Terraform and configure them with Salt. We will learn how the two can be linked and used to deploy a complete Django stack; the example will highlight the one of the biggest advantages of the approach - freedom from cloud vendor lock-in - so you can be confident your stack is easily movable from one infrastructure provider to another.

The tutorial will be partly based on the terrasalt open source project, link: https://github.com/bigbitbus/terrasalt
notes:
The tutorial will cover getting started with Hashicorp Terraform and Salt.

We've used the pair successfully internally at BigBitBus Inc. (http://www.bigbitbus.com/); our blog posts as well as our cloud-comparison tools derive all data from infrastructure spun up using the Terraform+Salt stack.

Working code and examples are in this OSS project: https://github.com/bigbitbus/terrasalt

title: Fantasy for Hackers
abstract: Crush your friends with friends with pandas, beautifulsoup, flask and sqlite
description:
I never really got professional sports. I didn’t find them all that interesting. And I thought that following teams and players was a complete waste of time. That was all until I got dragged into a fantasy league with some friends and won a bunch of money on the back of a couple of Python scripts. 

Now I’m in my third year of Fantasy and I’m completely addicted. Maybe not to sports, but to winning. 

In ‘Fantasy for Hackers’ you’ll learn how to fetch and aggregate stats, how to draft, how to simulate weekly matchups, and how to evaluate trades. 

You should walk away convinced that you don’t have to follow, or even like sports to be good at Fantasy. You just have to know a little Python. Specifically: enough pandas, beautifulsoup, flask and sqlite in order to crush your unsuspecting friends.

title: Accessible Algorithms
abstract: Defeat your enemies, save the environment, and win your fantasy league!
description:
al•go•rithm - noun /ˈælɡərɪðəm/ A word used by programmers when they do not want to explain what they did. 

Of course, that’s not actually the actual definition. But it sometimes feels like it is. And it’s a shame because… at a fundamental level an algorithm is just a recipe. A step-by-step guide for how to do something. 

In ‘Accessible Algorithms’ we’ll use simulation, visualization, and extendable functions to expose the important steps of a couple of noteworthy and useful algorithms. 

Specifically we’ll learn about how to defeat your enemies with Colonel Blotto, how to save the environment with PageRank, and how to optimize your fantasy team with the knapsack problem.
notes: This will build upon the success of my 'Amusing Algorithms' talk delivered at PyBay 2018, but will be self-contained and completely, 100% new!

bio:
Stuart Williams is a Software Architect at IGM Financial (Mackenzie Investments & Investors Group) where he helps teams with their use of Python for Data Science, operations, and web development.

He has taught Computer Programming at University, at summer camps for high school students, and at grade schools. His Python tutorials, taught at the North American Python Conference for over a decade, have received 60,000 views on YouTube.

He founded the Winnipeg Python Users Group, now the Python Winnipeg Meetup in 2005, and the Winnipeg Data Science Meetup in 2017.
title: Data Science with Python
abstract:
Data Science is hot. But what is it, and why is it in such high demand? And how can Python, an interpreted language, be one of the two most popular tools for it?

We'll answer those questions and then give a hands-on tutorial showing how Data Scientists use Python and Pandas, and how you can, too.
description:
Data Science is an emerging field that draws from Mathematics, Statistics, Computer Science, and Information Science. Its subdomains include machine learning, classification, cluster analysis, data mining, databases, and visualization.

Python is the fastest growing well-known general purpose programming language, and along with R is one of the two most popular languages for Data Science.

In the first half of this session we’ll explain exactly what Data Science is, why it’s in such demand, why Python is so popular with Data Scientists, and how an interpreted language such as Python can be fast enough for them.

The second half will start with a hands-on tutorial showing you how to use Python, Pandas, and Jupyter Lab for data exploration and analytics of some typical data sets IT professionals would explore such as logfiles from web or batch servers, and client data.

We’ll then demonstrate using Python to apply some basic Data Science techniques to various open and realtime data sources such as Twitter or municipal open data from Winnipeg or Toronto.

For the hands-on tutorial participants should prepare their laptop (Windows, Mac, or Linux) by installing the latest Anaconda Python distribution from http://Anaconda.com/downloads before coming to the conference.
notes:
This 1-hour tutorial should work even for novice Python users. The target audience is those want to learn more about Data Science, or how Python can be fast for Data Science, or how to use Pandas for data analysis.

I’ve presented the first half of this session twice this year, to the Winnipeg Data Science Meetup and the Python Winnipeg Meetup. I will be presenting it at a regional conference in Winnipeg, Prarie Dev Con), in late October.

The hands-on part of the second half will be very similar to the demo part of the same presentation, presented twice as mentioned above, but I’ll switch the examples to web server logs and some large fake client data sets as might be explored by someone maintaining a web server as part of diagnosis or understanding users, or an analyst answering questions about a client base.

In the the last part I’ll explore and prepare some analyses and choose one that is engaging by being specific to the conference, Winnipeg, or Manitoba, but not too complicated so it’s understandable in under 15 minutes and can be extended by participants after the session.

Ideas so far include: - Semantic analysis of tweets of past conferences or the one in progress during the presentation - Winnipeg Transit API data - not very interesting but I’m familiar with it - Winnipeg Traffic System data on traffic signals across the city

The Anaconda installation mentioned in the description is very straightforward. For student that forget to download it beforehand I’ll bring some thumb drives. The Jupyter Lab interface mixes documentation, code, and visualization so it will be easy for participants to work in it during or after the session with fairly little oversight. I may, however, try to bring in one or two assistants for that section.

title: Engineering Pop Songs with Python
abstract: Have you ever wanted to create music, but were intimidated by learning an instrument? Have you wanted to learn how to program, but we're afraid of learning cryptic commands? If so, this talk is for you? Let's learn the fundamentals of programming to re-create a well known pop song!
description:
In this workshop, we'll discuss the fundamental structure of programming and music with the use of Python. Python is a widely-used, and human readable programming language that allows users to quickly write code and solve problems. We'll discuss the structure and rules of music:

* Basic Music Theory and Notes
* The Major Scale
* The Minor Scale
* Chords

We'll take all of these concepts, and using the power of Python, re-create a famous pop song using only our computer! This talk is great for understanding the following concepts in Python:

* Basic types
* Classes  with an OOP paradigm
* Data Structures
* Control Flow
notes: This workshop is designed to get attendees up to speed on some basic and intermediate concepts of Python in a fun, and thought provoking way. Both subjects, programming and music, sometimes suffer from a lack of clarity from outside observers. We'll spend the first half of the talk learning about music, and then applying the rules of music in a programmatic fashion in the second half. We'll finish off the talk with the end-result being a re-creation of a song, in digital audio.

name: Christoph
bio: Christoph Gockel is a Software Crafter at 8th Light who enjoys writing clean code almost as much as watching Ghostbusters.
title: Why you need to TDD all the time and other lies
abstract: Very often discussions about TDD end up in absolutes. We either do TDD or we don’t. But building quality software is about pragmatism. We should TDD when we need to. And we should skip writing a test first when we need to. There is time and space for both approaches.
description:
The last sentence of the description is key here. I'm a strong advocator for TDD. I've taught many teams the benefits of it. Yet I don't do it all the time. When tests or TDD would slow me down, I'll skip them. This is most of the time to gather feedback quicker, or to gain new insights into the project I'm on. This doesn't mean the feature I'm on will not end up having tests at all.

But it's always a trade off. Do we want stability and confidence or do we need new insights?
This lightning talk tries to show both sides of the discussion. In the end we'll end up somewhere in the middle, with most things test driven and some parts either still untested or tested after they've been implemented. And that is fine.
notes: At 8th Light we help a lot of customers improving their code quality. Often by improving the test suites of their products. There's a lot of shades of testing and figuring out what level of scrutiny to apply is important. Nobody wins if all that is being discussed is whether or not we're writing an acceptance test or an "integration test". We should be discussing whether or not the test we're writing improves our confidence in our product.
additional_info: No special meals or assistance needed.

title: Julia for Numpythonauts
abstract: Julia 1.0 has just been released, and it's time to get excited.  A dynamic, performant language for numerics which supports first-class metaprogramming, Julia solves problems that we have to resort to Cython and Numba to address, and some we have no solution to.  Rediscover the joy of numbers!
description:
Do you work with a lot of numerical code in Python?  Don't you love the beauty and power of the numpy ecosystem, and how easy it makes working with data compared with our friends suffering under more "enterprise-level" languages?

.. but in the quiet spaces in your mind, have you found yourself frustrated with an algorithm which almost but not quite vectorizes, and so you have to fall back on a slow Python-level loop?  Have you ever had to drop out of a DataFrame back to ndarrays so that you could use numba?  Or wrestled with getting a compiler working on Windows so your Cython extension would run?  Have you ever had to restructure your code into an unnatural shape because it would be too slow if you wrote it from the Book?

And have you ever asked yourself the dangerous question "if we're going to be adding type annotations to all our code nowadays, shouldn't we get some benefits out of it?"

Welcome to Julia, a language _by_ the scientific computation community, _for_ the scientific computation community, both beginners and experts.  We'll summarize the highlights of what Julia can do for your numerical coding, and provide a bridge from our NumPy experience to the Julian world.  With Julia having influences from Lisp to Fortran, and with NumPy being a major source of inspiration, you'll fall in love with numerical programming all over again.

Come find out what the "Ju" in "Jupyter" is all about!
notes:
Technical Requirements
-----------------------------------

None, really-- the talk will probably be given as a mix of a standard powerpointy talk, actions at a console, and Jupyter notebooks.

Qualifications
--------------

As for why I'm a reasonable candidate to give this talk, I've been writing numerical code for 25 years.  I earned my stripes developing symplectic integration algorithms and creating parallel implementations of them to study planetary formation.  I've done numerics in a wide variety of languages, and have spent a lot of time in the Python ecosystem, both as a user and contributor.   At time of writing, I'm the #10 all-time answerer in the numpy tag on StackOverflow, #9 in scipy, #7 in pandas, and #14 in julia-lang, and have made substantial contributions of code to both pandas and the SageMath project.

(Okay, #14 in julia-lang doesn't actually mean that much, they don't get nearly as many questions as they should.  But that's something I'm trying to correct..)

name: Anton Nguyen
bio: Hailing from the cold northern plains of Canada, Anton had nothing better to do while growing up then basking in the warmth of his computers. Following graduation, Anton eventually ended up at FreshBooks. There he regularly leads an intrepid team of developers through the harrowing twists and turns of software development, weathering the IT world with pride and gumption. Also, he's a forking badass.
title: Rain or Shine - How Freshbooks Guarantees Email Delivery
abstract: Our customers rely on FreshBooks everyday to send invoices to their clients. Having such a important role in our customer's business, meant FreshBooks had to build a system that was dependable, reliable, and resilient to all disasters that could strike when delivering email!
description: FreshBooks sends over a million emails every year. And no, I'm not talking about marketing emails telling you about some exciting new email we've just released. I'm talking about transactional emails. When you sign up and verify your account, we send an email. When you send an invoice to your clients, that's an email. When you you want to reset your password, that's an email. Email is not only a critical part of FreshBooks, but of our customers. How can clients pay their invoices, if they don't receive them? In this talk, I'll be going over how FreshBooks built dependability, reliability, and resilience into our email infrastructure, so that we can guarantee that our emails are delivered.
notes:
The system we built utilizes a message broker system, where multiple applications simply sends messages into an AMPQ stream of events. The application that responds to these messages and coordinates the delivery is a python microservice that allows us to:

1. Create high/low priority lanes for different types of emails
2. Instantly switch between any email vendor that we've integrated with
3. Build a reliable pipeline that will never drop or lose an email

I'm the best person to speak on this subject, because I drove many of the changes that allowed our application to evolve to its current state.

title: The Art of Developer Testing
abstract: Tests ensure our program works as intended and that changes to the codebase do not break existing functionality. This talk will demystify the Art of (Developer) Testing with a focus on best practices and tools that can be used to help you write effective tests more efficiently.
description:
Seasoned developers have experience balancing writing code to solve business problems versus writing tests to ensure correctness and prevent regression. Finding this balance and knowing what to test can feel more like an art than a science, especially to those new to the industry.

This talk will introduce testing concepts in the context of a Flask web application. Topics include:

* Blackbox vs Whitebox testing
* Automated vs Manual testing
* Test Pyramid (unit, integration, and end-to-end tests)
* Test coverage
* Introduction to pytest
* High-level overview of tools that make testing easier
notes:
[Link to Slides](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1oI29-S6wFs8Yeqe5TouFak2kPF-pqnvNd66yQWn12Vs/edit?usp=sharing)

I previously presented this talk at an IndyPy Meetup in July.

title: Building a CMS in Python with Django+Wagtail
abstract: I often hang up when I hear a client request Wordpress as a project requirement. Creating an intuitive CMS in Python using Wagtail provides the web admin with amazing tools and allows devs to design powerful software. In this talk, we'll investigate the power of Django+Wagtail's and its workflow.
description:
## Overview
In this talk, I will give an overview and real-time coding demos of the power of Django+Wagtail in building intuitive content management systems. Wagtail is a framework built on top of Django that adds a whole new level of power to the Python platform. 

Whether you are familiar with Django or not, this talk is aimed at anyone looking to try out something other than the industry go-to of Wordpress while exploring the workflow. The talk includes an overview of features, common custom CMS issues that Wagtail handles gracefully, and code examples of creating page models and customizing the admin.

* Installing
* Data Migrations
* Multisite Support
* Internationalization
* Media Management
* WYSIWYG Editors
* User/Permission Management
* The Community
* And More!

name: Andrew Francis
title: Okay computer, please renew my loans: Prototyping Library Applications with Python and Voice SDKs
abstract: Physical libraries are great! Managing library material via web interfaces leaves much to be desired. In the age of Siri and Alexa, why can't one manage one's library loans with text messaging or voice? This talk discusses questions and answers by prototyping a  Python based conversational agent.
description:
Brick and mortar libraries are great! Managing library material via the typical web based OPAC (online public
access catalogue) of one's public library leaves much to be desired. In the age of Siri, Alexa, Cortana, Google
Assistant, etc why can't one manage one's library membership via text messaging or voice? Since the author didn't
know, he set out to find answers through prototyping a simple conversational agent (the Library Patron Agent),
focusing on the Amazon Alexa SDK. And the author could not think of a better language to prototype than Python.
Python figures prominently both in the construction of the web back-end server, as well as various command-line
utilities for language model construction.  In the course of developing the LPA, more questions than answers were
created. However two questions will be addressed: is it feasible for an application to support multiple voice SDKs?;
what is the division of NLP labour between the front-end and backend? One thing is certain, how one answers these questions has a profound impact on architecture and the tool-chain.

Introduction (< 5 minutes)
-----------------------------------------
   - Demo "Please renew my copy of Tom Sawyer" 
     - renewed by voice and sms
   - A description of the Library Patron Agent 
   - Why this is a toy (hint lack of standardised API for library circulation)? 
   - Two questions
       - what would happen if I wanted to support Google Assistant or Siri too?
       -  how does Alexa, Google Assistant, etc know Tom Sawyer is short for Adventures of Tom Sawyer? Or does it? Whose responsibility is this?

Anatomy of a voice app (< 5 minutes)
----------------------------------------------------------
   - Communication flow between front-end, the voice system and the back-end
     + Python modules used (Flask, SQL-Alchemy)
     + proprietary input     
     + output W3c standard SSML 

The Development Cycle (< 2 minutes)
------------------------------------------------------------

The Front-end and Language models (10 minutes)
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   - What is a language model
   - Example of different vendor language models
   - Annotation and testing tools 

The Back-end ( ~5 minutes)
-------------------------------------------
- The processing of "Please renew my copy of Tom Sawyer."
- NLP on the backend
- example: handling incomplete titles (NLTK and Spacy to the rescue)
- SSML generation

Conclusions and Future directions (< 2 minutes)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
notes:
The only technical requirement is the ability to pick up the audio from say, a Raspberry PI and or a laptop. I'll probably do a dry run of the talk somewhere to figure out the proper requirements.

I do not have a formal background in NLP. Much of this talk is about "Beginner's Mind." In 2012, I gave a Pycon Canada talk called "How to Solve a Problem Like Santa Claus." If one were sprinting last year at Pycon Canada 2017, one may have remembered me canvassing folks for feedback on the Library Patron Agent. In a former life, I was a computer scientist at Adobe.

title: Flying Python – A reverse engineering dive into Python performance
abstract: This presentation will look into the inner mechanics of Python in an attempt to suggest a different approach to writing Python code. In doing so, we will offer suggestions about how to make your Python code perform better.
description:
The original idea for this presentation stems from a passion for code performance and reverse engineering.
While there is a wealth of information on how to make C or C++ code faster, there is generally a lack of deep understanding of the Python interpreter preventing Python programmers from achieving what we call “conscious programming”. To elaborate, programmers often have to resort to using known best practices, sometimes without knowing why a given technique is faster, or more advisable, than another one. Obviously, using best practices is often enough. However it is our opinion that in order to own the craft of programming, programmers should be able to obtain and understand second level knowledge about how their tools and computer actually execute the code they are writing.
In this talk we will use a case well-known in the Python community: List comprehension vs. Loop for list initialization. However, we will explore it from the point of view of a reverse engineer and treat the code the same way C code would be treated. In doing so, we will question the way code is executed and suggest alternative or interesting angles to apply to programming in Python.
It should also be noted that in this talk, we purposefully chose to present the subject in the context of the current environmental crisis. Indeed, more performant code would run faster thus use less power to do the same job, potentially resulting in impressive savings in power consumption.
This presentation has never been presented and has been prepared specially for the PyCon conference.
notes:
There are no special requirement for this talk other than a projector and screen.
Based on my reverse engineering experience, I was often exposed to low level code (machine code level). From this, I developed a passion for code performance and code reading. That is also when I first noticed many errors (performance related) I was doing when writing higher level code. Learning how to write assembly code changed the way I write higher level code. Indeed, that gave me insights into how my higher level code was being translated for the computer to execute. However, even with this knowledge, languages like Python often poses a performance challenge. This is because the language uses an interpreter. This presentation was therefore born from a desire to explore python and its inner working in a quest to learn how to write better python code. My objective is to deliver a python performance related talk that can appeal to all programmers. The hope is that more and more programmers develop an interest into code performance and that we can collectively write greener code.

title: Choosing The Adventurous Route: The Career Track For Non-Managers
abstract: Your training, experience, and passion are all in computer programming, but sometimes you feel like a locomotive stuck on the track toward management. It's not true: you can deepen your skills, get promoted, and expand your influence as an individual contributor for the rest of your career.
description:
No Q & A during the time slot, but I'll encourage people to come talk with me in the hallway afterward.

(5 minutes) *Your career, on rails.* It often feels like when you reach a point of seniority, you inexorably become a manager. I experienced this once: I was a senior engineer due for a promotion, and I was forced to choose between two bad options. Either I could become a manager, swapping the job I enjoyed and did well, for a job I had not been trained for and didn't want to do. Or, I could refuse the promotion. What I actually did was quit and go freelance in order to get off the management track. But more recently I've joined a company that provides me an alternative.

(6 minutes) *The hidden rail switch.* There is another track available. Some companies offer a promotion path that allows you to expand your influence and responsibility without becoming a manager. When you switch onto this track you can continue advancing without giving up the work you love.

(8 minutes) *The adventurous route.* What does a very senior individual contributor do? Mentor junior engineers, and teach them to be mentors. Advise managers. Design very large, complex products. Establish practices and processes. Save projects in crisis. Write and speak in public, and coach others who want to write and speak. Unlike management, this track requires you to invent ways to spread your ideas.

(9 minutes) *Risks of derailment.* A senior individual contributor still codes, but you will code less than you did. You must relinquish some of your favorite coding work, and learn to enjoy writing designs and doing code reviews. You must find unorthodox ways to lead without commanding, e.g. by teaching classes or writing guides. You must learn to be satisfied by the spectacular achievements of the people you help, rather than by your personal achievements. Just like the management track, this track leads toward selflessness.

(2 minute) *Plan your route.* If you have a passion for management, by all means do it. We need good managers with coding experience. But if you don't want to manage, seek the hidden switch. Work for a company with a career path for individual contributors, or demand that your employer creates one.
notes:
I have not given this talk before. It is based on my experience working on one team at one company for over six years as it grew from 30 employees to over 1000, and IPO'ed.

title: Writing resilient code with retries
abstract: The internet is a scary place, and lots of things can go wrong when we’re trying to access remote services. In this talk learn common approaches to building resilient code using backoff, retries, and circuit breakers. Examples using modules like redo, tenacity, and circuitbreaker will be given.
description:
Assuming that your network requests will always succeed results in fragile code and applications. We want our applications to be resilient to short downtimes, so that we can deploy new versions of an application with confidence, migrate a database, or many other practical reasons.

Simple approaches to retrying network requests often make problems worse via a stampeding herd, or unreasonably long delays due to nesting retries. We will cover some basic approaches, and how they can be improved on using techniques such as exponential backoff and applying random jitter. Several modules exist on pypi that can be used to retry function calls or blocks of code such as redo, tenacity, and circuitbreaker.
notes:
I haven’t presented this topic before, but have written lots of code that needs to retry most of its operations! It's a common source of intermittent failures in production infrastructure, where everything from DNS to packet loss will eventually strike.

I'm happy to tailor the length of the talk to time constraints. It could be a quick 10 minute intro, or a slightly more in-depth 30 minute talk.

title: The Future of ChatBots in the Travel Industry
abstract: Imagine the future where an intelligent assistant suggests you places you could visit on the weekend. And plans the whole trip for you as well. The bot already knows your preferences and previous experiences, and makes you an offer you cannot refuse. Won't that be wonderful? This is the near future.
description:
The Future of ChatBots in the Travel Industry
Introduction
Imagine the future where an intelligent assistant suggests you places you could visit on the weekend. And plans the whole trip for you as well. The bot already knows your preferences and previous experiences, and makes you an offer you cannot refuse. Won't that be wonderful? This is the near future, my friends.
Everyone who loves to travel wants to have a smooth travel experience. ChatBots are trying to serve the needs of the users, coming up with content personalized according to each user. Wouldn’t you want to search for a hotel on the fly without setting up a plan to find the perfect getaway holiday for you? ChatBots in the travel industry are changing our overall experience and expectations of the trip. I believe natural interfaces will play a major role in e-commerce.

How does it work? 
There are a lot of stages that are involved in processing the sentence that the user says, and coming up with an intelligent reply: 
1) The intent of the message (Book a hotel, Customer Support, Filters, Sorters, etc.)
2) Keeping in mind the previous conversations. 
3) Understand if the user is conveying something particular (Number of people in the trip, Number of days, Currency, Exact dates, Not sure about the dates etc.)
4) Figure out when the user comes back after a certain amount of time, if they are starting a new conversation, or continuing the same one. 

These are some of the parts that needs to taken care of before coming up with reply. Each of these parts are handled separately. 

There are two major parts of the ChatBot: 
1) The brain of the Bot: Talks to the user, identifies if it can reply directly, or needs Natural Language Understanding to parse the intent of the user, and then come up with a smart and relevant reply. 
2) NLU (Natural Language Understanding) : This part of the bot parses the sentences and comes up with intents in the message with some confidence. 

Why is this important? 
1) Mobile App time Spent Grows 69% Year-Over-Year.
2) There are ~1.3 billion active users on Facebook. ChatBots have the potential to impact their lives and help them with their travel needs.
3) Chat outperforms voice in user tests as people perceive chat to be more natural, faster, and more intelligent .
notes:
Why Me?
I work at Booking.com in the ChatBot team, and I would like to share some insights, learnings and feedback from our users over the past few months. The difference in the experiences of users when talking to the ChatBot has been striking. There have been a lot of cases where the ChatBot understood each and every part of the conversation, and cases where the users were the ChatBot misunderstood the message a user was trying to convey.  

Why explain technical challenges? 
I believe first-hand experience is the best way to learn something. Sharing this experience with the audience will be intriguing for them, and will keep them involved in the talk. I will share some insights which will look pretty straight-forward but when we ponder on them, the audience will feel that those insights indeed play an important role in designing the ChatBot.

name: github@zli2.com
title: Making graphical interfaces from geometric primitives
abstract: Through a prototype demo, we'll see how to quickly and easily build GUI elements like buttons, text fields and status bars *without* using a GUI toolkit. We'll only need circles, lines, text and input events along with some parsing techniques.
description:
# Abstract

Instead of using one of the existing GUI toolkits (such as
GTK or QT), we want to build graphical interfaces from only circles,
lines and text (and input events). Through a prototype demo, we
explore how a library for this task could work.

Our demo makes use of a language written in a Parsing Expression
Grammar and the corresponding (modified) packrat parser to handle
input events and track states. Eventually, we'd like to blurs the line
between the editor and edited and have a single continuous program
from toolkit to editor to interface.

# More information for reviewers

This is a rather fast-paced 10 min lightning talk which is more showing than explaining. It has previously been given at local meetups with success.

This talk has previously been given at local meetups (name given in the notes) with success.

The project demonstrated during the talk is my own project.

title: Using Python to Quantify Portfolio Diversification
abstract: Diversification is a portfolio construction and risk management technique used in finance that aims to minimize the impact of any single investment’s performance on that of the total portfolio. How can Python be used to measure diversification in a quantitative fashion?
description:
This talk is about the term ‘diversification’ and its application within finance using Python. More specifically, it is about how Python can be implemented to measure diversification in the areas of portfolio construction and investment risk management.

The talk will focus on explaining the theoretical framework surrounding diversification, present examples of quantitative diversification metrics, and demonstrate how such measure may be used to construct and manage an investment portfolio.

It will show how common python libraries (such as Pandas and Scikit Learn) may be used to compute traditional diversification measures like number of unique investments, as well as more modern approaches based on extensions of principal component analysis.

There will be a discussion regarding the trade-off between intuition and sophistication when constructing a measure, as well as the importance of examining multiple measures at once when determining the diversification of a given portfolio.
notes: This talk has not been presented before, and it would be my first time presenting at PyCon if the talk were to be accepted. The talk will be presented using a Jupyter Notebook. Requirements are the ability to project onto a screen and connect a laptop to said projector.

name: github@zli2.com
title: How to build a parser from scratch and where to use it
abstract: A parser turns strings to useful tree shaped data structures. We'll see that parsing doesn't need to be hard by showing a 503 lines Python script without imports that can parse Python itself. The talks explains how the library version of the script works and it use in expected and unexpected places.
description:
A parser turns strings to useful tree shaped data structures. Parsers are typically used as a first step in an interpreter or compiler. Throughout a demo, I will describe an easy way for making a parsing library that is powerful enough to parse Python syntax and many other languages. It is based on the thesis "Experimenting with Programming Languages" by Alessandro Warth, with some modifications.

Depending on the time left, a number of examples use cases for this parsing technique will be shown amongst:

- A grammar for bootstrapping the parser itself
- A pretty printer
- An interpreter for some of the Python language
- A C implementation
- An x86 assembly implementation
- A graphical user interface toolkit maker

Also if time permits, I will show how to debug in this parsing library.

# More information for reviewers

This talk is a trimmed down version of a 90 minutes presentation given at the local Papers We Love meetup. I will present only the beginning with a session of pasted code in the Python interpreter and showcase some applications instead of speeding up more, in hopes that most of the audience will at least be able to follow the earlier portion.

All implementations discussed are my own.

## Audience level

I'm not too sure what "Audience level" to put for this one. All the Python code shown will be fairly simple. However, the new concept does take some time to absorb for those not used to it.

At the Papers We Love presentation, the audience was pretty engaged the entire time despite the length of the talk and many came to tell me they enjoyed it. But they could ask for clarifications during the presentation (because of the format) and some told me they didn't follow a portion of the talk.
notes:
# Alternative format

Although the first 30 minutes would stand alone just fine, this talk may benefit from more time.

It may be possible to instead have a 60 minutes tutorial. However, ideally participants would get to write their own parsing libraries from scratch but I think 60 minutes is too short to both accept the new concepts and be able to write a working parser library (even a more simplified one). We could just have people *use* the library I'm presenting, but that is less interesting since one of the main selling points is that it is easy to create.

# Profile

I've left the Profile Details section on Papercall empty, not knowing how Papercall will treat it. My personal webpage is zli2.com but this project is hosted elsewhere.

title: Open Sourcing at Work
abstract: We just open sourced 2 projects (datacompy, and locopy) with roots in Data Science and Engineering which we will showcase. While is it exciting and rewarding to share your ideas with the world it isn't always easy. Thinking about licenses, copyrights, and protect confidential information is a must!
description:
Working in a large organization which is embracing the mantra "open source first" is really exciting. Part of this journey is to make sure we give back to the open source community when we can. Two of our projects had gained traction internally: `datacompy`, and `locopy`. As part of our commitment we wanted to make sure we could open source these projects for others to use and contribute back to.

DataComPy is a package to compare two Pandas DataFrames. Originally started to be something of a replacement for SAS's PROC COMPARE for Pandas DataFrames with some more functionality than just Pandas.DataFrame.equals(Pandas.DataFrame) (in that it prints out some stats, and lets you tweak how accurate matches have to be). Then extended to carry that functionality over to Spark Dataframes.

Locopy helps load flat files to S3 and then to Amazon Redshift, and assist with ETL processing. It is DB Driver (Adapter) agnostic, provides basic functionality to move data to S3 buckets, execute COPY commands to load data to S3, and into Redshift, and UNLOAD commands to unload data from Redshift into S3.

While building these products was exciting and fun, some of the legal considerations were as interesting, complex, and required collaboration between many teams, from security, licensing, brand, and IP/copyright. We'll explore the projects, and some of these other considerations which can make or break if you decide to release a project into the wild, along with the road blocks we faced with in these areas.
notes: Having recently been involved in 2 new open source projects, I really would love to share with the audience some of the considerations we faced and the end result of our journey in open sourcing.

title: An intelligent shopping list based on the application of partitioning and machine learning algorithms
abstract: A shopping list is an integral part of the shopping experience for many consumers. Several mobile retail studies indicate that potential customers place the highest priority on features that help them create and manage personalized shopping lists. We propose one solution written in PYTHON.
description: First, we propose to develop a new model of machine learning written in Python3.6 and planning to predict which grocery products the consumer will buy again or will try to buy for the first time, and in which store (s) will the area he will shop. Second, we will develop a smart shopping list template to provide consumers with a personalized weekly shopping list based on their historical shopping history and known preferences. As explanatory variables, we will use available grocery shopping histories, store promotion information for the given region, as well as product price statistics.

name: Paul Ganssle
bio:

title: Contributing to Open Source: A Guide
abstract: Contributing to open source can be a rewarding experience, but many people don't know how, or find the process confusing or frustrating. This talk tries to bridge both the technical and social gap between new contributors and maintainers to help the listener have a positive open source experience.
description:
Open source software powers a huge amount of the technology you use every day. Maintainers often exhort the public for contributions, but many developers find the process complicated or don't think that they have any skills they can contribute.

This talk will cover:

   - The different ways *you* can contribute to open source projects
   - The technical process of using GitHub for Issues and Pull Requests
   - How to maximize the chances that your contributions will be accepted

If you think it sounds cool to be able to make a meaningful contribution to software that touches millions of lives, but never thought you could - this talk is for you. If some open source software you use has a bug in it that just never seems to get fixed - this talk is for you. Even if you don't see the appeal of contributing to open source projects and just want to learn why you might want to do so - this talk is for you.
notes:
- I am the sole maintainer of `python-dateutil`, which is a very widely-used
  open source project (though not an amazingly high-traffic project), and one

  at *many* projects, including large projects like CPython, matplotlib and pandas.

name: Markus Holtermann
bio: Markus is a Django core developer since early 2015 with a particular focus on the migrations framework. He discovered Python and Django in 2010 with ubuntuusers.de. Markus currently lives in Berlin, Germany and works as a senior engineer at crate.io in Germany.
title: Thoughts About Normal and Abnormal Data
abstract: A lot of our data lives in databases. A lot of those databases are relational databases. They are called relational due to how objects refer to each other. But just because having references between certain records is “normal” and “what you should do” it doesn't mean it's the best choice.
description: This talk is about educating attendees on database normal forms (1NF to 3NF). Normalizing data to 3NF is rather common and solves a lot of problems. However, when it comes to database query performance, _not_ normalizing some data and storing parts of it denormalized instead can make a huge difference. I'll point out the differences between the normal forms and show what difference database normalization or denormalization can make.
notes:
Given a 30 minute slot, I estimate 5 minutes for Q&A. The remaining 25 minutes are used as such:

* Introduction and what the talk is about (2 minutes)
* Explaining what the 1st to 3rd database normal forms (by Codd) are (8 minutes)
* Examples to show where normalization is helpful or counterproductive (15 minutes).

The examples in the last part of the talk will either include code examples of simple Django views or raw SQL, depending on audience.

name: Markus Holtermann
bio: Markus is a Django core developer since early 2015 with a particular focus on the migrations framework. He discovered Python and Django in 2010 with ubuntuusers.de. Markus currently lives in Berlin, Germany and works as a senior engineer at crate.io in Germany.
title: On The Look-Out For Your Data
abstract: Do you have data in the database of your Django project? Do you want to find that the needle in the haystack of your data? There are plenty options how you can achieve that. With various levels of complexity, confidence, and reliability. I'll give an insight into what the most common are nowadays.
description:
You're tasked with building a search for the project you're working on. But where do you start? What search implementation are you going to use? There's a sheer unlimited set of ways to implement "I'm looking for X in Y" out there. Elasticsearch, LIKE and ILIKE queries, MySQL's Fulltext S, PostgreSQL's Fulltext Search, Solr, Whoosh, Xapian, to only name a few. I'll be looking at the most common ones and showing some basic implementation techniques.

You should be familiar with Django in so much as that I'm not talking about how to create or update an object in a database. You should also have an idea of what database transactions are. The talk will feature some code snippets that I will provide in full, afterwards.
notes:
Given a 30 minutes slot, I’ll estimate 5 minutes for Q&A. The remaining 25 minutes are used as such:

* Introduction and what the talk is about (2 minutes)
* General notes on search (3 minutes)
  * one needs to keep their data updated in the search index
  * complexity considerations
* `__icontains`, the bare database level "search" (5 minutes)
* PostgreSQL's FTS using `django.contrib.postgres` (5-10 minutes)
* Elasticsearch _basics_. Pointing out the gotchas; where to look-out for (5-10 minutes)
* Questions if desired. Otherwise, the last two points get more time. (5 minutes)

title: Less Obvious Things To Do With Django's ORM
abstract: Django’s ORM is powerful. And it has been for ages. It only became even more powerful over the last years. Django’s ORM can be intimidating because it can do so many things. And it can also be confusing when trying to find out how to do things.
description: I want to point out some features that are likely less obvious to people starting with Django but super helpful to know or at least to have heard about. There’s a whole bunch of stuff in the ORM that goes just beyond the first exposure somebody has with Django’s ORM. This starts with `select_related()`, over `prefetch_related()`, goes on to `annotate()` and `aggregate()` and how the `annotate()` and `filter()` can screw each other.
notes:
Given the 30 minutes slot, I’ll estimate 5 minutes for Q&A. The remaining 25 minutes are used as such:

* Introduction and what the talk is about (2 minutes)
* Giving a quick introduction to what the ORM is (4 minutes)
* What benefits `select_related()` provides (5 minutes)
* When `select_related()` is not usable anymore and one needs `prefetch_related()` (5 minutes)
* Introduction to `annotate()` and `aggregate()` (5-10 minutes)
* BONUS (if I got time left): behavior change of putting filter() before / after annotate() * (4 minutes)

title: How not to overfit your predictive models
abstract: This talk will give a brief overview of validation & selection techniques for predictive models and common occurrences of overfitting when building models in python. We'll walk through some strategies to mitigate overfitting and build better models.
description:
Overfitting is a common problem for anyone who builds statistical models in python and it can be challenging to 1) identify that a model is overfitting and 2) to figure out how to maintain good model performance while also maintaining that performance over time. 

We'll start by walking through some examples of detecting an overfitting model and then I'll give a brief overview of some of my favourite techniques for dealing with overfitting including using regularization, ensemble methods & cross validation, and techniques for feature generation and selection. Hopefully this talk will give a quick and informative cheat sheet to people starting out or trying to level up their data science skills, so they can have a more critical eye when they're building their next model in python.

abstract: Data Science is an increasingly popular field,different from traditional software development.Every company is jumping onto the data science bandwagon-but what exactly does it mean?What do data scientists do and what steps are involved in the Data Science pipeline?Join me to unravel these mysteries.

name: Pradeep Reddy Raamana
bio: Pradeep Reddy Raamana is a neuroscientist with research interests in healthcare, machine learning and informatics. organization: Rotman Research Institute, Baycrest Health Sciences, Toronto
title: Why is Python ideal for research software development?
abstract: Python is showing an incredible growth in many fields, including academia. By enumerating the challenges we face in sustainable research software development and how Python's unique strengths are catering to them, I hope to explain this growth and encourage further adoption for scientific computing!
description:
There is a good reason why more Americans have searched for Python than for Kim Kardashian in the last year. In fact, there are many good reasons, for why Python is undergoing incredible growth in broad array of fields. In this talk, I focus on its growth in research software development. I would start by enumerating the [many] desirable qualities and requirements for sustainable research software development. They include being highly readable, having low barriers to learn and collaborate, rapid prototyping, ability to easily grow a script into a big project, and the ability to quickly make packages of all sizes distributable. In addition, support for data gathering (esp. over the web), high interoperability with other languages (for pipeline building) and high-performance computing are highly desirable, given the complexity and size of the academic data is only growing. Then, I hope to show how the unique strengths of Python are catering to these requirements well. In addition, combined with a strong undercurrent of open source, multidisciplinary research and need for web-accessibility, python is proving to be ideal for research software development. 

Moreover, I hope to convey the recommendations from the academic/research software community to further improve the status quo, such as leaning towards open software validation as a scientific society, establishing easy and agnostic validation guidelines, and badges to encourage the adoption of best practices, eventually leading to their endorsement. As it is difficult to communicate this multi-dimensional topic, I encourage you to read my blog post on this topic, focused on neuroinformatics can be found on my blogpost: https://crossinvalidation.com/2018/05/03/lets-focus-our-neuroinformatics-community-efforts-in-python-and-on-software-validation/

Thanks and looking forward to joining PyCon folks!
notes: Why am I the best person to speak on this subject? I have 10+ years in developing multidisciplinary research software at the intersection of computer scientists and clinicians. Having started in Matlab and then moving to Python entirely, and working with diverse stakeholders in academia, I've lived experience in the problems I have identified. Hence, I believe my suggestions are relatable, applicable and valuable to many working scientists in neuroscience and beyond.
additional_info: Prefer to avoid beef or pork.

name: Éric Araujo
bio:

Montréal-Python organization team member

Speaker at PyCon US and CA
title: Settings and secrets from local to production
abstract: Web applications live in many environments, from the developer's laptop to a staging server to multi-host production deployments.  How do we make app configuration files flexible without duplication?
notes:
- Starting from a typical django app
  - silent errors: `from .local_settings import *` → ok for local, not on servers!
  - bug magnet: `from .base import *` → duplication, hard to extend list settings
  - weird API: django-configurations

- settings vs secrets
  - sensitive information forever in VCS history :(
  - why change the code for a new hostname??

- Fixing the problem
  - using os.environ : good idea, real problems (subprocesses, /proc)
  - using URIs : ops-friendly format, supported by dj-database-url etc
  - using configstore : improvement on os.environ, works everywhere, developed and used by my company

name: Chris Fournier
bio: Chris leads one of Shopify's data platform engineering teams, developing a Pyspark-based ETL framework for data processing in Ottawa, Canada. He's interested in having a minimalist programming experience, having moved from using Eclipse as an editor to vi/emacs, and from relying on an editor to tell him about a software project to instead using Unix tools, and trying as much as possible to only interact with the command-line when developing.
title: Unix + Python = ❤️
abstract:
Need to write a shell script on a Unix platform? Next time, don't use bash, use Python! Learn how to create maintainable and testable scripts in Python.

Let's cover the basics of creating a script, handling console input and output, advanced topics like file descriptors and pipes, & unit testing.
description:
When writing a shell script, you might think that you'll just write it once to handle this one task, and that will be it. But then other people have the same problem and could also use the script. Some take it and adjust it slightly to solve their permutation of this common problem, and 300 lines of bash and 2 months later you can barely remember how the script worked. If only you wrote this script in a more readable language.

Enter Python, the perfect scripting language for your console needs. Learn how to write a maintainable script to handle many of the situations you would on the command line, including:

  - Making a script executable
  - Distributing a script in a module
  - Handling console input/output
  - Working with file descriptors
  - Piping data between scripts
  - How to unit and integration test a script
notes:
I've been writing Python shell scripts used by over 100 data scientists for the last 2 years at Shopify.

At Shopify, our data warehouse's ETL software is primarily written in Python. Our team maintains that software and writes scripts for our data scientists to use on a daily basis to accomplish tasks.

title: Serverless Computing for Folks That Still Kinda Like Servers
abstract: Serverless computing seems to be the new craze, but for a lot of folks familiar with traditional "serverful" computing, the benefits might be hard to see. This talk will explain what serverless computing is, why it is so popular, what it is best suited for, and how you can make effective use of it.
description:
# Description

The demand and support for serverless computing is increasing every day. To some, it may seem like just a new craze or fad. For anyone with experience with traditional "serverful" computing, the benefits might be hard to see. However, they exist!

This talk will explain what serverless computing is in a way that is approachable for beginners and experts alike. We'll dissect why it is so popular, from both the perspective of the users of serverless computing, as well as the providers of serverless computing infrastructure. We'll dig in to what use cases serverless is best suited for, and how you as a developer can make effective use of it.

# Outline

* Introduction
* What is serverless?
  * Common misunderstandings and confusions
* Computing with servers
  * Evolution of traditional computing
  * Problems that lead to where we are today
* Advantages to "going serverless"
* Identifying uses for serverless computing
  * Example: triggers
  * Example: webhooks
  * Example: bots
* Conclusion

title: Everything They Told You About Contributing To Open Source Was Wrong
abstract: In this talk, we'll dissect the most common pieces of advice that are given with regards to becoming an open source contributor, and why they can be problematic. We'll look at a few examples of how an attempt to contribute can go wrong on so, so many levels, and what can be learned from them.
description:
# Description

Making your first open source contribution isn't hard. What's hard is becoming an engaged contributor for an active project, and making meaningful and important changes that have a lasting effect.

In this talk, we'll dissect the most common pieces of advice that are given with regards to becoming an open source contributor, and why they can be problematic. We'll look at a few examples of how an attempt to contribute can go wrong on so, so many levels, and what can be learned from them.

# Who and why

This talk is for anyone who has wanted to contribute to an open source project but isn't sure how, anyone who has tried to contribute but has failed, or anyone who actively contributes but wants to become more effective.

This talk only requires a background knowledge of how open source software works (that it's community driven, volunteer-based, etc).

After watching this talk, attendees should feel empowered to become meaningful contributors to at least one open source project of their choosing.

# Outline

* Introduction
  - Who am I?
  - Everything they told you was wrong
* How I learned the hard way
  - The issue with "good first issues"
  - Open-sourcing your projects
  - Drive-by contributions
  - Stunts & Ego
* The one true way
  - The importance of context
  - In search of meaning
  - Micro-contributions
* Lessons Learned
  - No drive-bys
  - No stunts
  - Pay attention
  - Focus on what you know
* Conclusion
notes:

title: Level up your dataviz game with Seaborn
abstract: So you can make some basic charts with Matplotlib and pandas. Get more insights from your data with Seaborn, a library that takes the hassle out of Matplotlib. Easily facet your charts without making complex transformations, and make small multiple charts that are easier to understand.
description: Visualizing data is a powerful technique to better understand numbers. But Python's classic dataviz library, Matplotlib, despite its power and versatility, can be verbose and hard to master. Seaborn makes common dataviz tasks quicker and more concise. In addition to offering more advanced chart types, like violin plots and heatmaps, its power is in faceting your data. It lets you create multiple charts, each for a different variable in your data, without having to pivot or unstack long-format data. It quickly lets you see correlations with pair grids that chart columns against each other. This talk will go over some of the more useful ways to plot data that were used in CBC news reports.

title: GIS with Python: 6 libraries to know
abstract: Python has a rich ecosystem for geographic work. Whether you're creating, analyzing or visualizing spatial data, there's a library for your needs. This talk will briefly go over six of them.
description:
We're in the middle of the geospatial revolution. Tools for making maps and analyzing geographic data are making it easier than ever for people to tell stories about place and space. 

Python is no stranger to this movement. There are many tools for doing just about anything you want with spatial data, including making interactive web maps. This talk will profile six of them: shapely, fiona, geopandas, Basemap, Folium, and PySAL.

This will be a modified version of this talk, given at the data journalism conference NICAR and Python Montreal meetup:
https://github.com/robroc/GIS-with-python/blob/master/GIS%20with%20Python.ipynb

abstract:

In this talk we will be exploring graph networks and will work on analysing its various properties and features which will help us to analyse the various patterns that may exist in a network. title: Building and scaling Deep Learning Services with Deep Learning Frameworks, Flask, Kubernetes and docker
abstract: Deep learning systems have to be engineered in order to be used in solving an end to end business problem. One of the challenges in architecting and building deep learning systems are the areas of maintainability, scalability and deployments. I would like to discuss on how we solve this at omnius.
description:
Building technology platforms with AI systems requires a lot more thought process in terms of architecture and choice of tooling. The reason for this is because there is need for brainstorming around scaling, monitoring, deploying and managing the deep learning service as you would manage any other service. 

In this talk, I will be talking about how to take Deep Learning systems to production with the use of packages and tools like:

* Keras / Tensorflow / Pytorch - Deep learning frameworks providing the flexibility to write custom deep learning functions with lower level APIs 

* Flask - Flask is a micro web-framework that allows you to write REST endpoints with minimal effort. Its simple and easy to use. When paired up with Gunicorn, you can take it into production with no effort. The idea of using Flask is to provide REST end points for prediction.

* Kubernetes & Docker- Managing microservices which have a bunch of dependencies is hard to manage. Docker provides the capability of putting all the required pieces of software to run a service into one single logical box, thereby managing all the dependencies with ease. 
Kubernetes on the other hand provides the capability to orchestrate and manage these docker containers and manage the infrastructure in automated fashion with inbuilt service discovery, load balancing, self correction systems.

* ElasticSearch, Logstash & Kibana - Logging is one of the most crucial components of managing and running systems in production. With ELK, you can ship and manage logs from various services and this provides a way to evaluate how the prediction system is working in production.

* Prometheus - A tool to monitor Kubernetes clusters. This is a neat dashboard integrated with Grafana that shows the consumption of CPU and memory for systems in production, helping in evaluating how big or small the clusters should be in order to keep up with SLAs. 

* Model Versioning - A model versioning system implemented in python to manage deep learning models and version them, thereby providing the capability to reproduce the results from various experiments.

* Managing Data sets - An introduction to Git LFS and how to manage datasets. Extremely useful when working with the thought process of reproducible results. 

The focus of this talk to is to shed light on the qualms of architecting, devops and management of deep learning systems in production.
notes:
Over the years have realized the complexity of taking data science systems into production and I would like to shed some light on this area with the proposed talk. 
Have previously spoken at various Data science conferences like  Strata San Jose,PyData london, Pycon Czech Republic, FifthElephant Bangalore and AntHill Bangalore.
Extremely passionate about architecting, scaling and managing data science systems.

title: Combining Modern Tech with Traditional Music: Enhancing Angklung Performances with Python
abstract: Combining modern technology with traditional music? Why not! Listen as I explain how Python can improve the quality of life of players and conductors of an age-old traditional musical instrument, by harnessing computing power with the elegance and simplicity of the Python language.
description: [Angklung](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angklung) is a traditional musical instrument from Indonesia, which is also slowly [gaining popularity all over the world](http://www.houseofangklung.com/angklung-world-record.html). This instrument has a lot of variety in how it is performed; a common format is the orchestral format in which 15-30 players gather to form a team. Playing angklung in this way is fun but also presents some challenges that are hard to solve manually. I will show you how Python-based algorithms can be used to improve the quality of life of angklung players and managers, by helping calculate the most optimal distribution, highlighting conflict areas and missing angklung areas, and presenting it in a user-friendly interface. In addition, Python also plays a role in easing the pains of transforming western music notation to traditional musical notation ([Cipher notation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Numbered_musical_notation)). This talk will be(has been) presented at [PyCon Malaysia](https://pycon.my/) (25-26 Aug 2018).
notes: I am excited to speak on this subject because music (Angklung primarily) and programming have both been my passion for several years, and the two come together so perfectly that I can't wait to share my experiences and visions about this with others through my talk.

title: 5 Brain Science Hacks to Successfully Level Up in Programming
abstract: Leveling up in programming can be downright infuriating, time consuming & expensive. Take the frustration out of the equation with these 5 hacks based on research in educational psychology (brain science) applied to coding. Save money, time, and aggravation while expanding your knowledge base.
description:
There is a life cycle all of its own when learning something new even if that is leveling up your current skills. The natural ups and downs on the path to progress can cause learners to become stuck, encounter mental blocks, or even give up altogether. As a former college professor in the field of education, I can say with certainty, a little knowledge about educational psychology (lovingly referred to as brain science) goes a long way when you want to be a successful programmer. Educational psychology as a field studies how people learn new concepts efficiently and effectively and applies that to teaching methods and study strategies for promoting and achieving mastery.

In this presentation, I cover 5 principles of educational psychology, connect that principle with common learning situations in learning code (emphasis on frontend), and then provide suggested resources for success. The goal of the presentation is for you take charge of your learning and persevere.

If you think this presentations is just for beginners, you would be wrong. Programmers are constantly learning new languages, libraries, and frameworks. Use best practices no matter what you are learning and you will save time and money, but also frustration.
notes:
Why am I qualified to deliver this presentation? I am a former Professor of Literacy Education with years of experience teaching teachers HOW to teach, and students HOW to learn. I’ve published and presented various research-based projects throughout my time as a Professor. After years of teaching, I decided to leverage my background in education and literacy for a new career as a Front End Developer. However, I have never truly left education, and I have applied what I know about education to how people learn to code. I write a blog with the focus: A Professor’s Perspective on Learning to Code. I help new coders understand their unique learning process and their individual learning styles. I help coding instructors learn to differentiate their instruction to meet the needs of diverse learners. Further, I help coders understand WHY learning to code is complex, and how to choose the best resources to meet their needs.
